SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move that the following delegated legislation, the list of which I shall hand to the clerk, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The list read as follows—
1. Defence Determination 1997/16 made under s.58B of the Defence Act 1903
2. Locally Engaged Staff Determination 1997/7 made under s.82D of the Public Service Act 1922.
3. Quarantine (General) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 85, made under the Quarantine Act 1908.
[Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provisions apply: must be resolved within 15 sitting days after today or the Regulations will be deemed to have been disallowed.]

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include, possibly unfair provisions, administrative decisions which may not be subject to external review of their merits and inadequate notification of rights. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Defence Determination 1997/16 made under s.58B of the Defence Act 1903

SPEECH.PARA: The Determination provides for the reimbursement of costs of advertising a home for sale.

The Explanatory Statement advises that these costs may be reimbursed but that where more than one agent is engaged reimbursement is limited to the costs charged by the agent who actually sells the home. However, there may be circumstances where this provision could operate unfairly, such as where an agent is engaged to sell a home and, for some reason, such as the death or bankruptcy of the agent, the member must employ another agent to make the sale.
The Committee has written to the Minister for advice.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Locally Engaged Staff Determination 1997/7 made under s.82D of the Public Service Act 1922.

SPEECH.PARA: The Determination provides for an insurance policy issued by a specific insurance company to cover medical assistance to employees and their dependants in Lebanon.

The Determination provides for the Commonwealth to pay 90% of the medical insurance premium. Presumably the employee pays the remaining 10%. The Committee has written to the Minister for advice on whether there is a requirement for compulsory salary deductions and, if not, whether the policy could be void if an employee fails to pay the 10%.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Quarantine (General) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 85, made under the Quarantine Act 1908

SPEECH.PARA: The Regulations introduce a system of infringement notices for minor quarantine offences.

One provision defines an infringement notice offence to mean a contravention of a minor nature. There is no further definition of what is minor, which would appear to be left to the discretion of the quarantine officer.
There appear to be no review provisions relating to decisions to refuse to withdraw an infringement notice or to allow a further period to pay a penalty.
The Regulations provide for the content of infringement notices but do not require that the notice include significant safeguards affecting personal rights.
One provision provides for a discretion affecting personal rights although a mandatory provision may have been more appropriate.
The Regulations appear to include drafting deficiencies.
The Explanatory Statement is uninformative and, in some cases, slightly misleading.
The Committee has written to the Minister for advice.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE 97TH INTER‐PARLIAMENTARY CONFERENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday a report was tabled by Senator O'Chee, on behalf of Senator Watson, regarding the 97th Inter-parliamentary Conference and bilateral visit. It was not incorporated in Hansard and I seek leave to have that happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

I present the report of the Australian Parliament Delegation to the 97th Inter‐Parliamentary Conference held in Seoul and bilateral visit to Japan from 10 to 21 April 1997. This was a unique experience for me as I had the privilege to visit Seoul 14 years ago as a member of the Australian delegation to the to the 70th IPU Conference.

The 97th Inter‐Parliamentary Conference debated and discussed a range of topics including regional security and peace, sustainable development, the status of the Holy City of Jerusalem and the emergency situation in Albania and Zaire.

All members of the delegation played an active role throughout the entire Conference, participating in all facets of the conference agenda. I would like to take the opportunity to thank all members of the delegation for their companionship and assistance throughout the Conference and Bilateral Visit.

Having attended the 70th IPU Conference in Seoul, I was particularly interested to see just how far the IPU, as an international body, had come and where it saw its future focus and direction. During my contribution to the General Debate I touched on the need for the IPU to monitor and contain its costs along similar lines introduced by other international organisations. The Australian delegation is of the view that the IPU is at a critical stage in terms of its role as an effective international forum for parliamentary democracy. Many reforms are under way and other reforms are on the agenda. As part of this reform agenda, the Australian delegation felt it necessary to make a number of recommendations and conclusions which it believes should be given serious consideration by the IPU Executive and reported on at the next Conference in Cairo in September later this year.

In summary, the delegation felt that there is room for improvement with respect to the way in which the agenda is set for each particular Conference. Items placed on the agenda just prior to the Conference cannot be dealt with in an effective and consistent manner when delegates have not been given sufficient time to consider the consequences of particular actions taken at the Conference. It also became apparent to the Australian delegation that the IPU needs to follow up on all the resolutions adopted at each Conference by way of a report to the Plenary at the next Conference or via a publication. This would ensure that Conferences do not simply turn into a talkfest but there is resolution, action and results.

Because of the stance taken by the Australian delegation at the Seoul Conference, I believe it is vitally important that the Australian delegation sends a very strong and experienced contingent to the Cairo Conference so as to ensure that a number of very important matters that were left unresolved at the Seoul Conference are dealt with adequately and effectively at the 98th Conference in September.

The Australian delegation is in a unique position as it continues to play an active role in both the Asia‐Pacific and 12 Plus Geo‐political Groups. Both these groups are instrumental in setting the agendas for future conferences as well as monitoring and reviewing a range of issues germane to the activities of the IPU.

From a personal point of view, I was taken by the changes that have occurred in South Korea since 1983, particularly with respect to the progress in economic and political terms and the standing of the Republic of Korea in the international community. While the progress is noteworthy, many stumbling blocks still remain on the path towards peace. The greatest remaining challenge is the peaceful reunification of the Korean peninsula.

Members of the delegation took the opportunity while in South Korea to visit the demilitarised zone. While it is very easy for any visitor to be side‐tracked by the propaganda that is evident through the construction of opposing buildings in the zone, the erection of bigger flagpoles, the parading and positioning of soldiers and the strict adherence to a set of protocols, it does not take long for visitors to be reminded of the very serious side to the DMZ. While tensions between the North and the South remain tense, there is a glimmer of hope in the President Clinton initiative to establish four‐party peace talks involving the North, the South, China and the US. The delegation wholeheartedly supports this initiative in the hopes that there will be a breakthrough in the negotiations and that a path towards normalisation of relations can be achieved. Tragically, the famine in the North has compounded the conflict to the extent that the North Koreans are unwilling to allow aid to flow freely into the country which would help relieve some of the misery and starvation faced by many millions of its people.
I would now like to make a few observations about the bilateral visit to Japan.

The first thing to note is that the relationship between Australian and Japan is not simply one centred around trade The close relationship has manifested itself in many areas including sister‐city relationships, friendship agreements and a host of other cultural and commercial agreements. These agreements and treaties are also underpinned by a very significant movement of visitors in both directions.

The Australian delegation was received at senior levels throughout the visit. Many meetings and discussions with Presiding Officers, Ministers, Parliamentarians and senior business people ensured that the delegation was able to obtain up‐to‐date impressions on a range of regional and international issues. As former Prime Minister Nakasone told the delegation, Australia and Japan, form the pivotal North‐South axis in the all important Asia‐Pacific Region. It is therefore in both our interests to consolidate existing ties and forge new agreements so that we can maintain a very prominent alliance in what is the fastest growing region in the world.
In the time I have available I would like to turn briefly to a few of the issues that we discussed during the bilateral visit to Japan.

In terms of our bilateral relationship, Australia is now seen as a natural partner to Japan in the region in which we share a range of very similar interests. Defence links have entered a new phase with the number of discussions taking place in recent times and this has added a further dimension to the relationship whereby each country has come to rely on the other's support in both regional and international forums in recent years.

The Japanese economy has emerged from almost no growth in 1993 to around 2 and a half percent in 1995 and is expected to achieve only moderate growth over the next two to three years. However, all other economic indicators would be the envy of any other developed country; low unemployment, low inflation, healthy current account surplus and strong investments. As I said, most countries would be more than satisfied with these fundamentals but Japan knows that it must push on with its program of reform if it is to retain its pre‐eminent position in the Asia‐Pacific Region. The only down side to these impressive figures is the chronic public debt problem which stands at around 780 trillion Yen. It is this fact alone that is driving the long overdue administrative and structural reforms. However in most other countries this would be great cause for concern but in Japan this is manageable simply because the banks are prepared to take a longterm view of debt.

On the trade front, it goes without saying the Japanese market is crucial for many of our agricultural and mineral products. Traditional markets will remain steady for the foreseeable future but there are emerging signs of great potential in many other areas, particularly in the light of the reforms currently underway in Japan and the freeing up of many of the over‐regulated and highly protected markets. However, to be successful in these markets, an entirely different marketing strategy must be undertaken. Australian firms need to be in touch with end‐users and respond to their specific needs and tastes rather than simply develop a product and try to sell it into the Japanese market.

There are signs that the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation(AMLC) are developing this approach by targeting supermarkets directly to promote consumer awareness of Aussie beef. However, some members of the delegation are concerned about the level and focus of the AMLC's promotion and advertising since its recent change in ownership. This could have a significant impact on our export drive and therefore any reductions should not be based solely on short terms budgetary considerations. While beef tariffs remain high, at around 46% the main obstacle to increased exports of Aussie beef remains one of maintenance of quality and of a standard comparable to the highly expensive local beef.

Other successes are emerging in such areas as oysters, mangoes, tomatoes, capsicums, and further market successes are likely to be realised in such areas as apples, housing, furniture, processed foods, housing and construction, transport equipment, telecommunications, health services and sports medicine. Quality, not volume, will win the day, particularly if the product meets the very high health and safety standards demanded of the Japanese consumer.

Japan will remain one of our most important sources of tourists for the foreseeable future. It was pleasing to note that Japanese consumer satisfaction with our tourist facilities as a safe destination remains very high.

As I have already mentioned, food safety and food quality are key considerations for any successful long term contracts. Recent outbreaks of disease such as e‐coli, cotton trash and mad cow's disease have impacted not only in the country where the outbreak occurred, but have affected all exporters of similar products. Australia has a strong comparative advantage in agricultural production underpinned by a clean, natural resource base. Australia must continue to promote its position as a leading natural supplier of safe, high quality fresh and processed foods.

The process of administrative reform and deregulation is underway. While the pace of reform may not be as fast as many commentators would wish, the fact still remains that Australia stands to gain considerably as further reforms in many sectors will enhance opportunities for many Australian industries.

Prior to leaving Tokyo for visits to Kyoto and Osaka the delegation made a very moving and emotional visit to the Yokahama British Commonwealth War Cemetery to lay a wreath and pay its respects to the Australian Service Personnel who lost their lives in World War II. This is the only Commonwealth Cemetery in Japan, and provides a focal point for visitors to reflect on the ultimate sacrifice made by fellow countrymen and to contemplate the prospects of lasting peace and prosperity for people from both sides of the conflict.

In conclusion, Madam President, I believe the visit provided the delegation with a very good opportunity to explore many aspects of the relationship. While many other new relationships are being forged in the Asia‐Pacific Region by both Japan and Australia, none of them will diminish in any way, shape or form, the very strong and broad based relationship that has been built up between our two countries over the last 25 years. On the contrary, I believe, this relationship will continue to grow and be a major catalyst in the forging of other strong and lasting ties in the region. The delegation looks forward to further visits between both countries so as to strengthen the very close relationships and continue to pursue matters of mutual interest.
I commend the report to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing entitled Inquiry into the proposed amalgamation of the parliamentary departments together with submissions and proof transcript of proceedings.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This is obviously a matter that is of significance to all senators and members of the House of Representatives. Senators would recall that a proposal for amalgamation of parliamentary departments originally emanated from the discredited National Commission of Audit. After that report had been received by government, the Presiding Officers of both chambers of the Commonwealth parliament sought the views of the heads of parliamentary departments and there was a review of those contributions from Mr Noel Tanzer.

A working group was also established from amongst the parliamentary departments, and the two Presiding Officers, I think it is fair to say, Madam President, agreed eventually to a proposal for a two‐chamber department amalgamation model. This was made available and tabled in the House of Representatives and in the Senate with the report Managing the parliament—the way ahead. As is required in the standing orders of the Senate, this particular matter was required to be dealt with by the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing.

The appropriations and staffing committee conducted public inquiries and has spent a good deal of time examining the benefits and the disbenefits of the amalgamation proposal. I think it is fair to say that we were underwhelmed by the level of support for this proposal not only from within Parliament House and within the parliamentary departments but also more broadly from the community. I can recall only one vaguely suppor tive written submission that came to our committee and very little positive supporting evidence during the public hearings.

As far as the opposition is concerned—and in our own internal processes—this is not something about which we have come to a firm parliamentary party or caucus view. It is something that the members of the Appropriations and Staffing committee of the Senate and interested senators on the one hand and many of our colleagues in the House of Representatives on the other hand have had a close look at.

There are a range of views in the Labor opposition about possible approaches on this issue. What we have to say very clearly is that we do not come to the issue of amalgamation of the parliamentary departments from an oppositionist perspective. I am certainly not willing to rule out proposals for the amalgamation of the parliamentary departments per se. But what I would say is that the model that we have examined—the model that was subject to debate by the Appropriations and Staffing Committee and the model that has been presented in the report Managing the parliament—the way ahead—is not one that I can embrace. It is a model that has received virtually no support from within Parliament House or beyond.
On page 6 of the report the committee reports on the estimated savings from this two‐chamber proposal. The report says:

BREAK.PARA: It estimated that longer‐term savings from the elimination of duplication would be in the order of 40 to 50 staff, being 25% to 30% of the corporate services staff, which would generate savings in salaries of $2 million to $2.5 million. The Working Group suggested that these savings were not insignificant, but that further improvement of services to senators and members would be contingent upon efficiencies being realised in both the joint and separate operational areas of the amalgamated departments.

I really think that the parliament has to focus on the issue of whether the sort of upheaval that is envisaged in the one proposal—the two‐chamber department amalgamation proposal that is before the parliament—is warranted for this level of savings. The conclusion that I have come to and the committee has come to is simply that it is not.

The management model for the two‐department structure is very worrying. Effectively, it is a board comprising such eminent people as yourself, Madam President, the Clerk of the Senate, the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Speaker. I have always been concerned about how that board might work. There is always an opportunity in a four‐member board, as you know, Madam President, for the board to effectively split down the middle. You then have a situation where there are divisions between the Senate and the House of Representatives and yourself and the Senate Clerk lining up against the Speaker and the Clerk of the House or, alternatively, we could have a situation where the clerks line up against the presiding officers. I really think this model is just a recipe for inaction or non-action—a recipe for disaster.

I suspect that one of the problems with what we have before us is really the limited terms of reference that the Appropriations and Staffing Committee had. In other words, I do not think the model we had was a good model at all. Many of the witnesses that we had before us and many of the submissions that were before the committee were really able to effectively shoot holes in this. I think those who are genuinely concerned about proper administrative practice and management practice would have to be concerned about the nature of the proposal that was contained in the report Managing the parliament—the way ahead.

It is disappointing that the Appropriations and Staffing Committee's deliberations were limited to one inadequate model. The committee has recommended that the Senate not agree to the proposed amalgamation in that form. It has also asked the presiding officers to require parliamentary departments to identify where savings might be achieved and that the funding of new policy proposals from savings made by those departments actually be the subject of agreement between presiding officers.

We have been creative in suggesting that new policy proposals for the parliamentary departments be in the form of a joint submission from the presiding officers to the govern ment. I think that is a positive step forward. I hope that the government accepts these recommendations in the spirit in which they are intended.

For the small savings that can be achieved here, we will end up with great disruption and very little benefit from this proposal. If the amalgamation of parliamentary departments is to be further considered, let us hope that we have other proposals before us because I do not think anyone will write off the possibility of amalgamation of parliamentary departments. This proposal, as far as the committee is concerned and as far as I am concerned, is not the way ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry if I am interposing between a couple of other speakers, but I have another commitment very shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset that I am an unreconstructed amalgamationist. I have had the view for about 10 years that I thought four or five parliamentary departments on the scale of things was a ridiculous concept. I am always massively disappointed when I go into a committee hearing with those fixed views and have my prejudices overturned by compelling evidence. I have to admit that on this occasion that is simply what has happened.

We looked at a proposal for amalgamation of the parliamentary departments which had its genesis in the National Commission of Audit's report. The more we looked at it, the more we realised that the commission of audit had only scanned this particular issue and come to conclusions without any evidence or long-term thought.

The second thing that came up was that the way forward, the way ahead, was done genuinely and with good intentions by the group that put it together. But it is not an in‐depth document, and virtually every submission our committee received opposed amalgamation. So I had to think about this compelling evidence and, I must say, it convinced me on this occasion that this model is not the way ahead.

I should put on the record that this parliament, in the last four or five years, has contributed something like a 14 per cent savings regime back to the budget—the $10 million cut plus the efficiency dividends have meant something like a 14 per cent cut to the money available to the parliamentary departments. When you measure that against all other departments, it is not a bad effort. I would especially draw your attention to the savings that have been generated in these parliamentary departments with that of Treasury. Treasury does not cough up too much money. When resources need to be transferred to it, they always go at 100 per cent.

I also draw your attention to not a particularly brilliant line of questioning I did at estimates with the Department of Finance, which is outsourcing everything. When I put it to that department, `You have out sourced everything, why don't you merge with Treasury?' there was absolute shock and horror, `Oh, no, we could not do that, Senator, that is not on.'

So just arguing that amalgamation or big is better must be sustained by the facts. I know how much this report is going to be demonised by the Department of Finance and by some people in the House of Representatives. By refusing the amalgamation of parliamentary departments, we are going to be called recalcitrants—people looking after only our own self-interests, people who are not concerned with reform. But that is a most unfair characterisation.

The proposition is that if you amalgamate all the corporate services and go to a two departmental structure you will generate savings. But the savings are not calculated. The guesstimate is, at the very top, that you will save $2.5 million. But you will not save that in the next outyear or the outyear afterwards. Probably in three to four years time you will reach the $2 million to $2½ million savings. In the meantime, there will be much more money going out because of redundancies—and it takes a while to recover that.

What the government is saying is that for a one to 1½ per cent saving to the parliamentary budget it is going to turn this place over—it is going to start turf warfare amongst the people to see who will survive the musical chairs; it will have redundancies. This will take place against an atmosphere where, at the same time, we will be putting in workplace agreements, service level agreements and where there will be a divorce of all the employees in this building from the Public Service Act, which is proposed by the government.

So there will be a very destabilised period over the next three to four years for what really constitutes minor savings. None of us scoff at savings. None of us is so arrogant to say, `Even an extra million dollars worth of savings is not worth while.' But the fact is that there are alternative savings methods that will cause far less disruption than the amalgamation proposal. It has been pointed out in evidence that things such as joint procurement and the joint use of a variety of different facilities around the building in specialised areas will generate savings which can be used to offset other costs around the building.

But it does not matter whether you amalgamate the parliamentary departments and make savings or not, this building is going to run at a deficit for the next decade. We have an intrinsic problem here that there is no provision for proper asset replacement. In other words, the total global budget of this building can be moved around to make up various deficits as they occur. But there are not sufficient prospective savings, either by the method this committee recommends or by way of parliamentary amalgamations, that will fund the asset replacement to keep this building going. The security equipment, the phone system and the sound and vision system all require more money than any of the potential savings options available will provide.Even if we got to that stage and said, `Amalgamation is a possibility just on the basis of economic efficiency,' we then have to take the next step and say, `How does the place run on a two department structure?'

The proposal to set up a board of four to run the place is wrong in principle. I do not believe that the presiding officers should have to share their power responsibilities with non-elected clerks of the building. I do not think the clerks in this building would particularly aspire to that role either—they are the appointed employees, equivalent, I suppose, to a department secretary, to do administrative tasks and not to rule or make decisions on policy matters. As Senator Faulkner said, all sorts of divisions could appear.

We know at the moment that the President and the Speaker have a very harmonious relationship. For most times in the past that has been true, but not all times. If we set up this sort of structure in the future and we suddenly get personality clashes between the Speaker and the President, how would this structure work? For the first time ever we would have people from the Department of the House of Representative—staff, the Speaker—determining the resources for the Senate, and vice versa. That could cause a lot of pain.

In the actual division of the two other departments into the House of Representatives and the Senate, the Senate would inherit all the sick children. The Senate would inherit all those particular groups that would require a lot of money in future. There is no particular goodwill from that point of view. We might think, at first view, that the request is not bad, but in the end I think you will find it is a fairly poor deal.

The report does recommend some changes. It goes to the issue of having the four parliamentary departments put in a joint submission to the ERC. That will have the benefit of looking at the total expenditure of all four departments—or five if you insist that, but it is really four—and being able to shift money between one or the other, which happened this financial year. The Joint House Department was able to move money across to the Senate and House of Representatives to fill in the shortfall. Some time in the future it may be the other way round—some money from the Senate or House of Representatives departments may move across to the Joint House Department.

I again say that I think this report has great potential to be demonised and misunderstood. It is one of those genuine reports where a lot of people went in with pre‐existing prejudices and came out the other end with a different view. That view was based on the facts and the knowledge of the way this building works.

I say in conclusion that this cannot have been an easy report for you, Madam Presi dent, to have presided over, because of the dual roles that you play. I should put on the record that you adopted the very appropriate method of not having a chairman's draft but of having a draft by the secretary of the committee come to the whole committee. I think that was a most appropriate administrative way of handling it. I hope that in future people from executive government are not critical of you over this report.

I think it is fair to say that it was virtually the unanimous view of the committee, with some degrees of enthusiasm or otherwise, to come to these conclusions. I repeat: this report is not a case of senators going away and looking after their self-interest; it basically says that, the amount of savings involved here being very minor, it is not worth turning this place over just for the sake of change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —As the fifth speaker in this debate, I stand as the mover of the motion which asked the Senate to look into the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing entitled Managing the parliament—the way ahead . I am extremely grateful that the Senate, by a small majority, I have to say, agreed to look into this at the end of last session.

SPEECH.PARA: It was extremely important that there be a process by which the proposal was not only reviewed but reviewed in a way that enabled people to give submissions freely and openly on a very important issue under the protection of parliamentary privilege. The reason it is important, as has been alluded to by other speakers, is that it is not just about meeting the needs of parliamentarians; what this process is doing is enabling parliamentarians to work in a way that is appropriate to the needs of democracy. Democracy, in many ways, is a very fragile thing.

The ability to gain independent and professional advice is extremely important in a democracy. The ability to ensure the independence of advice and that each chamber of the parliament is not controlled by the other is extremely important and should never be underestimated.

The ability to operate departments without necessarily being forced to have operatives, for instance, departments, coming in on secondment is extremely important in the separation of powers. This could well happen if you have one chamber in charge of another chamber's outcome. The independence of the Parliamentary Library should never be underestimated. It has certainly been indicated that the savings may be illusory, if anything. It has never been my opinion that, if you have several bureaucracies and you amalgamate them, you are necessarily going to get a more efficient bureaucracy.

Unless it is conceded that one part of the bureaucracy is non‐functional or not necessary, the larger the bureaucracy, in my opinion, the less functional it becomes, the less able it is to meet the needs. It seems to me that outcomes sometimes get forgotten when we look for so-called efficiencies, which generally translate to job cuts.

A great deal of change has occurred over the last 18 months and the changes often occurred at the expense of jobs. So far, $14 million worth of savings have been achieved in the last 18 months by a great many changes. If there are ways of using existing resources to achieve the same or better outcomes and to use those resources more effectively, the primary motive of change should be just that. It should not be change for the sake of change, and certainly not change that may well mean that our precious and fragile democracy within the parliamentary system is threatened.

BREAK.PARA: We know that there are already differences between the way the House of Representatives and the Senate operates. We know that is because, as has always been the case, there is a majority within the government and the government gets its way. We know that the government ministers can direct committees as to what inquiries they take. We know that, in effect, it is possible for ministers to veto certain inquiries taking place. We know that departmental operatives can be seconded to committees and those departmental operatives are under the control, effectively, of the minister. We know that we do have a chance within the Senate to try to maintain that very precious separation of powers.

It is often forgotten within this place that within our constitution, within our tradition, `separation of powers' means that the executive, the parliament and the judiciary should be separate. This is not always the case, or it is not always clear within the House of Representatives, but it is extremely important that the threats are recognised and, once recognised, are guarded against.

That is why I believe it was very important to gain the opinions of a range of people and to put this report together. I would like to say that I commend those people responsible for this report for putting it together. I certainly hope that the government takes this fully into consideration before considering any amalgamation which may threaten our precious democracy.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Capital and External Territories Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories entitled A right to protest , together with transcripts of evidence and submissions to the inquiry. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
The purpose of this inquiry was to review the arrangements which apply when people wish to protest at Parliament House and other areas of national land.
That includes The Lodge, the Australian War Memorial, Canberra Airport, the embassy area, Commonwealth offices and defence facilities.
It would seem the title of the report, `A Right To Protest' begs a united chorus of "yes of course we have a right to protest."
That's because in Australia we have forever expected to have the right to protest.
So strong is our democratic tradition.
But in fact, as the Committee inquiry reveals, we cannot and should not take this right for granted.
So fragile is that right, so easily can it be lost.
It can be lost for example by only a few stirrers taking over a demonstration and causing property damage or provoking the authorities into a reaction.
This is when a protest becomes a riot.
Therefore perhaps the most important finding of the inquiry was society must not take for granted the right to protest.
Just as the price of freedom is `eternal vigilance', the same can be said about the right to protest.
After all that is the ultimate freedom.
Look at the ends of the scale.
At one end we have the Tiananmen Square experience, where the glimpse of a right to protest was squashed under a tank.
At the other end of the scale is Australia, a vigorous democracy which unequivocally allows our people the right to protest.
Though at times the bounds of our tolerance have been sorely tested.
I give the example relating to the demonstration last August which degenerated into the storming of Parliament.
That riot led to smashed doors, a plundered gift shop and, worse, a cowardly and vicious attack upon a police woman.
But what is little known about that day is the great tolerance shown by authorities in the heat of the moment.
In the basement awaiting the order to defend Parliament House was a tactical response force in full gear (shields & batons).
Even in the worst moments of the riot their commanding officer did not deploy them against the demonstrators.
They were only used to defend the building.
The reason was a good one because the possibilities of the riot turning even uglier would have been real.
Yet think of what the response of some other countries may have been to an equivalent danger.
We see them on the nightly news. . . ..
Countries so used to demonstrations turning ugly.
It would be no exaggeration to say, with a click of the fingers they would send in the riot police with shields and batons, water hoses, and even tear gas, if their Parliament was so threatened.
I venture to say its only because Australia has built a culture of a right to protest that the extreme was not used to retaliate against the mob out of control.
This culture is what we seek to preserve in our report.
This Committee chose not to over‐react.
We have adopted a minimalist approach to ensure that the right to protest is not diminished here in Canberra.

While some people proposed a more structured approach to dealing with public demonstrations, through permits or a formal notification system, the Committee considers that such options would be overly complex and unnecessarily restrictive.
Instead, we have put our faith in the Australian people that they will exercise their right to protest in an orderly and peaceful manner and will shun the violence we witnessed last year.
The clear message we received from many contributors to the inquiry was that Australians do not want or need a system which unnecessarily increases the controls or limits on their right to protest.
The Committee agrees.

Our recommendations focus on encouraging cooperation between protesters and relevant authorities to ensure the proper planning and conduct of public demonstrations at Parliament House and on other parts of national land.
Nevertheless, in adopting this minimalist approach, the Committee agreed that there is a need to tidy up some of the rules which apply to protest structures.
During the inquiry, we heard about many problems which have arisen when people have sought to erect structures in support of their protest.
The structures have included tents, sheds and even a Trojan Horse.

It is important to recognise that there already is a requirement for people to seek approval before they can erect a structure on national land, but the law is unclear and open to testing in the courts.
As acknowledged by the Committee, unclear law does not make for good law.
To make it fair for all, and to ensure public safety, the Committee has recommended the introduction of a permit system for protest structures on national land.
This is not an attempt to restrict protesters who want to use structures as part of their protest.
The system we have proposed clarifies and simplifies the process by which protest structures can be authorised.
Other Committee recommendations include:
identifying a contact officer in the Australian Federal Police to coordinate protests on national land and to liaise with protesters and other relevant authorities on the arrangements for protests;
producing a public information booklet with advice about protesting on national land;
repealing outdated and unnecessary legislation limiting protests; and
revising existing laws applying to protests to ensure that they are written in plain English and outline clearly the powers available to relevant authorities.

I finish by saying that while what we may classify as bad demonstrations are few and far between, it is through these bad experiences that the absolute and cherished right to protest may well be etched away.
So it is incumbent on all demonstrators to keep this in mind when taking up the banner and marching.
The Committee is very grateful for the work and support provided by its secretariat.
I commend the report to the Parliament.
Debate (on motion by Senator Margetts) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Abetz, I present the report of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on the role and function of the Administrative Review Council, together with submissions and Hansard record of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
I am pleased to present this unanimous report of the Committee into the optimal role and function of the Administrative Review Council.

The ARC's main role is to provide advice to government on administrative decision‐making and review. It does this by letters of advice, reports based on research projects, comments on Cabinet submissions, and providing departments and agencies with advice on the administrative review aspects of initiatives they are undertaking.

The Committee found that it is difficult to identify objective criteria against which to assess the effectiveness of the Administrative Review Council. Nonetheless, the evidence received by the Committee supports the view that the Administrative Review Council has been an effective body, providing useful and timely advice on administrative review matters. The Committee did, however, receive some suggestions that the ARC could give greater attention to identifying the costs entailed in adopting its advice and recommendations.

As our report notes, with one exception all the submissions we received basically supported retaining the ARC in something like its present role and shape. The one exception was a submission from Mr Anthony Morris QC, which argued that the ARC had largely fulfilled the functions for which it was established over 20 years ago, and that it should now be abolished.

The report recommends that the ARC should remain as a separate and permanent body, provided that it is making a significant contribution towards an affordable and cost‐effective system of administrative decision‐making and review.
The remainder of the eleven recommendations in the report relate to matters of detail.

Several concern the membership structure of the ARC. For example, the report recommends that in selecting persons for appointment, the Government should continue to have regard to the need for the ARC membership to contain a broad spectrum of qualifications and to represent a variety of interests. It also recommends that the qualifications required for membership of the ARC be broadened to enable the appointment of persons with direct knowledge and experience of the needs of groups or individuals significantly affected by government decisions.
The report further recommends that the legislation be amended to enable persons to be appointed as Council members for the purpose of a particular project.

However, the Committee does not endorse the suggestions it received that the Act should be amended to require the appointment of a person having any specific qualification or representing any specific interest.
Other recommendations relate to:
clarifying the definition of the ARC's functions in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975;
setting out the power of the Attorney‐General to issue directions and refer matters to the ARC; and

formalising in the legislation the present informal practices under which the ARC's project reports are provided to the Attorney‐General, are tabled in the Parliament, and are responded to by government.
Madam President, I would like to conclude by making some personal comments about the appropriateness of inquiries similar to the one that is the subject of this report.

At the time the inquiry was instituted, the ARC had been in existence for twenty years and had not previously been subject to any review. The request for the Committee's inquiry came from the Attorney, who was quite properly concerned to have the ARC's continuing relevance and effectiveness examined.

However, with the benefit of hindsight I believe that assessment of the optimal role and effectiveness of bodies like the ARC is probably better done by management consultants. The ARC has not been the subject of controversy or widespread criticism in the community. As a result, our inquiry did not benefit from receiving the broad range of competing views and arguments I believe is essential to provide the foundation for well‐grounded and well‐considered committee reports. In the absence of the sort of controversy that ensures a committee receives a range of competing views, the investigatory techniques available to management consultants are better suited to evaluating bodies like the ARC than the process of submissions and public hearings that committees use.

AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION SALE BILL 1997
General

Australian National's (AN) operations, in common with many other Government owned railways, are characterised by a large and increasing debt and a declining market share. The performance of rail stands in stark contrast to the road transport sector which has been very successful in addressing customer needs and therefore increasing its market share.

To a large extent this situation reflects the fundamental problems arising from Government owning and operating businesses that are more efficiently conducted by the private sector. In particular, Government rail authorities have in many cases over the years, largely operated as monopolies, have often been subject to political interference and have not been placed on a fully commercial footing. Under these circumstances, pricing, operating and investment practices tend to be unresponsive and inflexible. If real reform is to be achieved in the rail sector it is vitally important that the inherent deficiencies associat ed with Government ownership be replaced by a dynamic market driven approach.

The problems confronting AN, however, have been substantially magnified by the establishment of the National Rail Corporation (NR). In particular, AN has been left with very large debts while the large bulk of its profitable operations have been transferred to NR. Furthermore, AN has been required to provide NR with significant services at well below cost.

The Government became aware of the extent of AN's problems shortly after taking office. I commissioned the independent Brew review, which revealed a situation requiring urgent remedy. Increasing debt, a loss of business, and escalating taxpayer subsidies were aspects of AN which the former Government both ignored and failed to address.
I want to make it clear that the financial mess at AN was not the result of AN staff or management, but the result of decisions made by the former Government which left AN in an impossible position.

As a result, I announced on 24 November last year a $2 billion reform package to rejuvenate the rail sector. The reforms will impact through the separation of the management of the interstate rail track network from above track operations.

The major benefit of structural separation lies in replacing the incentives for anticompetitive and uncommercial behaviour with an incentive to maximise the number of operators on the network. The Commonwealth's role will concentrate on controlling and managing economically-efficient and non-discriminatory access to the interstate rail network. This will allow the interstate rail network to operate largely as the roads do now: Government-owned, but open, upon payment of an access fee, to anyone licensed to operate a vehicle over the network. Such a change can only be of benefit to the users of rail transport and indeed to the economy as a whole.

This Bill is the first legislative step in achieving this important component of microeconomic reform. The injection of private sector expertise into rail operations will reduce costs, improve service responsiveness and increase rail market share.
The Proposed Bill

The Australian National Railways Commission Sale Bill 1997 gives effect to the Government's decision to sell the non-interstate mainline track rail assets of Australian National (AN) in whole or in part. It provides a flexible framework to facilitate:
. authority and mechanisms for the sale, including authority to repeal, replace or amend rail agreements with South Australia and Tasmania following their agreement to sale arrangements; and

. reduction of AN to an entity charged with dealing with any residual functions and the balance of assets and liabilities not included above, or not able to be disposed of in the short term, and resolving outstanding litigation and disputes prior to abolition.
A viable rail industry

AN has been offered for sale as a single unit or by component parts such as interstate passenger operations, vertically-integrated rail freight operations in South Australia and Tasmania or railway workshops.

AN's rail operations have been restricted in their operation by corporate overheads and the burden of debt. Recognising that this arrangement is not sustainable, the Government has decided to offer AN for sale free of debts and liabilities.

It is proposed that companies be established under the Corporation Law to be the vehicles through which the sales occur. The assets of AN necessary for the operation of each component of the AN business will be transferred into a company by Ministerial direction listing the assets, or classes of assets. The shares in the company will be sold to a new rail operator. The liabilities of AN would be retained and paid out by AN or transferred to the Commonwealth.
Thus the Bill proposes flexible arrangements for the transfer of assets, liabilities and contracts between AN, the Commonwealth and a new rail operator.

To provide maximum flexibility to a purchaser, it is not proposed that any staff transfer to private sector purchasers. Instead it is proposed that staff be made redundant on sale or closure of the part of AN in which they work.
There will be no requirements or arrangements in the sales process for the transfer or re-employment of employees and general industrial relations legislation will determine award provisions.
The new operator will not be burdened by existing liabilities or inappropriate staffing structures and can develop arrangements consistent with a viable transport company.
Incentives to improve infrastructure

The States have interests in a large proportion of AN-owned land under the 1975 agreements which transferred railway assets to the Commonwealth. It is proposed that the land revert to the States for them to lease to a new rail operator.

It is important that the sale arrangement create an incentive for an injection of funds to improve and maintain the rail infrastructure. Ownership of infrastructure is considered a key part of providing this incentive.

To achieve an infrastructure ownership arrangement under land lease, the Bill proposes that railway land fixtures such as track, signalling equipment, culverts, buildings etc be severed from the land by the sales legislation for sale to the new operator with above track assets.
Agreements with the States

The Commonwealth has legislated a range of agreements with the States over the years. Some of these need to be amended or repealed to allow the sale to proceed. The Government is negotiating with South Australia and Tasmania on these issues and is confident of reaching agreement.

The shares in each new company established to operate a business previously within AN will become part of a sales agreement between the Commonwealth and a private sector purchaser. The Bill proposes that the Minister for Finance be authorised to sign an agreement with the purchasers of these new companies..

It is envisaged that these sales agreements will be a key mechanism by which Commonwealth commitments under the agreements with the States will be honoured. Sales negotiations with prospective purchasers cannot be finalised until the Parliament agrees to the sale and new agreements have been reached with South Australia and Tasmania.
The Bill thus proposes that:
. I be empowered to enter into new agreements with the States;
. those agreements be given legislative force through regulation able to be disallowed by either house of Parliament;
. the various Acts authorising current agreements with the States be repealed on the day on which new agreements take effect; and
. any agreement executed in this way be approved and its performance and observance by the Commonwealth be authorised.
AN financial obligations

The Bill proposes a range of provisions which are intended to both protect the Commonwealth from default by AN as a result of the loss of assets and revenue generating capacity and provide for the Commonwealth to take over and meet obligations of the Commission in order to protect companies which have contracted to AN in good faith.
These proposed provisions include the expansion of Commonwealth guarantee powers and provisions to enable the Commonwealth to discharge AN obligations from funds appropriated for this purpose.
Amendments to the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983

AN is established and operated under the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983. The Bill proposes a range of amendments to the Act to enable the Commission to assist the Commonwealth in implementing its rail reform objectives in relation to the Commission. It also provides a power of direction which enables the Minister for Finance to direct AN in the disposal of its assets and liabilities.

Through the sale process, AN will shed all its rail operations other than the ownership and management of interstate track. The Bill proposes transitional arrangements, including allowing flexibility to reduce the structure and size of the Commission as the business contracts and providing the means to transfer residual assets, liabilities and contracts to the Commonwealth and abolish the Commission when it has wound down sufficiently..
The Bill also proposes the amendment of a range of existing legislation to facilitate the sale and in consequence of the abolition of AN.
Conclusion

The future of rail in Australia lies with using our current system much more efficiently and effectively, through encouraging the participation of the private sector, introducing competition and providing a greater customer focus.

It is possible for the rail industry to operate profitably, and this will require substantial programs of cost reduction and capital investment by the private sector, accompanied by improvements in service quality.
It is these initiatives that will give us a viable long-term rail industry in Australia.

The legislation underpins the Government's rail reform package and is essential to its implementation. The reform package has a number of elements but, in particular, seeks to revitalise rail transport by separating the provision of access to essential infrastructure (the interstate track) from the provision of rail transport services, which is more appropriately the role of the private sector.

Passage of the legislation is crucial to the attainment of the Government's timetable for the sale as it will enable the Government to sell AN assets and services, clearly signalling the Government's commitment to reform. It will also directly increase participation of the private sector in the rail industry.

AN is losing money and is in an unsustainable and declining financial position which is unlikely to be improved in the current environment of uncertainty. The extensive restructure required to generate an efficient and profitable rail system is best able to be achieved through government divestment and the injection of private sector transport expertise. This is also the best long-term guarantee of employment in the rail industry.
Prompt passage of the Bill will mean that elements of AN can rapidly be divested and will thereby reduce uncertainty for AN, its staff, other participants in the rail industry and the community.
Delays in sale will unnecessarily increase taxpayer liabilities and adversely effect the Government's budget strategy.
WOOL INTERNATIONAL AMENDMENT BILL 1997

Madam President, this bill represents the culmination of a process aimed at providing the Australian wool industry with a clear direction for the future. It is the final stage in preparing the industry to stand on its own feet, unencumbered by unnecessary government regulation and direction. It heralds the end of an era in Australian wool, an era that has been marked by significant debate and controversy.

Last year, this Parliament passed a bill providing for the final stage in the disposal of the wool stockpile which was created during the last years of the reserve price scheme. The bill I now present establishes the wind-up procedures for Wool International, through liquidation, and the distribution of equity to wool tax payers in Wool International.

Above all, Madam President, this bill represents the success of the consultation process established in the early months of the life of this government which has had the ultimate aim of developing, with industry, a clear future direction for Australian wool, including finalisation of the sale of the wool stockpile, retirement of the associated debt and deregulation of the industry. Further more, the government will provide for the distribution to wool tax payers of equity in Wool International, providing wool growers with much needed, and deserved, entitlements to profits from the sale of the wool stockpile and associated assets. The granting of entitlements to wool tax payers will also provide a more secure basis for those wool growers in most need to either sell, or borrow against, their entitlements.

Madam President, a further, related, development in the wool industry has been the emergence of the proposed wool marketing joint venture, `Global Wool'. This proposal will only be developed, on a commercial basis, with the concurrence of the australian competition and consumer commission and the government. I emphasise that the government has no direct role to play in `Global Wool'. If the venture proceeds, Wool International's only proposed involvement would be by way of establishing the vehicle for wool grower investment.

This bill provides a package of measures which will see wool growers given entitlements in Wool International; the development of a loan facility which will allow growers to better use their entitlements as security for loans; provide for the liquidation of Wool International; enable interim and final payments of Wool International assets to wool-tax payers; and offer a mechanism to allow growers to invest their equity return in a growers' investment trust, which might participate in the proposed `Global Wool' wool marketing joint venture. It will also introduce the corresponding changes to the objects and functions of Wool International and reduce the size of the Wool International board.

Madam President, the first and most fundamental of the amendments is that of giving wool tax payers entitlements in Wool International. When Wool International was established in 1993, it was intended to corporatise and then privatise the organisation by 1 July 1997. Although the act never provided for this to occur, this government has made a commitment to provide growers who paid the debt component of the wool tax from 1 July 1993 to 30 June 1996 (including voluntary contributions) with an entitlement to equity in Wool International.

All wool tax paid up to 30 June 1996, including voluntary contributions, is to be converted to units. Wool tax payers are to be issued a statement of unit holding on the basis of a unit for every dollar of wool tax paid. Depending on the net assets of Wool International, each unit would then have an implied value which can be used as a basis for trading units.

This will give wool growers not only a right to the equity of Wool International, which has been an intention of the act since 1993, but will provide growers with the ability to trade their units. Similarly, wool tax payers will be able to offer their entitlements in Wool International as additional security when taking out a loan with a financial institution.

Wool International will maintain the wool tax register to record changes in ownership in future equity and, in the case of a loan over the units, the register will record the financial institution's interest in the units.

Madam President, Wool International will issue wool tax payers with a consolidated wool tax record in early June this year. Wool tax payers will be required to respond as to the completeness and correctness of this wool tax record by 1 August this year. I cannot overemphasise to wool tax payers the importance of a prompt response to ensure they gain their correct entitlement to Wool International equity. When finalised, this register will be the basis for entitlements and equity distributions.
Further, Madam President, the legislation will allow Wool

International to arrange, through a public tender process, a loan facility with a financial institution for the benefit of wool growers who hold entitlement to equity in Wool International. It is expected that this arrangement will produce more advantageous terms than would otherwise be available to borrowers negotiating individually. In performing this function, Wool International will be required to complete the tender process by 31 December 1997.

Madam President, having provided wool tax payers with rights in Wool International, the scene is set to enable the liquidation of Wool International and in the meantime, to make interim cash payments to wool tax payers of Wool International equity.

The liquidation of Wool International will take place by removing reference to the privatisation of Wool International currently set out in section 3(3) and parts 10 to 12 of the act. Further, it is necessary to provide in the act for the final wind-up arrangements of Wool International. These include the provision for left-over funds, treatment of small holdings, the final annual report and ensure provision for the wind-up costs of Wool International. It will also provide for a scheme for the distribution of entitlements to the beneficiaries of deceased wool taxpayers and insolvent businesses.

Madam President, interim and final payments to wool-tax payers of equity in Wool International is another major aspect of these amendments. Wool-tax payers will receive their interim payment as a cash entitlement. The payout to wool-tax payers of funds held under section 51 will not delay the retirement of the debt associated with the stockpile.

The act will provide for wool-tax payers to have the option to invest their initial payment, from the first Wool International payout, in a growers investment vehicle which may subsequently invest in a wool logistics and merchanting venture, commonly referred to as `global wool'. But the act will not involve Wool International other than to facilitate investment in the proposed growers trust by those growers who elect to do so.

Madam President, the act will require Wool International to receive my approval to establish the growers' investment trust. Wool International will be allowed to support preliminary steps in the establishment of the proposed trust, and will also be able to undertake, in a limited way, feasibility studies and related activities for possible investment targets for the trust, including the global wool joint venture proposal. As I have indicated previously, global wool will not proceed without clearance by the Australian competition and consumer commission.

A final distribution will take place after the stockpile has been sold, and will signal the liquidation of Wool International. It is intended that the stockpile funds after sale and disposal of the stockpile will be the last of the Wool International assets available to wool-tax payers.

Madam President, these amendments clearly signal the government's withdrawal from the wool market. Wool International will also be required to reduce its activities to the core functions of disposing of the stockpile and retiring the associated debt. This will result in the phasing out of the subsidiary functions of Wool International and the corresponding reduction in the size of the board.

The provision of services to the Australian wool industry, the development of a viable international wool futures market and the development of mechanisms for the sale of wool to allow more efficient management of risk, will be phased out as functions of Wool International.

It is, however, necessary to provide for the winding up of several current Wool International functions not associated with selling the stockpile and retiring the associated debt. These are to ensure that Wool International can continue the education program on forward marketing and a market reporting service on a commercial basis. It would be disadvantageous to the industry to remove these functions at this stage and under the legislation these functions will cease by 30 June 1998.

Provision has been made to give Wool International the role of establishing the growers trust an investment vehicle as I mentioned previously. An end date of 30 June 1998 has been included to ensure Wool International's function in this area is short term and on the basis of a simple facilitation of investment by wool-tax payers.

Under the legislation, madam president, Wool International will be able to spend up to $1 million dollars on the establishment of the investment vehicle and in contributions to the development of the global wool proposal.

With the functions reduced to only core activities, it is appropriate for the board to be reduced in size. In keeping with the phasing out of subsidiary functions, this is to occur gradually, with the board being reduced from its present number of 11 to 5 by 1 January 1998 as the workload associated with liquidating the organisation declines. I would take this opportunity to thank the retiring board members for their valuable contributions during their service on the board. The composition of the new board will be announced in due course.

Madam President, as I stated at the outset, these amendments signal the beginning of the final stage of governnent's involvement in the wool industry. It will of course still collect wool tax on behalf of the industry, contribute to r&d, and continue negotiations with customers on trade access issues. From this point forward the industry will have a clear view of the future and can plan a new, prosperous and independent environment.
I commend the bill to honourable senators.
INTERNATIONAL MONETARY AGREEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL 1997

Madam President, the bill amends the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947 to allow Australia to adhere to the International Monetary Fund's New Arrangements to Borrow and to simplify the framework for conducting and recording Australia's other financial transactions with the IMF.

The New Arrangements to Borrow (NAB) were developed following the financial crisis in Mexico in late 1994. The Mexican crisis prompted concerns about the adequacy of the IMF's resources in the event of possible future crises affecting the international monetary system, in view of the growing size and integration of international financial markets. The NAB will double the IMF's capacity to borrow to forestall or cope with an impairment of the international monetary system or to deal with an exceptional situation that poses a threat to the stability of that system.

Honourable senators will be aware that Australia played a key role in the development of the NAB a role with which we can be justly proud. The establishment of the NAB as the IMF's principal borrowing facility will be a milestone for the institution and the international monetary system. Importantly, it will enhance the IMF's ability to safeguard the international monetary system.

The NAB is open to all IMF members that have the capacity, and are willing, to support the international monetary system and participants will have equal rights and responsibilities. These two features will do much to ensure that the NAB will be a central element in the management of the international financial system into the next century. The wider participation of member countries in the NAB appropriately reflects the changing structure of the world economy.

Under the NAB, the IMF will be able to borrow up to SDR34 billion (or about $A61 billion) from the NAB participants. Australians share of these credit arrangements is SDR810 million (or about $A1.5 billion). In the event of a call, Australia would lend directly to the IMF and would receive a claim against the Fund. The bill provides that any loan to the IMF will be paid out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Under the NAB, there is scope for Australia to opt out of calls if the government determines that we will not be able to meet them because of our present and prospective balance of payments and reserve position. We may also, on the basis of a balance of payments need, require early repayment of part or all of any loan we have made to the IMF.

Madam President, Australia undertakes a number of regular financial transactions with the IMF. These include the receipt of interest on Special Drawing Right holdings, interest payments on the use of Special Drawing Rights, quota payments and remuneration received for the use of Australian dollars by the IMF. The bill introduces a simplified framework for the conduct and recording of these transactions. Under the existing arrangements, some of Australia's financial transactions with the IMF are conducted by the transfer of Special Drawing Rights between the Commonwealth and the Reserve Bank and corresponding changes in the Bank's retransfer liability to the Commonwealth. Under the new framework, the Commonwealth would purchase and sell all the SDRs required to undertake these transactions with the Fund. This will provide for a more transparent and cost efficient framework for such transactions.

It is desirable that these changes be introduced at the same time as Australia takes up its membership of the New Arrangements to Borrow to ensure that all of these transactions are conducted in a consistent framework.

Madam President, the amendments proposed in the bill will have no impact on the Commonwealth Budget. The changes proposed to the conduct of Australia's financial transactions with the Fund affect transactions which are, by accepted international standards, classified as financing transactions. Any loan by the Commonwealth to the IMF under the NAB would also be classified as a financing transaction because loans to the IMF represent monetary assets.

The participants in the NAB have agreed that they will meet once a year, in addition to any meetings needed for activation, renewal or amendment of the NAB. The objective of these meetings is to review and discuss macroeconomic and financial market developments, especially those that could have an impact on the stability of the international financial system and lead to a possible need for the Fund to seek supplementary resources. This is potentially an important new forum for consideration of these issues. The chairmanship of the NAB will rotate between participants and Australia is expected to provide the first chairman.
Madam President, I commend the bill to the Senate.
