SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Because this is the same wording as motion No. 4 in the name of Senator Bolkus, on behalf of Senator Bolkus and myself I seek leave to move notices of motions Nos 3 and 4 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the High Court of Australia (Fees) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 106 and made under the Judiciary Act 1903, be disallowed.
(2) That the High Court of Australia (Fees) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 106 and made under the Judiciary Act 1903, be disallowed.

This disallowance motion is an important issue in relation to the much talked about question of access to justice. This government is obsessed with the concept of cost recovery, and the fee increases we are attempting to disallow today are part of the ongoing process of charging the public for access to what were previously considered public or community services.

I thought that the provision of an accessible justice system was part of an open and democratic society. Taxpayers expect to receive fundamental services such as a court system in return for paying their annual tax return. If the revenue from taxation is not sufficient to pay for those services then we should be examining ways in which to increase that revenue, not charging people for services such as courts on a user‐pays basis. The consequences of moving to a user‐pays system is that the most vulnerable in our society who may need access to the courts and other aspects of the justice system cannot pay and are denied access to justice. That is clearly unacceptable.

BREAK.PARA: Whilst the Attorney‐General's office have briefed me on this issue and have pointed to the procedures for a waiver of the fees on the grounds of hardship, the problem with such a system is that many people in a situation of hardship are not aware of such schemes. Of course, with a decline of legal aid funding, they will increasingly find it difficult to get advice from lawyers who can advise them of such options. It is a vicious circle.

The reality is that many of the fees contained in these regulations have increased by up to five times the amount. The fee for a special leave application to the High Court, for example, has increased from $2,000 to $10,000. The daily hearing fee has increased from $1,500 to $12,000. Whilst it is acknowledged that wealthy corporations will also be required to pay these increases, with a doubling in many cases of the basic fees, the reality is that such increases work in favour of the corporations that can play the game of pursuing legal avenues all the way to the High Court without any relatively great financial hardship. What is $12,000 or even $20,000 to a multibillion dollar company? The general community, however, who are going to be increasingly left to themselves to pursue action against these corporations, will find it difficult to match such funding and, consequently, will have their access to justice severely limited.

You have to look at what is happening here in conjunction with the other changes that this government is imposing: changes to legal aid, to areas such as the Environmental Defender's Office—for having the audacity to try to defend the environment—changes through the community to try to shut people up, a discovery that certain laws should not be defended, that it is okay for governments to break certain of their own laws. Just imagine the outcry if this was a tax law or a corporations law. But about other laws, where the community at large is concerned, the government is saying, `Shut up, we don't want to know.'

This is not good enough, and it is not good enough that we are turning into a society that is trying to control people's thoughts and stop them from standing up and speaking for themselves or, more importantly, for justice—speaking up for what is right and requiring, heaven forbid, that the government obey its own laws. That is extremely important. It is so important that we must, today, stand up and fight against this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing is more critical to a cohesive society than access to justice. The measure we are discussing today goes very much to the heart of that. It is about rights being of value, it is about accessing rights. On this side of parliament, we believe that we should not have the impediment of user pays in the way of people accessing their rights. When some people can and some people cannot access their rights, and that distinction is based on the capacity of someone to pay, you have a very much divided society.

SPEECH.PARA: This view was best stated by the Chief Justice of Australia in a High Court case on the matter of citizen limbo in a 1989 judgment. I think it is worth putting this quote on record. He said:

Where a person has a legal right to enforce or a legal defence to offer to another's claim, the imposition of substantial fees restricting access to the courts of law may place that person, unless he be affluent, outside the law's protection. In a society governed by the law, no barrier can be erected against reasonable access to the courts for the vindication and protection of legal rights. To ensure that litigation is not frivolously commenced, modest fees have traditionally been exacted but the courts have reserved a dispensing discretion to ensure that, where litigation can be seen to be justifiable, poverty is no bar to the operation of law.

The principle of access to justice is one that is critical to our society. It underpinned the previous Labor government's justice statement. It also was reflected, before the election, by statements from the coalition.

What we are talking about here is access to the highest court in the country, a court which has the role of clarifying the law and the constitution, putting detail on legislation that is passed by parliament and developing the common law. As such, its role is very much complementary to the role of parliament. It has a special role.

We have to remember in respect of this role that only a very few cases get to the High Court. Some 13 years ago the proviso was that any litigant who was dissatisfied with a state or federal appeal court could go to the High Court if the matter was worth more than $20,000. That was replaced by the system we now have, a system where matters of important legal issue of criminal, constitutional and civil law can be heard by the High Court only by special leave of the High Court—so you have to have an important point of law.

What the government is seeking to do now is to introduce a new means test, a test where, to apply for leave, for instance, you have to pay $10,000, instead of some $2,000 currently and instead of the much smaller amount which applied before this government changed the fees last year. On top of that $10,000, you have already had to pay the costs in the court of appeal and your lawyers' fees as well.

Let us remember also that some 75 per cent of applications for leave are refused, so it is only a very small number of critically important matters that go to the High Court. Let us also remember that, if you do get leave granted, the appellant pays $10,000 for notice of appeal, compared to $2,000 before these fees, $8,000 for a hearing fee—just to get listed—compared to $3,000 before these fees were introduced and $12,000 for each day in court, compared to $1,500. You are talking about a monumental hike here. It is no wonder that the Courier‐Mail made it clear in a very pertinent editorial a few days ago that their view was that, in considering the principles of access to justice, there is a lot more to consider than the question of money.

One winner continually in all this—and Senator Margetts got this right—is the executive. What we have here is not just one measure in isolation but a measure in the context of a whole range of other measures. We have cuts to legal aid. We have fees of this nature. We have governments deciding and contemplating radical changes to tribunals—tribunals which are there to ensure that those without resources have access to a mechanism to ensure government treats them properly and within the principles of natural justice and fairness.

BREAK.PARA: Those tribunals are now being radically reassessed. I gather from reports that they are going to be abolished and replaced by some business‐type operation which will be run by a chief executive officer and will have to follow government policy, as opposed to the law. Fees are being contemplated for them, and so on. At the same time, resources for ombudsmen are being cut back and human rights resources are being cut back monumentally. We can add and add. We can talk about the Environmental Defender's office and so on.

The only access to justice people may be left with at the end of this government's program of denying access to justice may very well be section 75 of the constitution and access to the High Court. It is for this reason that we need to have a very close look at what we are doing here, because the winner will be the executive. People will not have a capacity to fight, and even those who are poor, who have access to the court because of exemption procedures, will have to worry about the costs they will have to pay if they lose the case.

Let us look at the impacts of these changes. What I would like to do—and I have not had a chance to discuss this with the other side—is incorporate in Hansard a schedule of comparison sent to us by Chris Pullin QC, President of the Australian Bar Association, which sets out the fee differentials. The schedule from the Australian Bar Association shows that, had you, for instance, taken a High Court case before the change of government, you would have had to pay some $3,000 by way of leave application, notice of appeal and hearing fee; if you were to take the same case under these provisions, you would pay close to $49,000 or $50,000 to run the same sort of case.

This is a monumental grab for cash. As Mr Pullin has quite clearly explained in letters to all members of parliament and to the Australian Financial Review, if you were a small business wanting to run a case in the High Court seeking justice, before you even paid your lawyers' fees and before you even take into account all the appeal fees that you have incurred on the way through, you would have to pay $49,300 for one day in court. This is obscene.

As I say, the poor may have some access; the rich will definitely have access; John Elliott will be able to rename the High Court his Princes Park; but small business people and people in between will just not be able to access justice. User pays is not appropriate when it comes to access to courts. It is not appropriate when it comes to access to the High Court. If you look at these figures and the motivation for it, you have to ask yourself, would there have been a Mabo case if these sorts of the fees had applied? Would there have been a Wik case? Would there have been cases that have over the years established in our constitutional framework concepts of access to justice, fair hearing and so on? Some of them may have got through and Senator Ellison will say to us, `Well, those people are exempt from fees,'—and well he might. You should never underestimate the threat of having to pay lawyers' fees if you lose the case. That is something that exemptions do not adequately cater for.

We are concerned about these fees. We were concerned about fees last year and we tried to bounce the government's proposals then. As I say, we are talking about these fees on top of a very large increase last year. The schedule of Mr Pullin QC will demonstrate that better than I will be able to in the time I have here.

Let me finish on two particular points. In the estimates process we asked the Attorney-General's Department how they actually came up with the figures and how they actually decided to levy the fees and charges that they have decided to levy. We initially asked them what modelling they did on the impact of these increases, either on small businesses or on the individual. The answer from Mr Skehill was that they did not do any. We then asked how they actually came up with the fees and charges. How did they decide what was appropriate? The answer then was that essentially they had a certain amount that they had to raise, they put that amount into a computer, and these are the figures that fell out. I am paraphrasing Mr Skehill's words. They put the figures in a computer, pressed a few buttons and these are the figures that came out. There was no modelling, no consideration of access to justice and no real consideration as to whether one fee was appropriate in terms of their benchmark in trying to achieve 30 per cent cost recovery in comparison to state jurisdictions and so on.

Our view is a very strong one and that is that the government is here just running a grab for cash and in their grab for cash they have really ignored those basic principles of democracy, access to justice and of people—rich or poor—having a capacity to access the highest court in the land. They have also ignored the fact that, of those very few cases that go to the High Court, most of them—in fact all of them—have to have a public interest component. The litigants are actually paying the fees to clarify the law for all of us.
In the words of a Courier‐Mail editorial of 18 June:
This is an unconscionable use of power by the Commonwealth government. It will prevent some important legal issues from being heard by the High Court. It should be rejected by this Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset let me say that these fee increases are designed to increase the High Court's present cost recovery rate of 12 per cent to 30 per cent. That brings it in line with other measures which the Commonwealth announced in previous fee increases for other courts. Most importantly, it brings it into line with the average fee recovery in the various state and territory courts across this country.

BREAK.PARA: It is important to note that the point Senator Bolkus made that indeed we might not see another Mabo is quite incorrect, because for a start that case was in receipt of legal aid funding and we do have a waiver or existing exemption provision which relates to those people who are in receipt of legal aid, Austudy, Abstudy or in possession of a card entitling them to Commonwealth health benefits. People who fall within those categories would be entitled to a waiver. To say that, if someone is impecunious, they are put at a disadvantage by these fee increases is quite wrong. The truth is that they are eligible for a waiver and, in any event, you can still apply to the registrar to waive the necessary fees. That decision is subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

While I am on that point of waiver, it is important to note—and the opposition should take note of this—that all criminal matters are exempt from these fees. What we are talking about are matters in the civil jurisdiction or pertaining to constitutional law. We are not talking about matters which are in the criminal jurisdiction. Of the applications that were eligible for fees in the year 1995-96, 10 per cent of those fees were waived on application. In that year of 1995-96, only two applications were refused. One can see that that exemption was not exercised in a manner which was exclusive, but rather inclusive.

In that year there were some 516 matters attracting a filing fee. When you look at the matters which actually reached hearing—37 were civil, seven were criminal and 17 fell into the constitutional jurisdiction—you can see that the civil jurisdiction is by far the greater area attracting the High Court's attention. In this area you have large corporations taking matters to the High Court. It is not a situation where the majority of High Court matters are being brought by individuals, people who are in receipt of legal aid, people who would fit into the battlers category. You have in the High Court many cases which are brought by multinational companies, companies and associations which are well funded and well resourced. It is important to remember that, at the end of the day, of those 516 matters, there was a small number of hearings.

Senator Bolkus alluded to this in his address when he stated that most matters were refused at the stage of application for special leave. So it should be, because that is where you sort out the wheat from the chaff. But that, in itself, takes up a great deal of High Court time. The High Court has to list those for hearing, it has to open a file and it has to process them. That is where you have a great deal of cost, a cost which cannot be ignored. The cost of running the High Court is exorbitant, and these costs just cannot be allowed to run away unchecked. In the current system there are safeguards for those who are impecunious, as I have outlined. There is the waiver of fees and, in any event, there is the availability of legal aid.

So to couch this in the terms of denial of justice or that this is an attempt by the government to deny people access to the High Court is just not true. In fact it is quite mischievous to say that. What we are doing here is bringing the High Court into line with other courts in the states and territories of this land and other measures which have been passed by this Senate in relation to other Commonwealth jurisdictions.

This government had the most responsible task of ensuring that we cut back on the deficit which we inherited from the previous government—in excess of $10 billion. It is projected that by next year we will have that figure in the black by $1.6 billion. We cannot afford to let up on our cost recovery across the board until that figure is achieved, until we have done for the Australian people what we said we would do—that is, to put the accounts into the black. We cannot say, `The Attorney-General's portfolio is exempt.' Like all other portfolios, it is subject to cutbacks and an increase in cost revenue or cost recovery. It is only appropriate that all the courts be brought into line. The High Court is no exception to that.

Cases such as the Mabo decision and the Brandy decision will continue to happen in Australia. There will be no denial of any application of that sort. Those sorts of people who bring those applications, if they have merit, will be heard by the High Court and, if those people are impecunious, they will be granted a waiver. If they do not fall into the categories I have mentioned, there is the safety net of applying to the registrar for an exemption. If you are not happy with the registrar's decision, you can take it to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I do not think we can be fairer than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —This government cloaks itself in the mantle of economic respectability that anything which means you can balance your budget makes it acceptable to cut costs or raise fees wherever you like. Of course, you will not have a crack at the Defence department or anything which you really enjoy. You will have a crack at those institutions which you do not enjoy. I have discovered, in watching what has been going on in this place in the past year, that we do not have an Attorney-General who defends justice and access to it, but one who attacks it and is not protecting our institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats will be supporting disallowance motion No. 4, as it is entirely consistent with the longstanding Democrats' opposition to economically rationalising the judicial arm of government in this country. We think that this move does not represent a question of fees and economics. We think this is part of an overall onslaught which will affect access to justice, which will limit and constrain it and which will result in it being part of an elitist approach to having access to justice only where you can afford it.

You have to put this into the perspective of all the other things you have done. You cut legal aid back, you raise fees in the lower courts, you raise fees in the higher courts and you assault the High Court in the media. This has to be seen in the perspective of this whole package. My colleague the Reverend Senator Woodley describes it as the corporatist state—the ascendancy of economic fundamentalism as a universal criteria for the development of public policy. In this instance, it is our opinion that it contributes to limiting access to justice in Australia. Your view, and I am distressed to hear you defend it, is that nothing is worth paying for, nothing is sacred from the view that you have to pay your way.

TALK.START.PARA: —But we have exemptions.

—You may have exemptions. The overall approach is such that people will find it harder and harder to access our courts. In the long history of theology, of philosophy, of civilisation and of history, the highest authorities have always made themselves accessible and open to the common people. The words you speak deny those very fundamental elements.

SPEECH.PARA: You do not actually comprehend, I do not think, the way in which you are chipping away at the most fundamental and important element in our society: justice being free and accessible to those who need it, not efficiency and user‐pays driven in every respect. The Australian Democrats' opposition to the notion that the court should be responsible for their own cost recovery is well documented. Such a user‐pays principle is entirely contrary to the universal principle of access of ordinary people to justice, particularly—not exceptionally—to the highest courts in the land.

The deceit in your user‐pays logic, to us, is obvious. We say that the purpose of revenue raising is that the public pays for the services that it wants. It already pays for political and legal institutions. It already pays for the Defence department, for education, for health. What is absent from your view is that, in the system which is created under our present constitution, that constitution puts down the desire that the court should be readily accessible to our citizens as a birthright of the citizens of this country. It is what we offer as a nation—it is part of our nation, in fact: the right of all Australians to access and participate in our system of government, should they choose to. We part company from Senator Ellison on the fundamental principle that access to the courts should not be interfered with by financial considerations. There are other considerations far more important to that which go to the heart of our attachment to the rule of law which we believe take priority.

In the last decade the recognition of the rights of Australian citizens, particularly indigenous citizens in terms of the government's view of the High Court, has been a bugbear for governments in this country. The hysteria led by the Deputy Prime Minister, now the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer), after the Wik decision is just an example of the irritability that the High Court is causing for the reactionary and fundamentalist side of politics in this country, but those opposite should bear in mind that the courts are often the most conservative elements of our society. Those of us on the progressive side of politics find that to advance the cause of environmentalism, of Aboriginal rights or of anything else is a long, uphill battle. Those courts are there to balance the interests of society, both from the conservative side and from the social and progressive side, and they have done as much for your side of politics as for us on our side of politics over the years.

We see the rule of law as a fundamental tenet of democracy, and we believe that that rule of law is challenged by the present government—unless, of course, they see it as operating to their advantage. We do not doubt that, if the Wik decision had swung in favour of the pastoralists—and we believe that the Wik decision as it stands did quite well by them—there would have been little comment from the National Party or the government about the way in which the High Court functions.

You cannot have it both ways. You cannot have a democracy governed by the rule of law and enforced by an independent judiciary under the separation of powers doctrine and then call foul when decisions do not go your way. In our constitutional system of government, the High Court is the ultimate umpire whether you like it or not and whether we like it or not. We do not appreciate the Attorney-General (Mr Williams), the government and the Deputy Prime Minister in particular continually attacking this particular institution. It erodes one of the basic protections we have in our society.

In my speech in the second reading debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1996 I incorporated a table of the last set of court fee increases brought into effect by last year's budget. I note, and I repeat for the benefit of the Senate, that the disallowance motion for those fees was defeated when Senator Colston and Senator Harradine supported the government. I repeat that we do not regard those fee increases as being an economic matter; we regard them as attacking our institutions where we want increased access to them and increased availability of justice for citizens who need it. What we need much more of in the intermediary process is conciliation and arbitration, which prevents people having to take on governments, companies and each other on an adversarial basis.

BREAK.PARA: For the High Court alone these fees represent the following marked increases: for applications made under rule 1, order 55, 172 per cent for individual applicants and 443 per cent for corporate ones—this is from a government which says what a wonderful job it is doing about inflation; that is not helping inflation—for a writ of summons or petition, 172 per cent for individuals and 443 per cent for corporations—so much for supporting small business; for civil special leave applications, 308 per cent for individuals and 716 per cent for corporations; for applications under section 40 of the Judiciary Act, 713 per cent for individuals and 1,526 per cent for corporations—that sounds like 1930s inflation; for notices of civil appeal, 172 per cent for individuals and 443 per cent for corporations; and for setting down fees for civil appeals, 144 per cent for individuals and 387 per cent for corporations. And transcripts per page have increased by 1,650 per cent for both individuals and corporations. In any respect these are astronomical fee increases—not keeping pace with inflation. These increases were introduced by this government not less than 12 months ago.

Conservative estimates by the legal profession now say that, if these court fees proceed, a one‐day appeal hearing in the High Court of Australia will cost on average $40,000. That is more than the average salary of an Australian. It is extraordinary that, in a society which should be democratic, should champion the cause of access to justice, should pride itself in being governed by the rule of law, we are requiring citizens who are forced to go all the way up to the High Court to forgo a year's salary or more for one day in court.

I appreciate that you say there are exceptions, but the fact is that that is the overall result for everyone. As we well know, many court cases run for a number of days or even weeks, and it is foreseeable that, given that most people's chief asset is their home, in deciding whether or not to pursue their case people will quite literally have to contemplate losing the roof over their heads. What we must always consider in these matters is not the big boys who compete in these things, but the small person and what the effect of losing has on them. Many people risk a great deal to pursue things that matter to them.

Thirteen years ago all Australians had the right to have their case heard in the High Court as long as their claims amounted to $20,000 or more. It seems an odd cut‐off to me to do it by money but, anyway, that is what it was. The consequence, of course, is that a huge workload was created for the High Court, and cases, which were limited then, were required to be restrained somewhat. Appeals are now taken to the High Court only if they are granted by special leave. We have to ask, if there is so much demand for these institutions, what does it say about the way in which we resolve our problems within society?

I welcome, incidentally, some of the other things the Attorney‐General has been doing, such as looking at the resolution of disputes and making the courts work far better at the lower end. So let me not blacken your name completely as a government; you are certainly addressing some of the issues about demand and management of cases. I appreciate that and I want to give you the recognition for that.

The scenario that these increases would see occur is this: if these fee increases are not disallowed, for a person to even request special leave to appeal will cost them $10,000 instead of the $2,000 at present. That is just to get their case listed. If special leave to appeal is granted, and in 75 per cent of cases it is not, the applicant must shell out another $10,000, an increase from the present $2,000, to take out a notice of appeal. By this stage they are already up to $20,000 and the case will not have been heard yet, and all the time their solicitors' and barristers' fees will be ticking over. And, of course, legal aid is harder to get.

To get the case on what is called the list, another $8,000 will need to be paid. This has been increased from the present $3,000. The grand prize in this hike in court fees goes to the daily hearing fee, presently $1,500—up to $12,000 a day. That is for every day a person spends in court.

We do not need to be reminded that evidence currently before the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee inquiring into legal aid reveals that civil appeals have long since ceased to be funded in almost all jurisdictions. The option for Australians wishing to access their right to justice is now clear: you pay more than your annual salary and possibly you risk your home just for your day or days in court.

The government may think it is desirable to discourage people as much as it can from going to court. I say to you that, unless you have an alternative process whereby they can resolve their differences, you have to continue to allow them to have that access. Your fee increases will decrease access to justice, will limit access to justice and will attack a fundamental principle in our system that access to justice and the rule of law is required to be pursued and promoted.

I think that this sort of thing just adds to the overall view of your government as one which really has some very mean‐spirited and hard attitudes to Australians and their needs, both at the most fundamental level of their constitutional rights and their philosophies and principles, and at the ordinary day‐to‐day level as to how they can earn their living, whether they can get a job and whether they can live in a society where people are tolerant of one another.

I have told you before, Senator Ellison, that I consider you to be a decent and honourable person. I would urge you to influence your government to reconsider their whole approach and their whole attitude to these questions on the way in which law and justice is to be approached in our society. We live in a society which is getting increasingly aggressive, increasingly insecure, increasingly uncertain, increasingly bothered about what is happening to it and what its prospects are. It is not good enough just to stand up and say, `Look, in terms of economics, this is how it all works.' Those people are crying out and saying, `We are not just an economic unit. Our lives are not just run by economics. We do not want to hear just about economics. We want, for once, to hear that this is right because it is right, not because it costs mon ey.' Of course it costs money. Adding these fees is not going to stop the court system costing money. They want to know that you will protect and preserve the institutions and the rights and the important things that matter to them.

I am not opposing this because it is my job to oppose the government; I am opposing this because it reflects an overall philosophy and an approach which we think does damage to our system and is not warranted and affects everyone: small corporations, individuals and community groups. The only people who can really afford this are the big people in the world, and mostly they can look after themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say, first of all, that Senator Ellison's comments and explanation of the regulatory increases were the most succinct and almost persuasive that I have actually heard. I commend Senator Ellison for that effort. But it was a defence, sadly, of the indefensible.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, when there were considerable increases, they were actually not disallowed by this parliament. I was really surprised to see the additional increases that were imposed this year by these regulations. I had not really expected them, I must say. Might I also say that I do not know whether too many other people had expected them either. No doubt these matters were under due consideration over a period of time within the department and no doubt the department had been required to come up with something that would go to some extent to cost recovery, and they have lighted on this figure of 30 per cent, which is said to be the figure that applies to cost recovery, as a general rule of thumb, in other jurisdictions, in other courts.

As has been said in this debate, we are dealing with the High Court, and that is a very special court indeed. As has been indicated, you need special leave to go to the High Court. The matters that are to be dealt with by the High Court are, by definition, matters which must meet the public import ance criterion. They must be matters of significant public importance. Section 75 matters—that is, original jurisdiction mat ters—are set down in the constitution and we cannot do anything about those. But by definition, if one looks at section 75 matters, they are matters of considerable public interest and public importance.

There are two questions here that are raised in one's mind: one is the right of persons to have their day in court and the other is the role of the High Court in the clarification of laws that are passed in this country. With regard to the first question, I know that the parliamentary secretary, Senator Ellison, of all people, is very interested in the area of access to justice. I indicate that, so far as that is concerned, there are problems with regard to fees.

Senator Ellison has said that there are waivers. He has indicated that there were only two applications last year—I thought he said only two applications; it may have been three or four—that were refused waiver. Two applications for that sort of assistance were actually refused. But one has to go back one step and ask: how many others would have not got over the barrier had that barrier been too high? The point that I am making is that I think that the fees, as listed in these regulations, are a further hurdle to access to justice.

I will not delay the Senate long. The role of the High Court, as provided for in the constitution, is to clarify the laws of the nation. From memory, section 76 gives this parliament the power to decide these particular matters. I know that a great deal of concern has been expressed by a number of people about the problem of judge-made laws. Laws are to be made, really, by the democratically elected members of parliament, and that is a very important principle of democracy. We should not go down the track of judge-made laws.

Nevertheless, we should not impede access by appellants to the High Court in order to have clarified the laws which are binding on those appellants, and that, as we are all well aware, is not an easy task. Special leave must be obtained. Something like 75 to 80 per cent of requests for special leave were overturned in the last 12 months.

BREAK.PARA: In short, I just do not feel that I could support, even in a negative sense, this regulation. As has been indicated in this debate and elsewhere, the increases are enormous. The increases that have occurred since 1992 are enormous—500 per cent; and even higher than 500 per cent. I just simply say to the chamber that I do not think, overall, I am in a position to negatively support the government even by abstaining. I am aware that if I abstain from the vote on this matter, it may be carried by other means. But I am supporting the disallowance motion on this particular occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing this debate, I will not be holding up the Senate unduly. I would like to thank all of the senators who have made a contribution in today's debate. I do believe it has been a very important debate. It has been about justice and it has been about access to justice.

SPEECH.PARA: We should not have government by fear. It should not be that contracts within society, which even the right wing of any society tends to hold up—including the contract that a government makes with society in relation to the constitution and the contract that a government makes when forming laws—are enforceable contracts. It should not be that some laws are enforceable and that they cannot be challenged in the highest courts of the land.

I want to mention a couple of the debating points that were made by Senator Ellison. He said cost recovery was appropriate. No, not at this level—not in terms of access to justice. These are not appropriate cost recovery mechanisms. He said that, in relation to cases like Mabo and Brandy, there would be no denial of justice, that test cases would be run if they have merit. Who will be deciding if they have merit? Who, in the final analysis, will make that decision. If it is the government—if it is government people and government decisions—surely that is not a valid argument. In whose opinion? Who decides? If often the case of whether a person does not have to pay fees is based on whether they have access to legal aid, you have to go back to that circular argument. Fewer and fewer people are going to be able to access legal aid. That level of eligibility—because of funding cuts—is smaller and smaller. If access to legal aid means that a person gets access to exemptions from fees, that means fewer and fewer people will fall into those categories.

Senator Ellison says that there is always the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Well, guess what? A person needs funds to access the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as well. They need legal assistance to get that and, if they are having trouble getting legal assistance either through legal aid or through organisations like the Environmental Defender's Office—which was the one that recently assisted pensioner Len Howard to get a clarification of what the government should have been doing in terms of releasing documents—then you are going around in circles: we do not give it to you, so you cannot get it, so we will not give you the exemption.

It is a real problem and this has been recognised by the very good arguments that have been made today. I commend this disallowance motion to the Senate. I hope that the message that has been given by all opposition senators and by the community clearly and unequivocally is accepted by the government. We know that charges were imposed by the previous Labor government. We are standing up for basic access—when that is taken away from the grasp of ordinary people. This is the principle upon which we stand today.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, before the division is taken, I advise the Senate that I may have an interest in this matter, as I have a case that may be appealed to the High Court in the very near future, and I am voting against my interests.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That regulations 11 and 12 of the Austudy Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 83 and made under the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

In moving this disallowance motion, I would like to emphasise the importance of this measure to the Senate. It directly relates to young people—single students—without dependents who share accommodation. They are being directly penalised by the actions of this government. These are actions that were taken in the 1996-97 budget. This will be the last of a series of measures coming through that go to the removal of half a billion dollars in assistance to students through various changes to Austudy and Abstudy.

These measures specifically reduce by one-third the maximum rent assistance available to single students without dependents who share accommodation from 1 July this year. The government will argue that this is a proposition that ought to be supported because it will effectively be in line with the Department of Social Security measures which will also cut rent assistance payments to some persons, which were dealt with in the Senate last year.

I would like to emphasise to senators that this measure is different. While technically in line with those measures being taken in the social security arena, this measure is different because the circumstances and the experience of students are different. As we have seen in the last two days, the government has announced changes with regard to youth assistance, which make this problem all the more difficult for students. It will make the situation all the more difficult for those students if this principle is accepted by way of regulation, the principles of which are outlined in these particular regulations that the government is seeking to put into force.

The government is sending out two quite contradictory messages with these new policy announcements on the youth allowance which, in the end, I suppose, boil down to the one message. On the one hand, they are saying that students and people who require rent assistance should not share accommodation. That is effectively what they are saying. They are saying, `If you share accommodation, your level of assistance should be reduced because it is argued that there are fewer costs.' I will argue that that is not the case.

They are also suggesting that if you live at home, which they say they are trying to encourage people to do to actually build family values or some such measure, you will not receive any assistance at all. What this new youth allowance proposes, which is directly related to this fundamental principle being established in this particular set of regulations, is that persons under 18 not at school will lose $145 per fortnight. However, under the government's family taxation initiatives, they will receive some $18 per fortnight. The disparity could not be more stark. On the one hand, the government is saying that there will be an increased requirement by state policy for parents to take increasing responsibilities for the support of young people in this country. On the other hand, at the same time they are imposing additional costs on families to meet the various requirements for education, health and a whole range of other areas which actually make it more difficult for families to do that.

So, on the one hand, what we have is students being deprived of assistance by the government and forced into the social security system because of the breakdown in the various policies this government has been instituting while, on the other hand, at the same time, families are actually having assistance, which would enable them to assist various members of the family, taken away from them.

This particular measure highlights the special case for students. Students do not have flexibility; they do not have the opportunity to pick and choose where they live because they are tied to a particular location—that is, somewhere near the particular institution at which they are studying. In those localities, where the demand for accommodation of a particular type is often high, it is in fact necessary to share with others to reduce costs. Rent assistance is required all the more for students because of the special circumstances under which they study. I will come to that in more detail later.

This is the final change of a range of changes to Austudy that were introduced in last year's budget. A whole series of measures were taken to undermine that fundamental principle of the government's responsibility to actually assist people to stay at school, at university and at TAFE colleges. In fact, a whole series of measures—all negative—were introduced in the last budget which, in total, added up to some $½ billion in cuts to student assistance.

This particular measure the government is seeking to introduce will save the government some $700,000 over four years. However, if the principle is accepted by the Senate, there will be much greater savings to the government with the introduction of the youth allowance, which extends rent assistance to a far broader number of students than presently is the case. In fact, the number of applicants for rent assistance will increase. But this particular measure will actually restrict their capacity to claim under the new youth allowance provisions. The reduction of the maximum amount payable to singles in shared accommodation will become far more significant in that context in terms of the number of people who will be directly affected by this particular measure.

I think it is important to understand precisely what sorts of people we are talking about when we discuss these measures. We are not talking about people who have a lot of money; we are talking about people who must fit into one of the following categories to get this assistance: you have to be homeless, which is an irony in the sense that you are trying to provide rental assistance for people; you have to have parents who are unable to provide a home or carer support; you have to be an orphan; you have to be a refugee with no parents in Australia; you have to be in state care getting away‐from‐home rates and living away from your foster carer's home. In other words, we are talking about the very people who are most in need of assistance, who are already facing very severe disadvantage.

Austudy, as we all understand, is designed to help people complete their education. This obviously provides some benefit to them and to society as a whole. People who receive rent assistance are perfect examples of the sorts of persons Austudy was designed to directly assist. It is somewhat ironic to reduce the benefits to those persons and undermine their capacity to successfully complete their education at a time when the government is actually saying that there ought to be a greater emphasis on people staying at university, at TAFE and at school.

TALK.START.PARA: —They couldn't get it under your government.
—That is quite clearly not the case, Senator Tierney.
—Rent assistance through Austudy.
—That is clearly not the case.

BREAK.PARA: The measures that you have introduced will try to reduce some $½ billion worth of assistance to Austudy. In order to assess such assistance, students need to be paying a certain amount of rent, a threshold amount, before they can receive any assistance. It is not like getting a bonus. There is actually a requirement in this provision to pay the money out before you can get the rental assistance. Of course, above this threshold, three‐quarters of what is paid by way of rent is then paid to the student in the form of rent assistance, which itself is subject to a ceiling.

So we are not talking about some sort of windfall gain here to people who might not need it; we are talking particularly about a very disadvantaged group of people who are required to undertake study at particular universities and colleges, at particular educational sites, which are often in inner city areas, in areas with high rent, in areas where there is a requirement to share accommodation to reduce costs. As I say, the very special circumstances of students makes it necessary for assistance such as this to be maintained.

What this government is proposing to do is to penalise them for actually being required to attend a particular educational institution and find accommodation in a particular area close to that institution. The government is about to reduce the weekly rate of rental assistance—and these are the huge amounts of money that are actually involved—for such people from $37.30 to $24.90. This is hardly a king's ransom, but to the individual it is of great significance—particularly individuals who fit into such disadvantaged categories.

This measure will immediately affect around 2,600 people. It is likely that some of those people will find it too difficult to continue their studies. One of my great concerns about this measure is that it runs contrary to what I think all of us here would acknowledge is important—encouraging people to go to university and TAFE colleges to undertake further study, to participate in the education system and to enjoy the benefits of that education system, not just for themselves but for the benefit of the country as a whole.

With the commencement of the youth allowance on 1 July next year, some 70,000 full-time students who are currently Austudy recipients will be eligible for rental assistance. Those who are single and living in shared accommodation, which I would suggest well might be a significant proportion of them, will suffer because of this change. In fact, the precedent is being established now with a small group of some 2,600 people, and it will later apply to a much larger number of people.

The government has said that the youth allowance is not a savings measure. The truth of that matter is that we have not seen the full details of the costings, so we do not really know. In the 15 months that this government has been in office, I have lost confidence in their capacity to tell the truth when it comes to the issues of what programs cost and how the money is being spent. You cannot rely upon a ministerial press release to tell you what is going on. You cannot even rely on the budget papers to tell you what is going on. You cannot assume, just because the government says that a certain measure is not going to be a savings measure, that that will be the case.

I have an example which quite clearly points to this situation. What we are talking about today is a savings measure which is in advance. The government is taking away an entitlement to maximise rent assistance before the rent assistance is provided. It is caught securing a savings measure, in an underhanded way, without declaring it as such in the first place.

The government claims that the youth allowance is designed to encourage young people to study. Yet, as I have said, last year's budget reduces student assistance expenditure by some $513 million over four years. That represents a substantial attack upon the income support for students. These students do not enjoy millionaire status, as the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) would have liked us to believe when she dredged up the fictitious Wright family. This assistance is designed to assist people who already are substantially disadvantaged and are in real need of support from this parliament.

As I see it, this action can take a place amongst the unjustified and mean‐spirited changes to Austudy which were introduced last year. It can stand beside the cessation of case management for secondary students on the homeless rate of Austudy and Abstudy, beside the cessation of schooling and incidental allowances for the same homeless students, beside the tightening of the means test, which Senator Vanstone turned into an administrative nightmare, and beside the raising of the age of independence which, apart from being inequitable, is impacting particularly unfairly on some students who, for technical reasons, are considered dependent on their parents, when in reality they have led independent lives for years.

Essentially, this measure is a miserable device to inflict greater pain on families, not to provide additional support. It comes at a time when this government has introduced a whole range of measures across an array of portfolios. It is inappropriate for us to say that families should be encouraged to take on additional responsibilities for the support of students at schools when this government is not meeting its obligation in that regard. In fact, it is reducing its commitment to the provision of support to allow people to enjoy the benefits of participating in the education system.

Frankly, it is a mean, nasty and miserable measure aimed at inflicting greater pain and suffering on young Australians who are seeking to improve their position, and reach their full potential in life by participating in education. I urge the Senate to support this disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the disallowance motion before the chamber today. I agree with the comments of my colleague. I believe that the measure designed to reduce by a third the amount of rent assistance available to single students living in shared accommodation, to be introduced as of 1 July this year, is penny‐pinching, mean and nasty.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that, with the announcement of a common youth allowance, one of the ironies of this week is the government's boasting about the proposal to extend availability of rent assistance to students living away from home but, at the same time—this very week, in fact—it looks like the government will vote against attempts to stop the reduction of that rent assistance for students in shared accommodation. It is quite ironic when we are moving towards a system where families are increasingly expected to deal with financial burdens and economic hardship in supporting dependent children.

When I say `children', I am talking about 16‐, 17‐, 18‐year‐olds and upwards. These are not children. These are young adults with the same expenses and, in many cases, responsibilities and burdens as other members of the community. But that seems to be lost by many members in this place and in other decision making institutions. For that reason, the Democrats will support the disallowance of regulations 11 and 12, which is being moved today.

As a result of this measure, around 2,600 students are expected to lose as much as $24 a fortnight. That is an additional $24 a fortnight that they would have had to help pay the rent. This is when these people are receiving a maximum of around $264.70 a fortnight, and $24 equates to a little under 10 per cent of the total standard Austudy payment. That is based on the independent rate, which, as most of us know, would be the most generous amount, yet I think that would equate to around 60 per cent of the poverty line levels. So $24 a fortnight, to some people in this place, may not seem a lot to lose, but it is a substantial amount for students on Austudy who are struggling to make ends meet.

The government's decision to discriminate between students living in boarding accommodation and students living in shared housing seems nonsensical. Not many students on Austudy can afford to live alone, and I think this government just wants to punish them for being poor. Housing costs are one of the biggest causes of poverty in Australia, and that is why I find it even further distressing that this government would penny pinch in this area.

It is a coincidence that I have just come from the launch of a report today entitled Shutting the door in their faces: barriers to housing experienced by young people by Dr Rodney Fopp. The National Youth Coalition for Housing is having a press conference as we speak. They could not help but point out the ironies in this week's decision on the common youth allowance. The chairperson of that coalition, Maggie Hughes, says—and I will add the positive bits as well so I am not accused of misrepresenting the position of NYCH:
The common youth allowance went some way in recognising young people's housing affordability issues by extending rent assistance to students living away from home.
The Democrats commend that measure. She continues:

It did not, however, seize the opportunity to remove the unequal discrimination young people face by paying them lower benefits than older recipients. Further, it could result in further disadvantaging young people by refusing to recognise that leaving home is a normal process for those who achieved adulthood by parentally means testing the payments for students aged up to 25 years and the unemployed up to 21 years.

So while there are some positive measures that have come out of this week, the negative ones are compounded not only by the measures we see today but, as Senator Carr pointed out, as they are coming in a string of measures designed to attack young people, to reduce the eligibility for Austudy and other measures of financial assistance, especially for students—look at the recent Abstudy cuts of around $38 million. So it is a string of measures, a pattern, by this government to punish those least able to afford it and, in particular, to punish students.

Talking about students, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) only two days ago said that students were somehow the big winners under the common youth allowance proposal. Yet, I cannot see how students have been anything but the biggest losers under the coalition government. Apart from the 2,600 who will lose if this measure is not disallowed by the Senate, 125,000 students lost out under the Austudy changes that were passed in this place last year.

We know that young people aged 15 to 24 are on lower incomes. They have high levels of unemployment, housing problems, poverty and homelessness than the rest of the population. Just because we have re-runs of the Brady Bunch does not mean we want to go back, but this government seems to want to return to some halcyon days in the 1950s where some cute and quaint concept of the family ruled, where families were expected to shoulder sole responsibility for themselves and their children.

The 1950s were a very different place, and measures such as this overlook the economic and social reality of family life in the 1990s. Families cannot always afford to look after their students or young people in education training. They are not always in a position to do that. As for 16‐ and 17‐year‐old young unemployed people being expected to be dependent on their families, it is an outrageous decision.

As for Austudy, it remains shamefully below the poverty line. I said that the maximum rate equated to around 60 per cent. If that does not equate with the minister's or the departmental assessment, I would be happy to hear what their estimates are. As for the average rate of Austudy, I think that equates to around 35 per cent of the poverty line, so we are talking meagre benefits, meagre benefits that the coalition, before it got into office, promised it would actually maintain. That led many of us, including students, to presume that this meant in its current form or that at least what benefits did exist would be maintained.

In the same week that we have heard announcements about a common youth allowance, I note that the minister for youth affairs has announced a national youth week. I think around $400,000 is to be spent on PR and various promotions, but I do not think that the promotion and PR opportunity of youth week are going to somehow erase the cynicism that young people feel towards this government. The only thing that will do that is the truth. That is, if young people have reason to believe that, when governments or oppositions make promises—and core promises at that, such as not cutting operating grants, maintaining Austudy or not increasing various fees and charges—they will stick to those promises. But the coalition continues its zealous drive to push young people back into the parental home, and the common youth allowance is a further indication of that.

I look forward to the glossy brochures and the media fanfare of national youth week. I do not think it is actually starting until 1998. It would have been nice if even a token commitment to young people could have been made this year, but I guess we are going to get all the nasty stuff through in the meantime.

Students and the unemployed are not going to be fooled by this. If they are not a full-time student and under 18, if they are students living in share housing or public housing or if they are under 25 years of age, they are probably losing out under this government. Students on the coalition's current rent assistance hit list are not big winners, contrary to the minister's claims. The 2,600 single students living in share accommodation who are set to lose a third of their current rent assistance on 1 July are not going to be fooled, nor are the students in public housing who will lose rent assistance under the proposals in the 1997 federal budget.

Students should be wary of claims that they will have access to rent assistance under the common youth allowance. The promise of rent assistance for students, I note, is only for those who `have to live away from home'. So I look forward to the minister, her department or her representatives in this place, specifically stating what `have to live away from home' means. It sounds somewhat sinister to me, like another way of cracking down and narrowing the eligibility criteria, another way of narrowing access to benefits for young Australians.

I would like to know what the coalition means by that phrase. If the track record of this government is anything to go by, students will probably have to become homeless before they can qualify for rent assistance, a point that was made earlier by my colleague Senator Carr. He certainly pointed out the irony of providing rent assistance when, in order to obtain it in the first place, homelessness has to be demonstrated.

The standard rate of income for a student over 18 and living away from home remains at a level of around 60 per cent of the poverty line. That is shameful. The news that the common youth allowance will extend the incomprehensible actual means test, which was so mismanaged under Austudy, is not welcome. I find it an extraordinary decision of this government to extend the actual means test, which was the subject of such debacle and such mismanagement earlier this year, when it takes as long as six months to receive a payment under the AMT.

This week I got a phone call from a woman who has been in contact with my office who only this week received her first Austudy payment for the year. That is a long time to go without a cent from Austudy—we are now into June. From January to June this woman has survived without Austudy. So I am frightened that the use once again of the actual means test will leave many young Australians in the lurch; that is, without benefits or with meagre benefits for as long as six months.

Today the Australian Democrats are proud to support the disallowance. I only wish the coalition had taken the opportunity with its announcement of the CYA to really do something about the availability of housing and rent assistance to young Australians—not this token measure the coalition has put forward.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, while we are on that topic, the coalition could probably do something about analysing the age of independence for students under the current scheme of Austudy. One of the greatest barriers to participation and to obtaining financial assistance for most students and young people wishing to study is the fact that the age for the independent rate is set at 25—one of the most regressive measures introduced by this government and one that the Democrats oppose and will continue to fight against. I do not understand how you can define students as winning under this government or under the last week's proposals when they are faced with those kinds of financial and psychological barriers.

The reality is that this government has eroded consistently the benefits available to students and young people. If they vote against the disallowance today then they are set to do it again. There is no doubt that the key to ensuring access and equity in terms of participation in education at whatever level—primary, secondary, higher education or tertiary training—is through an appropriate scheme of student financial assistance. Instead, we are seeing governments go the other way.

I do acknowledge Senator Tierney's earlier interjections while Senator Carr was speaking that, in may respects, the former government was not much better. They were involved in reports, they were involved in committees—

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely!

—Don't worry, Senator Tierney, I am not excusing your government either. We were there and we suffered through the Price report and the Chapman report and the report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee. We have read all the recommendations. How dare the government suggest, as I believe they did yesterday, that the gist of those recommendations has been implemented by this government. All the bad recommendations seem to have been implemented, I note, whether it is the Chapman report and the loans scheme or a range of other recommendations that have been made. I am waiting to see a few more of the positive recommendations implemented.

BREAK.PARA: The Australian Democrats have been fighting this cause for a long time. Back in the days of TEAS we were arguing that there should be parity between unemployment benefits and student financial assistance payments. You have no gripe there from the Democrats; we are very happy to see parity achieved. However, we want to see meaningful, livable incomes provided. There is no point in providing payments for people if they do not even meet or go some way towards meeting poverty line levels.

What we would dearly love to see is not only realistic eligibility criteria for these schemes, and that includes a realistic assessment of and understanding of what is an adult and what are adult expenses, but also accessible and appropriate levels of income—not these meagre, penny‐pinching schemes and amounts that are made available to young Australians and students. Students deserve, in terms of financial assistance, livable income levels that not only enable them to pay for the necessities of life such as shelter and food—and shelter is what we are talking about today; that is, ensuring that students who are living in shared accommodation are not deprived of assistance or do not have their rent assistance cut by a third—but also for the purchase of things such as study materials, books and a range of other incidentals and costs incurred as a result of choosing to study.

As I understand from yesterday's rhetoric, that is what this government says it is about. It wants to provide incentives for young people to be involved in education and training. So why, when you use the word `incentive', do you introduce fees and charges that are up front and full cost? Why do you hike up HECS? Why have you introduced a three‐tier system of HECS? Why do you debate or even consider the possibility of a HECS structured fee system for TAFE? Or why do you not do something about current up‐front and other charges available in the TAFE and vocational education arena? Why make student financial assistance so poor, so meagre that students are not sure that they can survive on those benefits let alone take into account the moneys that they need to finance their education, study materials, books, et cetera?

If you are really keen on incentives, why not do something about it? You can start today. The minister's representative and his colleagues could start today by supporting this disallowance, putting their votes where their mouths are and providing an incentive, meagre as it is, by voting not to reduce by a third the amount of rent assistance available to those students in shared accommodation. If you need any other rationale apart from that being provided today, I strongly urge members to get a copy of this report by Dr Rodney Fopp, which outlines painfully and clearly the hardships that young people face in accessing housing in the private and also the public rental markets. I urge you to study that report closely because it makes quite shameful reading. I seek leave to table that report.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start, I was interested in the comment made by Senator Carr that he had difficulty finding information from the budget papers. Welcome to opposition! The budget papers are not designed to give information. There is a whole lot of information that is given in various forms, it generally changes each year and it is extremely difficult, if not impossible, to directly compare one year to another. As I say, welcome to opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I am debating the disallowance motion from the ALP in relation to Austudy regulations which reduce rental assistance for singles sharing accommodation. This is a budget 1996‐97 measure. At the moment, rental assistance is only payable to homeless Austudy students, although we acknowledge that the youth allowance changes will pay rent assistance to more students.

Rent assistance is currently payable to around 2,500 homeless students on Austudy. If they are single, they normally get a maximum rate of $37.30 per week. The government wants to reduce that by one third, to $24.90 per week for those who share accommodation. The Greens are fundamentally opposed to the assumptions behind this measure. Students do not necessarily cut costs if they share. That is a very middle‐class notion. This is a question of economic survival. It is not as if poorer students who would be eligible for Austudy—and we are talking about homeless students here—have the option to live by themselves and suffer the costs. This is simply a crass attempt by the government to cut costs and steal from the poor once again.

The government also wants to nip this reduction in rent assistance in the bud because it has given rent assistance to 70,000 other students under the youth allowance. That is a sweetener, giving assistance to more students while cutting off some 60,000 16‐ and 17‐year‐old unemployed young people, leaving them with no income whatsoever if they are not in education or training.

The Greens oppose the reduction of rent assistance to all eligible students, and to homeless students in particular. For the past four years I have been calling for rent assistance for all Austudy recipients. Just to live near the universities and get to campus—especially in Sydney and Melbourne—students have to pay very high rents. Additionally, we believe the youth allowance should provide a rent assistance component. This should be accompanied by a restoration of benefits to all 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds, whether or not they are studying. Not to do this is to abrogate social responsibility, create a multitude of social problems and discriminate against young people. The Greens (WA) will be strongly supporting this disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 1996 budget, this government announced changes to the DSS rent assistance provisions. What we are doing today is extending those in an equitable way to include students who are currently receiving Austudy. Under our new youth allowance arrangements—starting from 1 July 1998—students on Austudy will come under the same sorts of provisions. We believe this is equitable and, indeed, much better treatment, particularly for the group who were students under the previous Austudy arrangements. I was pleased that Senator Stott Despoja was at least gracious enough to acknowledge some of the positive aspects of these youth allowance arrangements, including the fact that a vast number of students are going to benefit who did not previously.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a budget savings measure. It is actually costing the government more money. We are prepared to put more money into this, because we have seen the inequitable position of students who were on Austudy under the previous Labor government. If those students decided to try to improve themselves by education—and possibly came off unemployment benefits to study—they had this massive disincentive. They lost benefits if they moved to study. They might or might not have got Austudy but, even if their support income levels were low enough for them to get Austudy, two things happened. Firstly, they were paid at a lower rate compared to those on unemployment benefit and, secondly, they did not get any housing assistance at all. Senator Carr says this is a mean measure. What could be meaner than those students not being able to get any assistance at all? That was precisely the situation during 13 years of Labor government.

In 1994, the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training brought in a report which pointed this out and recommended things along the lines of a common youth allowance and the removal of disincentives in the system. At that stage, students had an incentive to move out of study and into unemployment, and we had evidence right around Australia of a great number of students doing exactly that. As students, they could not hack it financially. They found that, if they moved to unemployment and did nothing, they might be able to survive—they got a higher benefit and rent assistance, but they were not studying. We were putting those people back into the poverty trap, and that is what we are reversing with this bill.

I am very curious that Senator Carr is moving a disallowance motion now. Last December there were a number of amendments proposed by the opposition when we were considering budget measures in relation to people on social security benefits. Rather curiously, although this reduced shared accommodation arrangement for people on welfare payments was in that previous bill, the Labor Party did not oppose it at that time. In December, there was no opposition to those measures which had a reduced payment for shared accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.
—That is true, Senator Carr; we have checked that. I do not know whether you were asleep at the time. Your party did move a number of amendments to that bill, but you did not—
—Have a look at Senator West's speech.

—I am talking about the vote, Senator Carr. Are you talking about what people said in the chamber? I am talking about what the vote records. The vote records that you did not then oppose this measure in relation to people getting welfare payments. All we are doing is supporting what you supported in December last year. We are extending that to people who are currently on Austudy, and you should welcome that, Senator Carr. I have heard you speak on many occasions in this chamber about the need for equity, and that is exactly what this measure achieves. This is an equitable measure. It is a measure that treats people who are now on Austudy in exactly the same way as those who are now on welfare benefits. I thought you would welcome that. I thought this would be one of the key measures your party would support. Let us have a look at what it actually does, because the whole focus—
—This would be a first for you. It is about time you got around to it.

—If Senator Carr stops jabbering on and listens for a moment, let us have a look at what it actually does. Let us take the situation of four students sharing accommodation; quite often students share accommodation. If they are in a place like Sydney they might be paying $200 a week and with four of them sharing they would pay $50 a week.
—Oh! Ha, ha!

—You must have a different rent system in Melbourne, Senator Carr. Maybe you might want to tell us about that. The new rate of rent assistance for those people would be $49.60 and if a person was living in a single situation they would be getting $74.60. I did invite Senator Carr when he was speaking to go through the maths of it and explain to the Senate why someone who is sharing accommodation, and therefore has to pay perhaps only a quarter of the rent, should get exactly the same money—which is what he is proposing—as someone who is actually living alone and receiving the assistance rate of up to $74.60. Why should they get the same amount? Their rent is going to be vastly less if four people are sharing. That is what this aspect of the bill recognises.

SPEECH.PARA: I will run through quickly how it will work. The amount triggers in after people are paying $32.20 per fortnight. If when paying their share of the accommodation they pay another $66.12, that would take them up to $99.32 a fortnight as their part of share. They would be able to get up to $49 in assistance under this plan. If we round off those figures to $100 a fortnight, they would be paid half of that.

I ask Senator Carr to give us the maths of what actually happened under his government in terms of payments for people who are on Austudy. How much did they get? We are saying that under that example they would get half. But in the 13 years of his government how much did they get? Zero. Zilch. You did not pay anything for people on Austudy. Under this bill we are paying that. We are treating them equitably. We are paying them exactly the same amount as the people who are on welfare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did this measure come from, that you are actually reducing—out of thin air?
—Could you rephrase your question so that it makes sense? What measure are you talking about?
—The measure that we are talking about in this disallowance measure. Where did it come from?
—The disallowance measure came from you.
—It is to reduce our program.
—Reduce your program? Senator Carr, we are actually spending more money in this.
—That is not true.

—Senator Carr, you must stop fibbing in this place. If you look at the measure you will find that it is not a budget saving measure. It is actually a measure where we are spending more money. Where are we spending it? We are spending it on the students who are now going to be treated the same as people on unemployment benefits. Not only are we putting these people in a much better situation financially, but I will give Senator Carr the key point—something that his government could never do. We have put incentive into the system for people to move off unemployment into study. All the research shows—if Senator Carr has a look at it—is that, if you study and gain a qualification, you are three times as likely to get a job. That is what this government is on about and that is what this measure is on about. For that reason I would urge the Senate to defeat this disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I begin by saying that it is customary on these measures to actually have a minister to deal with the particular issue before the Senate. While it might strictly be within the standing orders for Senator Tierney to put the government's view, it is not consistent with the normal proprieties of this place.
