I might suggest that it demonstrates the contempt with which the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) treats this chamber. It is quite apparent that this government has no compunction, no problem at all about saying whatever it likes no matter what actually is the case or what measures are actually being introduced. The government will say or do anything when it comes to trying to win support for them.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I suggest to Senator Tierney that we are in fact talking about regulations that go to the issues as outlined in budget measure No. 55 in last year's budget. You are in fact discussing the wrong issue. When you are talking about the youth allowance, you address all your remarks to the youth allowance as it will apply next year. These regulations go to the questions as outlined in budget measure 55 from last year's budget.

Fundamentally, I might suggest to Senator Tierney that Senator Vanstone might well have been better served if she had actually done this job herself and not left him to do it, because he cannot even follow the brief. I would have thought that with the amount of interest he has in education he could at least follow the brief and get the right measure. He is discussing the wrong measure.

On the philosophical questions, this government says it is about family values. This government says it is about providing additional social support to families to make sure that they look after their own needs. It privatises social security in this manner. This government in fact abandons families and individuals in real need. This is a government that is founded upon the fundamental hypocritical proposition that everyone ought to look after themselves, no matter how badly they are in need of support from the community at large. If someone is in need, it says that is their problem. And it says that it is a compassionate and Christian government!

The truth, of course, is somewhat different from that. What you see in a whole series of measures introduced by this government is that they are about making it more difficult for people in need, making it more difficult for families to survive as a result of actions taken by this government. A whole series of charges have been introduced in child care, in education, in health care and in pharmaceutical benefits—right across the board they take away the capacity of families to help their own.

We are not talking about a group of people that are well off. We are talking about 2,600 people that are hard up against it, some of the most disadvantaged people in this country—some 1,400 females and 1,200 males, according to the department's own advice to me at estimates. We are talking about people that are homeless. We are talking about people that are the most disadvantaged in our society. We are not talking about the sons and daughters of millionaires.

This miserable, mean‐spirited, pathetic defence that we have just heard highlights just how nasty this action is. A pathetic effort is being made here to try to pull the wool over the eyes of the Senate. What is being attempted here is to target 2,600 people and set the precedent which will of course apply to many tens of thousands of people in future years. It is a pathetic effort by you, Senator Tierney, to not even get the right measure when you do it. I would have thought you could at least get the right measure. We are talking about measures to reduce assistance from, currently, $37 to $24. As I say, it is specifically aimed at 2,600 people most directly in need.

What I want to emphasise is that there are special circumstances for students as a result of the particular arrangements that have to be made for them. To have reasonable access to universities or TAFEs, students often find it necessary—not an option, but necessary—to live in inner‐city, high rent areas and to share accommodation to reduce costs. This government is specifically aiming its measures at penalising those people.

Senator Tierney talks about equity. But he does not talk about fairness and he does not talk about justice. He certainly is quite prepared to use the usual tory double speak when it comes to explaining what is a vicious measure aimed at hurting people rather than providing them with assistance. It might well be equitable to treat all people harshly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Equally badly.

—Equally badly, as my colleague points out. It is not necessarily just and it certainly is not fair. What this measure is aimed at is inflicting greater pain and suffering on Australian families. Senator Tierney likes to have a crack at the Labor Party. I suppose that is what he is paid to do and I cannot begrudge him that opportunity. I have been known to have had the odd shot at him from time to time. But what he ought to be straight about is that the Australian Labor Party oversaw a 164 per cent increase in student assistance in its term in office. In its last year of office, half a million students were assisted at the cost of $1.6 billion.

BREAK.PARA: It is somewhat disingenuous of him to suggest that students were not able to get rent assistance under the Labor government. As I say, budget measure 55 reduced that assistance introduced by the Labor government. This government have cut half a billion dollars out of student assistance, and now they are trying to claim credit for an extension on the rent assistance measures to some students in the future. We have yet to hear precisely how they intend to do that. They said that in the future they are going to spend another $25 million. They have already taken $500 million away from those particular people to do that. So, as Senator Stott Despoja has rightly pointed out, before that cut is introduced they are reducing the maximum entitlement to students.

Senator Tierney talked about four students sharing accommodation and each having to pay only a quarter of the full rent. But the question is not whether they pay a quarter, or a half, or an eighth or any other number. The question is the net amount that is paid as a result of the circumstances in which the students are forced to live, the special circumstances that I speak of. In this particular measure, no matter which way you look at it, there is a requirement to meet a threshold level of rent before the assistance cuts in.

So, Senator, quite clearly you are disingenuous. I can say that most charitably. You are disingenuous. This is a measure which cuts in in order to assist, hopefully, students who genuinely need it. Surely, there could be no argument about the genuineness of the need. It is a measure that you would think would be aimed at helping such disadvantaged persons achieve success at university, at TAFE and at school.

Senator Tierney tries to have the Senate believe that there is not a threshold: `The three‐quarters of what is being paid by way of rent is paid to the student in the form of rent assistance'—which is itself subject to a ceiling; he forgets to point that out. We are not talking about people that are enjoying some sort of windfall. We are talking about people who genuinely need the support of this parliament to provide them with the necessary resources to assist them in securing some success through the education system. We are talking about people who are paying out more than that threshold amount of money.

This is not about a windfall gain, and it is an extraordinary proposition quite in keeping with what I say is the dishonesty of this government when it comes to addressing issues in terms of genuinely assisting families in need. It has been suggested that, if the state provides support, it somehow or other can be at the expense of the rest of the community. That is not the case. We are not providing support here to the sons and daughters of millionaires. We are providing support, as we should and did under the old measure, to people who genuinely need it. We ought to be talking about providing appropriate assistance that meets the circumstances of the 1990s. As Senator Stott Despoja pointed out, it is inappropriate to try to dwell upon some illusion of what family life was like in some distant golden age. We should be talking objectively about the real circumstances in which people find themselves today.

If you are serious about helping disadvantaged people to enjoy the benefits of education, you will ensure that the means to assist them are available. This is not a huge measure in itself. My recollection is that we are talking about the provision of $37 a fortnight—an extraordinarily small amount of money. If you are genuinely talking about equity rather than lowering standards, and if you are genuinely talking about fairness and justice, you will support this disallowance motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Carr's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of Appropriation Bills by Legislation Committees

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the respective chairs, I present reports on proposed expenditure in respect of the year ending 30 June 1998, together with the transcripts of evidence, for the following legislation committees:

SPEECH.PARA: Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee, Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee, and Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee.
Ordered that the reports be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move government business notice of motion No. 1, I seek leave to amend it by deleting the references to the Australian National Railways Commission Sale Bill 1997, the Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill 1997, the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill 1997, and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move government business notice of motion No. 1, as amended, which now reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the following bills, allowing them to be considered during this period of sittings:
Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98
Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1997‐98
Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1997‐98
International Monetary Agreements Amendment Bill 1997
Wool International Amendment Bill 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the government for the change as far as the Australian National Railways Commission Sale Bill 1997, the bill on privatising rail, is concerned. It is a very important matter for Tasmania, where the whole rail system is in enormous contention at the moment. The legislation came to the Senate just this morning. There are 44 pages of it. I am in discussion with a wide range of community groups in Tasmania. I will be meeting unions at a national level this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens are in favour of the railways staying in public hands free of debt at state level and under the jurisdiction of the public through the return to state government owner ship. I just flag that, and I thank the government for giving me more time to consult with community groups rather than having to debate this on the run. It is too important for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —As you well know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the cut‐off motion is designed to ensure that opposition parties have sufficient time to properly examine proposed legislation before it is debated, as we do not have extensive departments and resources to consider legislation that is rushed through. In this instance the Senate committee has reviewed the matter of rail in broad terms and therefore we have had an opportunity to examine it. We always like to resist cut‐off motions if we can because we believe that thoroughly examining legislation is one of the fundamental roles of the Senate. In this particular case, however, the Democrats will support the government in allowing this bill to come on for debate this session. This is because we believe that it is important that discussions start now to ensure that the matter is resolved as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: However, we would like to put on the record just how badly the government has managed this whole affair. The government announced in November 1996—that is, seven months ago—that it wanted to sell AN by 1 July this year, but they did not bother to introduce legislation into the House of Representatives until only a few weeks ago, on 14 May 1997. Why did they wait so long? Why didn't they table the bill in the previous session? It is what any sensible and reasonable minister should have done, and I believe the Senate should condemn the minister for the way in which he has managed this process.

Not only did it not occur to the minister to do this but the government only recently became aware that complementary legislation needs to be passed by the South Australian parliament, and that legislation has not yet been tabled. That is another reason why we need to accede to the minister's request, because the South Australian parliament are waiting for us on this issue.

BREAK.PARA: The government has mismanaged the sale process. Expressions of interest in the purchase of AN were called for in the national print media on 19 March 1997 and had to be lodged by mid‐April. This left little time for prospective buyers to prepare suitably detailed and thought‐through submissions. Final offers had to be lodged by early June, giving selected bidders only a few weeks to work on their submissions.

One bidder has been reported as saying that it was ridiculous to ask bidders to prepare adequate documentation in such a short space of time. Another has questioned why the sale is being rushed when a new owner would not be operating on 1 July.

Minister, I appreciate the system and I know that you are acting as a messenger in bringing this before the Senate and asking for our permission, but we would like to convey to you, from our side of the chamber, our disquiet with the manner and the process that is being adopted by the minister responsible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 June.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997. The question is that Democrat amendment No. 6 to clause 26 to agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Page 16 (after line 17), after Division 2, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 33A Electoral Commissioner to prepare information about the ballot

SPEECH.PARA: (1) As soon as practicable after the commencement of this Act, the Electoral Commissioner must prepare a statement containing information about how the ballot is to be conducted.

(2) Subject to subsection (3), the Electoral Commissioner must cause copies of the statement prepared under subsection (1) to be distributed in accordance with the procedures for distributing candidate statements under section 65.

(3) The Electoral Commissioner must not distribute copies of the statement prepared under subsection (1) unless the statement has first been approved by the Joint Committee on the Constitutional convention established under section 169A.

This amendment basically ensures that, in the flow of information that will be made available about the ballot—in candidate statements, booklets and so on that will now be available in a much more limited way—there be circulated with such information an information statement as provided for by our amendment No. 12. It is a statement prepared by the Electoral Commissioner about how the ballot is to be conducted. As I say, it is something that we would like to see distributed in accordance with the procedure that the Senate adopted for distributing candidate statements under section 65. It is a minor thing. I do not know if the government is prepared to pick it up, but I would like to think they would.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the general sense, of course, we are opposing opposition amendments which flow from the fact that the opposition will not accept a postal ballot, therefore necessitating this sort of amendment. As the AEC advises me, they do provide information on voting methods at every election, so there is no need to actually legislate to provide for the question of how-to-vote statements and how to comply with the election requirements. That is a normal function of the AEC and does not require legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The other problem with this, really, relates to precedent. Given that the tone of the debate has been—and has been pointed out to the government to be—that this is consistent with normal electoral methods, it has never been the case that a parliamentary committee oversees what the AEC does in this respect. We have all accepted the independence and the objectivity of the AEC in providing information on how-to-vote material. That should not be overseen by parliamentarians or politicians. This would be something of an unfortunate precedent to set.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, we have said that this is a different election but, by and large, where the provisions of the Electoral Act are sensible and relevant, they should be applied. That is the position the government has taken with much of this legislation. This is, we think, an unnecessary departure and is potentially setting the sort of precedent which should not be set. So we will be opposing the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You may be able to short-circuit this debate. Can I get an assurance from you, parliamentary secretary, that if a ballot does go ahead, such a statement would be circulated in the normal course of events? If I can get that assurance, then I will not proceed with the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am happy to give that assurance, Senator Bolkus, on advice from the AEC.
—Senator Bolkus, will you seek leave to withdraw that amendment?
—I seek leave to withdraw the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Clause 28, page 14 (after line 5), after subclause (1), insert:
(1A) A request under this section is a valid request only if:

PARA.TAB: (a) as near as practicable to 50% of the candidates in the proposed group are men; and
(b) as near as practicable to 50% of the candidates in the proposed group are women.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to try, as near as practicable, to ensure that 50 per cent of candidates in group voting tickets are women. This is always a difficult issue. I have not come across any parliamentarian who does not agree that the parliament should in fact be fully represented in the question of gender. But the electoral process, I am afraid, keeps delivering us a result which is not equivalent. What is under scrutiny, as a consequence of that, is the manner in which the major parties preselect women for winnable seats. It is to the credit of the Liberal Party that in the current parliament they have markedly improved the gender representation both in the lower house and in the Senate. We still have some way to go, but you are certainly making some progress.

The Democrats believe that, given the inequality of representation of women in parliament and in positions of power generally, women should be given encouragement to actively participate in this debate. Senators would be aware, as I am, of the historical situation whereby our original convention that set up the Federation actually had no women at all. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has promised to ensure a proper balance between men and women at the convention, and Senator Minchin has indicated his own preference for 50:50 representation in terms of the appointed delegates. We thank you for that commitment and we look forward to it being realised in fact.

We think we need to go further and legislate in this convention to ensure that women candidates are given appropriate exposure. There were no women at the Australasian federal conventions in the late 19th century. Women's representation in parliaments across Australia is an average of 20 per cent, which is regarded as pretty pathetic by all those with an eye both to what is moral and what is right.

The Australian Democrats do not support quotas. We do not use quotas in our own party. We clearly have not needed them. We would not support the implementation of quotas in this situation. But we do believe that requiring those setting up group voting tickets in the election to have half their candidates as women is one way to address gender inequality. I am aware that, during the second reading debate, persons such as Senator Neal did attack the intention that we are putting up and indicated that there is nothing to stop groups putting women at the bottom of the ticket in unwinnable positions.

We know that is possible but I happen to be a co‐patron of the Australian Republican Movement, along with Senator Eggleston and Senator Cook in Western Australia, and I happen to know that the ARM people will not be putting women in unwinnable positions and do not intend to allow that to happen. While Senator Neal, in theory may have a point, I am hopeful that she is wrong.

We could have advocated a quota. It is very difficult for the Democrats to do that in view of our own policy and our own attitude. Our objective in moving this amendment is not to use women but to respond to the very strong appeal that we have had from women in our constituency and from women outside our constituency—from all parties, incidentally—and from organisations such as the WEL organisation, the Women's Electoral Lobby.

We would like cross‐party support for this motion. There are some people who deliberately vote for women when and if they appear. We think they should be satisfied in the process. The Labor Party clearly have problems with the issue as outlined by Senator Neal, but I regret—and you would be aware of it, Senator Bolkus—that the ALP's record on the advancement of women in your party has been under strong attack. It is not too late to start to redress an unnecessary problem you have as a result of your history of not advancing women sufficiently in the electoral context. I would not like to think that the strains of chauvinism are still alive in the breast of the Labor Party. With those words, I would like to commend our amendment to the Senate. I will be interested in hearing the response to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not disagree with the aspiration of this proposal by the Australian Democrats. It is one that we are implementing both within the party and also quite rigidly in our participation in the tickets that will be put forward for this convention. In our involvement with the Republican Movement and with other parties, we are ensuring that there will be gender equality in the winnable positions to the extent that we can define such and, in that way, we will deliver on this.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Murray himself would acknowledge that this issue of representation should be broader than just women. We need to find ways of including and reflecting the diversity of our society in any representative body that is elected, and that is another principle that we will be looking at both in terms of indigenous Australians and also the multicultural diversity of our society.

This particular Democrat amendment does not in a practical way achieve that. I know the motivation and the aspiration may be there, but we all know that, under the particular proposal, if a team of 12 chose to put six females on the bottom half of their ticket, they would still satisfy the requirements of the Democrat amendment. We share with you the aspiration. We cannot see that your amendment will deliver the outcome you want.

We do think, in terms of representation, there should be a reflection of greater diversity. As I said yesterday, our amendment No. 82 is one that we believe is probably about as far as a parliament can go in terms of laying down a framework in this particular context, and that is the amendment that does talk about the need for the convention to be fully representative of the diverse experiences, backgrounds, views, beliefs and aspirations of the Australian people. We do reflect on the fact that the constitutional conventions of a hundred years ago were composed entirely of male delegates and we do say that we would wish that all groupings in this particular context would provide for fair but, more importantly, equal representation of women. I hope that you will be supporting our preamble to the bill later on. I also ask you to note that, though you may want something more, your amendment does not really deliver that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly make the point, Senator Bolkus, that, even if you went for half women and they were all on the bottom of the ticket, it would at least be the first time that half a ticket were women in your background and experience, and that would be an advance, although not as much as we would like.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time available, while sympathetic to the objectives of the Democrats, the government cannot support this amendment. We do not believe that it is appropriate to start regulating the composition of candidates' tickets. I point out that one of the effects of the Democrats' amendment would be to prevent and deny the possibility of an all‐female ticket. If a group wanted to put up 100 per cent females on the ticket, they could not do so under the Democrat amendment. They can under the bill as it stands. We are not prepared to accept the amendment or support it.
—If the Norwegian parliament can legislate for this sort of measure regarding the make-up of cabinet, we could do it for this convention. The Greens support the measure.
—The question is that the amendment be agreed to.
—I would like to ask that the vote of the Democrats and the Greens in support of the amendment be recorded on the voices please.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Wine Export Charge Bill 1997 and the Wine Export Charge (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly on the Wine Export Charge Bill 1997 and the Wine Export Charge (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997. This legislation was not just requested by the industry but actively sought by the industry. The purpose of it is to assist with the funding of export promotion for our Australian wines.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry has had this on its agenda for a couple of years. I wish to very briefly acknowledge today that, while there is overwhelming support within the industry, that support is not unanimous. There are some concerns from some of the smaller winemakers about the way in which some of the charges are to be levied. After my discussions with winemakers, they do acknowledge that the greatest beneficiaries of this are going to be the small winemakers. The bigger ones can basically look after themselves. They have chosen to stay in it but not at the same rate as some of the smaller ones will be paying. However, I want to stress here that it is only for exporters; it is for those people who are selling very good Australian wine overseas. The Democrats are fully supportive of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wine Export Charge Bill 1997 and the Wine Export Charge (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 seek to impose an industry levy on the wine industry. The purpose of the levy is to pay for the generic Australian wine promotion programs that support exports of Australian wine. Of course, there are already levies being charged on the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for urgency is that the government does not see fit to provide transitional funding to cover costs while this bill is being debated, so we will find it here in non-controversial legislation the second last week for passage prior to its intended starting date. We have not had it for a long time but we have been required to deal with it very quickly.

We have been told that the lack of the levy could cost the wine industry $50,000 per month to keep their infrastructure intact. The resources of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation are now exhausted to an extent that they will have to start borrowing to avoid losing what they have already done.

While we have agreed to expedite the legislation at the urging of many in the industry, it is not a non-controversial bill. That there should be a levy is not controversial. That it should be industry funded is not controversial. The controversy lies in the collection mechanism and, to some extent, the benefits derived by various classes of wine producer. The proposed collection mechanism is to place a levy on the value of the wine exported. This means that producers of more expensive wines will pay more per bottle exported regardless of how much wine they export, but of course it is per bottle.

Wine export promotion is fundamentally based on promoting the high quality of Australian wines. We have received substantial recognition for the quality of our premium wines. Not only the quality but also the diversity of premium wines builds our image as a producer of high quality wine. By enhancing the reputation of Australia as a wine producer, the identity as a producer of good wines spills over and allows increased exports of less expensive, lesser quality wines and bulk wines.

Since it is the premium, high quality wines that create the international identity that allows increased exports of all wine, it seems stupid to have a collection mechanism which is, in this sense, price based creating a disincentive for premium wines and an incentive for cheaper and bulk packed wines. A collection mechanism levied on a quantitative basis would be more beneficial for just the sorts of wines we are trying to promote overseas—the premium wines that build our reputation as a wine exporting nation.

The large wineries produce both premium wines and cheaper high volume wines. Small wineries produce almost exclusively premium wines. The skew in the levy favouring cheap wine is, therefore, a skew towards the big wine makers who also tend to dominate the various industry bodies. I am particularly aware of this skew since WA has almost no really large wine makers. Nearly all of our state industry falls in the category of small and medium producers. Their plight becomes more evident for this reason. I really am here speaking for small premium wine producers all over Australia—and there are a disproportionately high number of producers in my own home state.

The dissatisfaction over this ad valorem tax comes on top of the general dissatisfaction with the outcome of the wholesale sales tax issue from 1993. Wholesale sales tax is, of course, a price based tax which penalises higher priced wines. In the wine industry, the entire tax is price based, while in the other alcoholic beverages industry it is partially price based and partially based on alcohol content—a volume based measure. The smaller wineries felt that the interests of bulk suppliers of cheap wines were the winners of the 1993 debate, and calls for shifts to a volume basis were ignored in favour of the big players.

The collection mechanism for this levy is further problematic because there is a stepped arrangement. As the amount exported increases, the levy rate decreases. For the first $10 million worth of wine exported, the levy is $250 per million dollars exported. It drops to $200 per million dollars on 1 July next year. But for those exporting over $10 million of wine, the levy is $150 per million and that will drop to $100 per million next year. They have to pay the levy on the first $10 million at the same rate as the small exporters, but then the lower rate kicks in, giving them an overall lower rate of levy—one which gets effectively lower as the volume decreases. When the export volume reaches $50 million worth of exports, the levy drops to $50 per million dollars exported.

This system further favours the big players who are already favoured because they are the exporters of the cheaper, low cost, high volume cask wines. It allows distortions that mean some small winemaking organisations believe the three largest wine companies, who account for roughly two-thirds, or 66 per cent, to three-quarters, or 75 per cent, of exports, will only pay approximately 20 per cent of the total levy between them.

The collection mechanism is, therefore, of concern to the smaller wineries. The fact that they may only be paying $150 because their exports are only worth $½ million does not make the situation more equitable, just a little less painful. The levy is not meant to be a big tax. It is set up by the industry as a levy the industry feels happy with. The contributions of each small winery may seem minor, but in aggregate they are going to pay a disproportionate bulk of the levy. I will ask, therefore, that the minister give an undertaking, in the next review of this levy, to pay special attention to the equity of value based levies and consider volume based levies as an alternative or perhaps consider some sort of mixture of the two.

The second issue of concern to many of the small and medium wineries I have spoken to relates to the value of the services the levy funds. Many of the medium wineries believe they get little or no value and that the major beneficiaries are the big players. We know the big players also provide a lot of their own promotions. But they also benefit, I must say. Even if they are promoting the cheaper wines, they benefit from the prizes and the promotion that is done by the premium, low volume, high value wineries.

In fairness, I have also heard that some of the small wineries who are just trying to enter do feel the programs have been a positive benefit to them. But many of the established small and medium wineries are very active in promoting their own product. It was notable that as I called around recently nearly all the owners and senior managers of the wineries were overseas directly promoting their wines at various shows. The premium wineries do a lot of work that benefits all Australian wine exports at their own cost. Moreover, a number of the premium wineries expressed the opinion that their own work has resulted in their recognition and the establishment of growing niche markets for exports—and this has nothing to do with the promotion by the Wine and Brandy Corporation.

One medium winery in WA who exports several million dollars of wine each year expressed the view that, as a company, they get no benefit from the levy. They expressed their resentment of the injustice of the collection mechanism but in the end reluctantly agreed that they should probably support this levy going through. They did so on the basis that the promotion efforts, while of no benefit to them as a business, were of benefit to the industry and should be supported. We recognise this.

I found this attitude expressed over and over again. Very few small and medium wineries in WA seemed happy with the scheme—either its collection mechanism or its benefits to their business—and felt resentment at the flow of benefits to the bigger wineries. They did, in spite of this, feel it would be better to have the promotion schemes than to let them collapse.

I will therefore ask the minister, in the interest of justice, to ensure that the promotion schemes this levy will fund will substantially benefit the small and medium producers of premium wines. These are the people who will pay a disproportionate amount of the levy. These are the people on whose reputation, as makers of quality wines, our wines will rest. These are the people active in promoting their own products as exports at their own expense and this creates benefits for the entire sector. The promotion scheme should provide substantial benefits for all these people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all speakers in this debate for their help and assistance in getting something through that the industry itself wants. The government is introducing the charge at the request of the wine industry. They have had meetings about it and 94 per cent were in favour of this levy in 1996. I thank all speakers very much for supporting this levy, which is going to help an industry which is expanding very quickly. The industry is looking at about $2.5 billion in sales by the year 2025. It is one of the top industries in Australia that is really driving itself forward to exports.

SPEECH.PARA: Having listened to the speakers in the debate, I thank Senator Margetts for her cooperation. I also thank the Democrats, the Labor Party and the Independents for their cooperation. In developing the export promotion program, I will ask the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation to consider the special needs of small volume, high value exporters enunciated by Senator Margetts a moment ago.

As honourable senators are well aware, the continuation of the export charge is to be reviewed every five years to ensure that the arrangements are meeting their intended purpose. As part of the review, I believe it appropriate that one of the matters to be considered at that time is whether the ad valorem export charge is equitable and whether it should be converted to a volumetric basis, if it is to continue. I think this is going to give the industry a chance to meet the competition that they are going to face in the next few years out in the wide world from Chile, South Africa and other countries around the world. I thank all speakers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 is an omnibus taxation bill covering a wide area. Many of the measures in the bill are of an anti‐avoidance nature, specifically: the tightening of rules concerning capital losses to ensure no abuse can occur where the underlying beneficial ownership of the company group has changed; limiting withholding tax avoidance, including by broadening the general anti‐avoidance provisions, part 4A, to cover arrangements to avoid withholding tax; denying dual resident companies the benefits that they may inappropriately receive through being Australian resident companies; and, aligning the treatment of the leasing of luxury cars with the restricted depreciation regime applying to luxury cars.

SPEECH.PARA: These anti‐avoidance matters are all supported by Labor. Indeed, some of the issues dealt with in this legislation were announced by Labor in the last election campaign and stolen by the government—for example, the dual resident company provision. There is still much legislative and compliance tightening that needs to be achieved to ensure that the loopholes which higher income earners are taking unfair advantage of, are closed in order to provide the Australian government with its fair share of tax.

The repair of the tax base, the closing of loopholes and the pursuit of tax cheats is the kind of tax reform that should be undertaken by the government. Ordinary families are paying their fair share of tax and they should not be threatened by the introduction of a GST or other like new tax changes.

There are two other significant matters in the bill to which I will address some specific remarks: the reforms of the withholding tax provisions and the alteration of the standardised contribution rates for employer superannuation contributions. In regard to the withholding tax, the restructuring of the withholding tax exemption provisions provided for in this bill will allow Australian small businesses, home buyers and consumers to benefit from lower interest rates overseas. The exemptions from interest withholding tax which now apply for business funds are to be extended to other areas such as home mortgage finance and consumer finance.

These changes will have the effect of lowering the costs of accessing offshore finance for non‐business purposes. This should directly benefit lenders accessing offshore finance and also place further pres sure on the margins of local lenders ensuring an ongoing benefit to all borrowers.

Labor is a strong supporter of this measure, not because we agree automatically with government policies but rather because this legislation is enacting a Labor policy initiative. This measure was announced by Labor in the innovations statement of December 1995. Subsequently, in June 1995, the Treasurer, acknowledging Labor's position, proceeded with development of this proposal. An opportunity has also been taken to reform the anti‐avoidance tax regime concerning bearer debentures. Again, Labor does not oppose this provision.

In regard to superannuation, the bill proposes to remove, from 1997‐98, the option for employers to make standardised superannuation contributions on behalf of employees. This will generate savings of $35 million in 1997‐98 and $40 million in 1998‐99 and later years. It is being done to protect the PAYE tax base. Disproportionate deductions are not allowable for superannuation contributions. These are limited on an age basis which recognises that older employees may have greater needs than younger employees with respect to superannuation.

Labor introduced a simplified administration option for employers with more than 10 employees, whereby a standardised maximum level could be applied to all employees on whose behalf superannuation contributions are made. The bill proposes to eliminate this option for employers. We will not oppose this change but Labor does point out that, as a consequence of this change, the government is consciously imposing a higher compliance cost on small and medium sized businesses and reducing the superannuation benefits to be accrued for some employees.

With respect to reducing the superannuation benefits accrued for some employees, we do not argue with the fairness of that approach. However, I would point out the double standard we hear, particularly from the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, in this place, and from the government which pretends, and has indeed promised, to reduce red tape and administrative paperwork for small business, but is constantly increasing the compliance business on small business. This particular measure will certainly do that.
Generally, Labor believes this legislation package is appropriate and should be supported. We do so without moving amendment and we agree to a swift passage of the legislation.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the opposition for their support of these measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
