QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, I refer to the already immortalised Vanstone guarantee for 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds that you gave here in question time yesterday, when you said:

QUESTION.PARA: If a kid cannot get a place—
in training or education—
we will give them the youth allowance.
Do you stand by that guarantee, or do you, in your usual style, having made a brash statement, now wish to qualify it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, the question you asked me yesterday with respect to the youth allowance focused on the question of whether there was an adequate supply of training places for students to go into. It was a stupid question for you to ask. You had rightly pointed out to you—in fact, you were castigated for it—the failure of your government to so adequately reform the vocational training and education system as to ensure that there would be enough places. In fact, I think I reminded you about querying, after 13 years of Labor, the proposition that any child or kid who left school should be able to get a place, that there would be one there. That was, of course, a matter that you chose to deny and ignore.

ANSWER.PARA: The youth allowance is a means, among a number of other things, of ensuring that the incentives are there for students to go into education and training. If there are no training places available, of course they are going to be eligible for the youth allowance, but if their parents are earning $90,000 they are not going to get it. But will a child whose parents in a sense qualify get the youth allowance if they cannot find a training place? Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in answer to a similar question to the one I asked you yesterday, your junior minister, Dr Kemp, said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . if there is no education or training available, they—
That is, 16‐ and 17-year-olds—
will be able to access the youth allowance but they will be required to undertake . . . an activity agreement.
Minister, what precisely does that mean? What are the conditions 16‐ and 17-year-olds will have to meet? Why didn't you tell the Senate the whole truth yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet again I am embarrassed for the opposition.
—So are they.

—So were you yesterday, so you might as well admit that you are today. Senator, you know that unemployment benefits, as they were paid under your government, were subject to an activity agreement. The same will apply. Just go back to your own systems and you will understand. One does not simply pay out money without some requirement. There will be an activity agreement there.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Singapore, led by the Speaker of the parliament, Mr Tan Soo Kwoon. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate, and I trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I would propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mr Tan Soo Kwoon was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now for a sensible question about the youth allowance. My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. What has been the reaction to the government's new youth allowance and its restoration of incentives to study for young people? Have any incorrect claims been made about its impact on young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to get an intelligent question about this again. Intelligent questions seem to be coming from only this side of the chamber, unfortunately. You would think that, with the mess that was left in this area by the previous government, some elements in the Senate would be interested in asking intelligent questions. I suppose that, from the opposition, who are the ones who left the situation in such a mess, you would at least have expected some contrition.

ANSWER.PARA: They gave us the youth unemployment rates of over 30 per cent. They decimated the apprenticeship system, as we told you yesterday. They had a system whereby the young unemployed were being paid more than their peers who were studying. You would know that people who were needing income support faced a bewildering array of different payments—five different payments at 13 different rates. You would think that, with that record, Labor would really, in their heart of hearts at least, like to see the system cleaned up. No such luck. Instead, the ALP and the Democrats are peddling their usual scaremongering, mixed with complete inaccuracies.
For example, yesterday, in the other place, the member for Jagajaga, my shadow minister, said—

TALK.START.PARA: —She never gets anything right.

—She never gets anything right; she tries scaremongering instead. She said that students are going to face an increase in their rents as a result of this government's miserly approach to rent assistance. What is the truth?
—It's a dorothy dixer; keep reading the answer.

—Perhaps, Senator, you should listen so you will learn. The previous government paid not one cent of rent assistance to students. We are the first government to offer students up to $100 a fortnight to help pay their rent. Their housing costs will fall, not rise.

ANSWER.PARA: The member for Jagajaga has also claimed that 16‐ to 18-year-olds not in full-time education have been abandoned. Once again, that is absolute rubbish. People unable to find a space will be exempted. She said that they would have no help looking for a job. That is also wrong. All 15‐ to 20‐year‐olds are eligible for access to labour exchange services irrespective of whether they are on income support. Listen and learn.

Let us turn to Senator Kernot. She could not be bothered to come to question time. It is a pity she did not come to learn. She said yesterday on AM that a family on $30,000 with a student child would lose under the youth allowance—completely false. Students are already subject to a parental means test. Their benefits are going up and the parental means test ceiling is going up from $37,000 to $41,000 and higher for the bigger families. Senator Kernot also said that a family earning $35,000 a year with a 16‐year‐old at home would get an allowance of $10 a week. Again, that is completely false. They will actually receive $16.50 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —She didn't care.

—She did not care. Anything went. In fact, they will have no change in their current circumstances as under 18‐year‐olds are currently subject to the Austudy parental means test. Bag first, ask questions later: a highly irresponsible tactic for Senator Kernot to indulge in.

BREAK.PARA: There is a lot more you could say about this. I feel that the opposition parties have a vested interest in trying to stir up young people who do not have access to these facts, but it is mischievous to make their press releases and public statements utterly untrue. It is quite unfair to the young.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust that Senator Stott Despoja will fax to Senator Kernot the answer that Senator Newman has just given. My supplementary question is: does the minister have any other examples of the benefits of the youth allowance? In particular, what has the editorial comment been in relation to the youth allowance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to say that the editorial writers have been pretty sympathetic to the reform process of the government. Let me point out to you the Financial Review article, `Get the young back to work'. What does it say?

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much interjection in the chamber. Senators on my left will cease interjecting.
—The Financial Review says:

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Government's decision to ditch the dole for under‐18s and tighten access to benefits for 18 to 21-year-olds should be vigorously applauded.
The changes announced . . . by Senator . . . Newman are weighed towards solid Australian values of responsibility and hard work.

They force all but the poorest parents to take greater financial responsibility for their offspring. And they close a bizarre gap which has financially encouraged the young to be unemployed rather than to study and given students greatly increased access to rent assistance.

There is a whole lot more that one should read, and I commend it to the Senate. Look at the Herald‐Sun , `An incentive to learn more'; the Sydney Morning Herald , `Without dole, responsibility'; and, best of all, `The drinks aren't on taxpayers'. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. Minister, can you confirm that an unemployed young adult aged 19 and living at home in a family with a total income of $36,000 a year—that is, only $36,000 a year—will lose $121.10 a fortnight under your youth allowance? How on earth is a family in that situation going to make up for the shortfall? Is that what the Prime Minister meant when he said on 27 February this year that his government would provide: `a decent safety net, for those in the community who are less fortunate'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it nice to have another question about this major social policy reform? The senator has obviously forgotten that the means test ceiling for Austudy students that her government introduced was $37,000. So are you particularly concerned about the families who are earning $36,000?
—She doesn't understand.

—She does not understand at all. The means test ceiling for these families whether their children are unemployed or are students is going up to $41,000 if there is one child at home in the family and several thousand more for each child in the family. There will be a family income ceiling of up to $58,000 if there is one child living away from home and several thousand more for each child.

ANSWER.PARA: I wonder why it is that we are getting these crocodile tears from the opposition about young unemployed people who are now being treated in exactly the same way as their government treated the students. That is absolutely true. The difference is that this government is making sure that we bring the eligibility for students up to the level of the young unemployed. What is unfair about that?

BREAK.PARA: I know that some of the opposition parties have been proposing that the government should be providing pocket money, milkshakes, lollies and trips to the pictures from the taxpayer. I just draw your attention to the editorial in the Daily Telegraph today, the second positive editorial from this organ for the last two days. It says:
There is a fundamental mistake in many Australians' thinking about the role of government, and it was repeated yesterday by Cheryl Kernot.
Senator Kernot, Leader of the Australian Democrats, apparently believes it is the duty of government to pay for everything from the army to a night at the pictures.
The editorial says:
It is the responsibility of families and individuals to earn their luxuries. Provision of lollies should not be part of the welfare safety net, certainly not to adults and near‐adults.
But many still believe—
and obviously the Labor Party do—
Australia to be the land of milkshakes and movies for all, whether they are earned or not.
This is a significant problem for a nation reluctant to come to terms with the fact that there aren't the resources to do this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like an answer to my question, yes or no, with regard to $36,000 a year and whether or not they will lose $121.10 a fortnight under the youth allowance. Do you seriously expect families on incomes of $36,000 a year with children under the age of 21, or anyone else for that matter, to believe that the youth allowance is a decent safety net for them if their kids cannot get the jobs they need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The same thing applies for families supporting a student for up to five years, not some months, as is the case with an unemployed young person. The burden that is on families to support their student children is very much greater in that it is longer and often more expensive. So I find it hypocritical in the extreme for these games to be played, absolutely hypocritical. I have learned from being in this chamber long enough to never trust a detail that is provided by the opposition. The chances are their facts are wrong. Let us get you checked out.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Senator Parer. The Federation of Automotive Product Manufacturers has released details showing a significant rise in the value of automotive exports resulting in Australian components now being used in a surprisingly wide range of cars around the world. Can the minister tell the Senate how the coalition government's recent decision on the future automotive policy will assist this developing market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Ferguson very much for that question. Coming from South Australia, he has a keen interest in the automotive industry. Yes, I am aware of recent reports that have shown that export earnings for the industry are forecast to grow to approximately $6 billion by the year 2005. Overall, automotive exports now represent four per cent of manufacturing exports and two per cent of total Australian exports. The forecast growth up to 2005 of just over $2 billion continues the strong growth trend we have seen to date and represents a threefold increase in the 1996 export figures. It demonstrates a very strong commitment within the automotive industry to develop export markets and capture export opportunities. I would also like to note that, according to a recent statement made by the Federation of Automotive Product Manufacturers:

ANSWER.PARA: The government's recently announced auto industry policy has given the green light for the export of 180,000 cars by the year 2005 with matching component exports expected to reach $3 billion. In total, automotive exports will amount to as much as $8 billion per year by the middle of the next decade.

In its automotive decision announced on 5 June, the government announced the framework for an automotive trade development strategy. Key initiatives of the strategy include the establishment of a new automotive trade council, the appointment of a specialist trade access negotiator, a market development package worth $20 million over four years and the development of a WTO consistent program to replace the current export facilitation scheme when it expires in the year 2000.

BREAK.PARA: When the government reached its decision on the new policy arrangements for the car industry we did so with two objectives in mind. Firstly, we addressed the need to keep the decision consistent with the APEC commitments and, secondly, we addressed the need to secure the next round of industry investment. The decision announced by the Prime Minister earlier this month is wholly consistent with both of these objectives. It puts in place a mechanism which reduces tariffs by more than 50 per cent over the next eight years and with the full support of the industry it creates certainty in the investment environment.

With the government's commitment to continuing reform I am confident the Australian car industry will be well placed to lead the region into the next century. Unlike the opposition, we did not flip‐flop our way to a great mistake. We developed a pragmatic approach which secures the best of both worlds. Tariff reform and securing industry investment are not inconsistent goals. This decision clearly shows that the government's industry policy is based on a clear understanding of what Australian industry needs in the run‐up to the year 2000.

It is worth noting what Labor did during its period in government. In 1984, shortly before Labor came into office, car production in Australia stood at 370,000 units. When it left in 1996 production was 314,000 units. Nissan had closed down production and Australia had lost the capacity to produce small cars such as the Ford Laser. Under Labor, employment in the industry declined from 70,000 to 45,000. What a record—totally indicative of 13 years of Labor mismanagement.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Goods and Services Tax: Petrol Prices

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, do you agree with comments by your colleague, prominent Liberal backbencher Mr Bob Charles, that replacing the fuel excise tax with a GST would not deliver lower petrol prices for consumers as petrol in Australia is `not expensive by world standards'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —This is in the wider context of a debate which is occurring in the wider community on tax reform and in which people are putting forward a variety of views. I notice even in the Labor Party people are putting forward a variety of views. The shadow Treasurer, Mr Gareth Evans, thinks that there is room for taxes to rise in this country. That is one of his views. Lindsay Tanner, another Young Turk in the Labor Party, has felt that we should be looking at an expenditure tax and at broadening the tax base. There are a variety of views which are being put forward.

ANSWER.PARA: I guess the difference between our party and the Labor Party is that when people put forward views we do not regard them as treachery, which is what happens when Labor Party members and senators put forward views. As I said, Mr Charles can put forward views and he will obviously have to justify those views.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you obviously know nothing about fuel excise taxes in Australia, but can you give an example of any OECD country where petrol prices have fallen on the introduction of a GST or like tax such as a VAT?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give you some examples of where petrol prices have risen because of the increases in excise tax. Do you remember, under the Keating government, that excise taxes on fuel rose from 7c or 10c a litre to over 30c a litre?

—I rise on a point of order. My point of order goes to relevance. The question was clearly directed at Senator Kemp's knowledge—or apparent lack of it—about the introduction of GSTs or VATs in any economy and the reduction in prices of petrol. We have had enough waffle from this minister. He should be pulled back to the point, and he should answer the question.
—I draw your attention to the question, Senator Kemp.

—Thank you, Madam President. I make the point that this was not a question about government policy. The question was to do with excise, and I was pointing out what happened to fuel excise under the Keating government. With your record, Senator Sherry, I am amazed that you have the cheek to get up and raise that question.
—I rise on a point of order.
—Senator Kemp, have you finished answering that question?
—Yes, I have.
—I raise a point of order on a point of relevance.
—I think the matter is concluded.
—It is a point of order, and you have not heard it yet, Madam President.
—The minister has completed answering his question.
—I rose to my feet before he concluded his answer. You have not heard the point of order yet, Madam President. My point of order is that this is very relevant to the National Party.
—That is a matter you can take up in taking note of answers, Senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Yesterday you rejected concerns raised by Lifeline in Brisbane that cutting the dole for young adults will place stress on families. Here are some quotes from the Reverend Wayne Sanderson, the Director of Lifeline in Brisbane. He says:

QUESTION.PARA: Forcing unemployed young people to be financially dependent on their families is a contrived dependency sticking families together with artificial glue.

He also said your policy will reinforce the negative self‐image some young people have of themselves. He said you have `hung out young people to dry'. Will you admit that your draconian policy will cause great misery for families and for the young adults that you are treating like children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I do rather despair of some of the friends of the Democrats. It is a pity that Lifeline does not take trouble with the detail of the government's social policy reform—or that you do not take the trouble to help them, Senator. It is quite clear that, where young people are truly independent, they will not be parentally means tested and, therefore, they will not be in the position you have described. Where young people are homeless, where they have no parental support, there are a number of safety net criteria which will apply to them. Clearly, the spokesman for Lifeline has been responding in ignorance. It would, perhaps, have been better if you had—
—He's probably not a subscriber to the Financial Review .

—Maybe they have better access to the information, Senator. It is a shame for Lifeline to be putting their reputation on the line when they are quite clearly basing their statements on inaccuracies and a lack of knowledge of the total picture.

ANSWER.PARA: This government consulted widely before this decision was taken. The criteria that the welfare organisations wanted to see included to protect the vulnerable and to look after those who were independent were taken on board and included. To bear witness to that, I draw your attention to the press release I referred to yesterday, put out by the Brotherhood of St Laurence. If the Democrats and your Lifeline spokesman are not prepared to accept my word, perhaps they would be prepared to accept the words of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, who have studied the material, who have worked with the government to end up with the reform we have produced and who say that it is a much needed reform which goes the way they want it to. They were very pleased with the results of the consultative process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Minister, thank you for your reply. I am sure the director of Lifeline will be glad to hear what you have said and will probably reply to you himself, as he has great experience in this area. However, it is interesting that you choose to quote editorials selectively. I ask if you agree with this quotation from an article—headed `Dole Cuts No Solution to Jobs Crisis'—in the Courier‐Mail :

QUESTION.PARA: Forcing young people to remain in an academic environment in which they will struggle is not the answer. It may be less about improving their job prospects and more about keeping them out of unemployment statistics for a little longer.
Do you agree with the Courier‐Mail editorial?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am convinced that unemployment is not the future for our young people, and none of us in this place would want it to be. I am also convinced that simply providing income support is no solution. Young people need jobs, first of all. Secondly, they need skills development, so that they are eligible for those jobs and able to take them up where they are offering. Quite clearly, the integrated reforms which Dr Kemp and I have now introduced are going to make a difference to those young people. The grade 9 and 10 students who are leaving school without skills are going to be the most disadvantaged young unemployed in this country. The measures which Dr Kemp is putting in in terms of vocational education, TAFE places, and school based traineeships in place of apprenticeships—and other traineeships—will all make a difference in getting young people off the dole and into work. (Time expired)

—I address my question to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Can you confirm that callers to the government's Austudy hotline were left waiting for an average of 49 minutes during January and that the waiting period for reviews is still three months or longer? What steps have you taken to ensure that your government will do better than this in administering the actual means test which will now apply to unemployed 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reynolds, this is another question from the past. We dealt with this matter in February. I do not know if you were in the chamber then, perhaps you were on holidays. We dealt with it in March. We clearly indicated that the Austudy hotline was inadequately staffed and the waiting time was clearly inappropriate.

ANSWER.PARA: Numerous figures have been tabled at a variety of estimates committees, not just in the last round but in the round before. For those who are slow learners, they had to ask again. I think that is right. Here you are, asking it yet again.

Let me repeat what has been outlined on a number of occasions for your benefit, Senator Reynolds, and for the benefit of anyone else who has not yet cottoned on. Yes, the Austudy hotline was understaffed. Yes, that problem was attended to and the staffing was very substantially increased. Holds, waiting periods, et cetera on the hotline now are down to a minimum.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's a minimum?

—I cannot give you the exact minutes or proportions of minutes, but it is really not very much at all. Senator Reynolds, therefore, I think you will find that the lesson was learnt—that is, if there is to be a hotline in relation to Austudy, or the youth allowance, as it is now, then the hotline has to be appropriately staffed, otherwise people are kept unnecessarily waiting.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it true that your own department's performance report of the student assistance centres has found that as many as 40 per cent of centres have failed to meet the national benchmark standards for response to inquiries and that this has meant that around 40 per cent of calls have not been answered promptly? Have you spoken to your parliamentary secretary, Mr Abbott, about this appalling performance? How will you personally guarantee that this situation will not be repeated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reynolds, let me repeat it for you. The calls have not been answered in an appropriate time and I believe the department is appropriately attending to that. I think the figures that have been released so far indicate that, with respect to the hotline in particular, there has been a very dramatic improvement.

BREAK.PARA: Do I speak to Mr Abbott regularly? Yes. Was he concerned that the hotline was not appropriately staffed in the beginning? Yes, of course he was. Did he help to fix that problem? Yes, of course he did. I speak to him every week in my regular meeting on Thursday morning. I tell you what: I will mention to him next Thursday morning that you have an added concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy—and I believe he will be the next environment minister temporarily. What measures will your government take to assure that the integration of electricity provision under a national electricity market system does not result in the increased sale and use of cheaper Victorian brown coal of low thermal value, with the result that economic competition means we displace less polluting black coals or less damaging fuels in favour of dirty coal further increasing our greenhouse emissions and the damage to our environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Margetts is suggesting that we shut down the Yallourn coalfields and all the power stations in Victoria. That seems to be what her proposal is.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say that one of the great advancements in recent years on this by all sides of politics has been the deregulation in the electricity market, because what will flow to the economy and also to the households is a reduction in the cost of electricity. Also, I might tell you this, Senator Margetts—and it is something you should be very interested in—it will also mean overall a reduction in the gas emissions from the electricity industry itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—I will tell you exactly how, if you will listen. The reason is that, under deregulation, we are having gridding between the various states. So you have gridding between South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. Some of these were a little difficult to achieve, I might tell you. But having achieved it, it means we will no longer have a situation where states react to an undersupply by creating an oversupply. As it now stands there is, as I understand it, some oversupply in Victoria and some oversupply in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: With the gridding pack coming into Queensland, this will postpone the need to build more power stations. One of the things that is important for a power station is that, if a power station operates at full load, full efficiency—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President. My point of order is relevance. I am just hoping the entire answer will not be about grids, but that the minister will talk about the displacement of less polluting black coals in favour of dirty coal.
—There is no point of order.

—As I was saying, what is happening is that the gridding pattern means that power stations operate more efficiently and it postpones the building of new power stations—which would have occurred if there had not been the deregulation of the electricity industry. To use your words, Senator Margetts, I think you said the polluting black coals—
—Less polluting black coals.
—The majority of the coals that supply power into New South Wales and Queensland are the so-called black coals. In Victoria and South Australia they use the younger brown coals.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Margetts, I am not sure what you are suggesting, but there is no doubt that, with the deregulation of the market, the net effect will be—and this is important—a reduction in costs, except I might say in New South Wales. When the silly New South Wales government gets a reduction in the costs to the consumer and the industry, it puts a darn tax on it. That was never the intent of the deregulation of the industry.

What we want this to do is make Australia more competitive in regard to electricity industries. It will attract more industry into Australia and it will provide more jobs. That is the major purpose of it, apart from the fact that it will also lead to a reduction in costs to householders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister says he is not sure what I am suggesting, and that is becoming quite obvious. Will the department of resources and energy work actively and systematically to attempt to meet our greenhouse obligations through establishing mechanisms to internalise externalities—particularly environmental costs—so the market will reflect real costs, not just the short-term dollar costs, of damaging practices? If not, how will it work in a significant way to meet our obligations so householders will not have to pay more in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The department of resources and energy is very much involved in something which Senator Margetts should know about. If she does not, it is a thing called the greenhouse challenge.

ANSWER.PARA: The greenhouse challenge is a voluntary agreement between industry and government over time to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. It is something that is growing very rapidly, and there are a number of reasons for it. In the process, the companies and industry organisations are able to show that they are reducing greenhouse gas emissions. They are also showing that they are becoming more efficient, and the bottom line is they are also saving money. To use a term that was used in the past by quite a lot of people, it really will be a win‐win‐win situation because the net result will be that you will have lower greenhouse gas emissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no we're not. Not from what we have got now. Tell the truth.
—What Senator Margetts is now suggesting is that she does not want any growth in the Australian economy and she does not want jobs to be provided for the unemployed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, yesterday you proclaimed to the Senate, `There can be no bigger indictment of a government and their efforts to keep young Australians employed than their letting the apprenticeship and traineeship system fall into decline.' How then do you explain the decline in the number of apprenticeships by 1,000 in the last year? How do you explain that the growth in the number of traineeships has declined from 117 per cent in the last year of the Labor government to only 32 per cent in the last year under this coalition government? Doesn't your government stand indicted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly not, Senator. You perhaps have not had the opportunity to see a media release put out by Dr Kemp in the middle of May this year in which he highlights—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, it is old news; but let us come back to it.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much interjecting on my left.

—Thank you, Madam President. It is old news, but apparently your side have not cottoned on to it. That is often the case with good news; you do not want to know about it. Let me run through what Dr Kemp had to say.
—He's undermining you.

—I will not read it word for word. He indicated that the federal government is going to provide $265 million for more than 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships in 1997-98. They are going to be in high growth industries such as technology, finance, tourism, hospitality and sport and the traditional trades, in which you were happy to have them continuing. The funding is part of $415 million in 1997-98 for the new apprenticeship system. We are expanding career options and opportunities for the 60 per cent of students not going on to full-time university or TAFE. He went on to indicate the government's intention, and that is that the new national apprenticeship system will provide trainees with world-class skills, giving Australian businesses a competitive edge in the global economy. Presumably you under stand, Senator Childs, by the tone of your question, that human resource development—
—Tell us about his campaign undermining you? When will he get your job?

—You will get your chance. Why don't you put a button in it and wait until you have another chance. Put a button in it and you will get your chance. Keep working hard and maybe in 10 years, when you are an old man, you will come back on this side of the chamber. But right now I am trying to concentrate on an answer to a question from a senator from your side. I thought you would be interested and courteous enough to let him have the answer—but courtesy is a lot to expect from you, I suppose.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Kemp goes on to point out that the federal government will provide a total of more than $1.3 billion for vocational education and training in 1997-98. He goes on to point out that in the calendar year 1998, $891 million will be provided for TAFE and other training providers through the Australian National Training Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a cut. Why don't you tell the truth?
—Senator Carr, you have been persistently interjecting.
—Madam President, I think the relevant standing order is 203(e), and sooner or later you are going to be invited to use it.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Seeing that you are being referred to the standing orders, I ask you to refer the minister to the standing order that requires her to answer the question that I have asked.
—It would be different if anyone were listening to it.
—I was listening.
—It is not apparent.

—Thank you very much, Madam President; although I indicate to you that the standing order I was referring to is 203(e). It does sometimes get a bit much. If they do not want to hear the answer—they are not usually interested in answers; they only want to ask questions—I am happy to sit down. But, if they want to listen to the answer, I am happy to give it to them.
—We can read Kemp's press release.
—Why didn't you?

—Good point, Senator Patterson. If you can read it, why didn't you? You would have then had all this information at hand. Other features for the 1997-98 package include $50 million to expand vocational education in secondary schools, very important for years 9 and 10; $24 million for the new national network of one-stop shop apprenticeship shops, they are the shops that will allow employers and people who want to be apprentices to get the whole matter dealt with at once instead of running between different bureaucracies; $20 million to help disadvantaged unemployed people into apprenticeships; $16 million to support increased apprenticeships on a regional basis; and $14 million to increase the number of apprentices in group training. Senator, you specifically referred to some figures. If you want to give them to me, I will give you a comment on them when I have had a look at what you put before me.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Isn't it true that 53 Qantas apprentices who were sacked by Qantas last month are part of this fall in the number of apprenticeships. Why is it that, despite the government's pledges to help, only two of the 53 have been found permanent work in the airline industry? What do you and Mr Howard, who is off on his Qantas cricketing tour, have to say about these apprentices? Will you answer my specific question about the 1,000 apprenticeships that have been lost?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice you do not refer to what I told you yesterday about the deplorable state that you left the vocational education and training system in. I notice you do not refer to the numbers of apprentices being almost the same as they were 10 years before, after 13 years of Labor government— the worst in three decades. Frankly, Senator, you kid yourself. I will make some inquiries about how we are going with the Qantas apprentices and I will get back to you on that as well. But I repeat: if you want to give me the figures that you are quoting from, I will have a look at them. But, if you think that I am going to answer a question about some figures that you have just put before me when I have not had a chance to look at them and verify them, I am sorry, Senator, you are mistaken.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Will the minister inform the Senate of the steps that the government is taking to protect the dugong in the southern Great Barrier Reef region of Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, as you know, the Howard government has a very strong record on nature conservation, and it made further decisions last weekend with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Council which will, we believe, be a turning point for the dugong in the southern Great Barrier Reef region.

ANSWER.PARA: I have previously informed the Senate of the alarming decline in dugong numbers in the southern Great Barrier Reef region. This animal is one of the values for which the Great Barrier Reef was listed under the world heritage convention. We therefore have a responsibility to protect the dugong, yet numbers have fallen between 50 and 80 per cent over the last decade. Unlike the ALP, which was of course in government during that period, the Howard government is committed to taking action to rescue the dugong. While there are several threats to its survival, the greatest threat appears to be associated with the use of mesh nets in commercial fishing operations.

The Senate will recall that I took decisive action last year to protect the dugong by banning mesh netting in Shoalwater Bay, which has one of the healthiest dugong populations in the region. Last weekend the Great Barrier Reef Marine Council agreed that further action had to be taken. The council agreed that mesh netting must be banned in other dugong sanctuaries. The ministerial council also agreed that, where individual fishermen are affected by closures, compensation should be considered. The decision was taken after extensive consultation and careful consideration.

The ministerial council will meet again in two months to finalise the boundaries of the areas in which mesh netting is to be banned and the appropriate industry adjustment compensation mechanism. The ministerial council will also consider proposals for further action on other threats to the dugong, including measures to protect seagrasses.

Unlike the ALP, this government will work cooperatively with the states and with other stakeholders, and that is exactly what we are doing in this instance. We recognise that most fishermen wish to protect the dugong—in fact, I acknowledge the efforts of the fishing industry to develop its own strategy. However, scientific evidence indicated that, if we were to protect the animal, the only option available to us in these very specific areas is to ban the mesh nets. We will work through the adjustment and compensation issues with the industry over the next couple of months in an open and transparent way.
The action we have taken to protect the dugong has been welcomed by the conservation movement. The Queensland Conservation Council has stated:
It is probably the greatest step forward for conservation in the Great Barrier Reef since its World Heritage listing.
Also interestingly, the broader community recognises the need to protect this unique mammal. Sunfish, the association representing recreational anglers, has praised our decision.

The steps we are taking to protect the dugong represent a win for the environment. Because this government does things in a responsible manner, affected fishermen will also be looked after. We are protecting the environment for the whole community, for present and future generations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Just for clarification: I take it, therefore, that nothing will be done without compensation for commercial fishermen and that the minister intends to consult with those commercial fishermen in the process of putting the compensation package together.

—We believe that there should be compensation. The limitations will relate to only the endorsement on their licences for gill netting in these specific areas. As a matter of interest, there are not many fishermen involved and also their take from those gill nets in these specific areas is not very great. But, to the extent that they are regular fishermen who have been earning a living from those gill nets, we believe the public should pay compensation to them because the decision that is being taken is to protect those values for the benefit of the whole community. So, yes, we look forward to working with fishermen, who have been cooperative in this effort, to find an amicable and fair resolution of the compensation issue over the next two months.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, I refer to a letter I have from Mr Howard dated one week before the last federal election in which he says:

QUESTION.PARA: The coalition is committed to maintaining current levels of funding in the human services area covering family resource centres.

Is it true that, since Mr Howard won the election on this and a multitude of other broken and discarded election promises, he has terminated funding for the Ipswich Family Resource Centre and for 10 other centres under the family resource centre program? Isn't it true in fact that, far from maintaining current levels of funding, he has slashed over $2 million from the program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are something like seven or—

—Ten or 11. Of course, I represent Minister Moylan on this issue. It is the family services minister's responsibility. Nevertheless, this issue was canvassed somewhat extensively at estimates, and I would have thought the opposition could not milk another single tear out it.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation is that the funding for something like 11 centres around Australia is now being focused on 200 centres around Australia—much more representative of the nation. I think the 10 or 11 family resource centres were in virtually the eastern states of Australia. Western Australia, Tasmania and I think the ACT as well did not have any of these centres, which were basically the middlemen in putting services available in the community together with people who may need the services. These centres had a coordinating role, if you like, but were not a provider of services.

So what the government has decided to do is in fact to use a substantial part of that money in providing help to 200 youth centres around the country which may have adolescents who need assistance or parents who need assistance with their adolescents. That is an important issue when we all recognise that adolescence is a time when young people and their parents often do not see eye to eye. Where there is a need for field officers, for instance, to help parents and young people work together to achieve reconciliation, that is obviously a very worthwhile family initiative. In difficult economic times, this government has decided that it is better to make sure that that assistance goes to 200 places in Australia, a lot of them in rural and regional Australia. Most of them were getting no assistance whatsoever from the family resource centres.

That was canvassed, as I say, pretty widely in the estimates. I am very glad to have the opportunity to give the whole of the Senate the benefit of that information, which I think is a very worthwhile change of direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I know where the money has gone, but I have a letter here from Mr Howard making a commitment that the funds were not going to be cut. Isn't this a prime example of Mr Howard blatantly misleading the Ipswich Family Resource Centre and centres elsewhere in order to gain their votes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it hardly becomes the senator to make those sorts of imputations. This government clearly is concerned about family issues—

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections throughout the chamber. Senators will not shout across the chamber at each other.

—The noise that comes from the other side of the chamber is designed to obfuscate the issue that is basic to this whole matter, and that is that 13 years of Labor government left Australia with a $10 billion deficit which had to be rectified by this government, and by the next budget this country will be in surplus. If that is not the best thing you can possibly do for Australia's families, I do not know what is. The family tax initiative is vitally important to Australia's families. The rebate for health insurance is important for Australia's families. Over and over again I can go through child‐care measures that are going to be better for Australia's families—as I said yesterday, there is out of school hours care assistance, which they did not get under your government.

ANSWER.PARA: This is practical assistance for reconciliation between parents and adolescents. There cannot be any higher measure in terms of family need, surely, to make sure that those break‐ups do not occur. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, I refer to the government's plans to introduce a common youth allowance. I ask: how many additional young people aged between 16 and 18 do you expect to return to or to stay in secondary schools as a consequence of this measure, and what effect will this have on school enrolments over the next five years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Allison for the question. I do not know how many young Australians will continue to stay in school or who, instead of staying in school, will move from school to some sort of vocational training. But this much I can tell you: I am very happy about every extra child who stays in school or goes into training instead of leaving school to go on the dole, hoping to get a job.

ANSWER.PARA: So, if that is the consequence, every one that you add up that does that we are very happy about, because every child that stays longer at school or goes into vocational training has a much better chance of a much less bleak future than they would have if they were on the dole—a much better chance of a less bleak future. No doubt you are concerned about funding for schools; that is your concern. You might understand that there is school funding on a per capita basis, so, frankly, we do not understand the nature of your problem.

But, while we are on the question of the youth allowance and the opportunities that it creates for young Australians—that is, greater incentives for education and training—I might ask you, and you could address it in some supplementary question you might want to put to me, whether you endorse the comments of your colleague Senator Woodley, supported by your leader Senator Kernot and by Senator Margetts, which go to an all‐time low in Australian politics of suggesting that an incentive for education and training will in fact lead to increased youth suicides.

I ask whether you are prepared to stand behind Senator Woodley, Senator Kernot and Senator Margetts in that respect. As you will understand, the allegation is made that Australia has a very high level of youth suicide. It is a very sad situation when young people choose to take their lives; and, when they do so, a part of the cause, I imagine, is despair as to their future. One way to build a better future—
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise in the chamber is far too high. People should stop interjecting.

—Senator Woodley is giving you a hint there, waving a bit of paper. One way to increase the opportunities for a better future, to increase the positive outlook that young Australians have, is to create the right incentives for education and training. The comments of Senators Woodley, Margetts and Kernot in that respect are, in my view, pretty disgraceful.

ANSWER.PARA: This government is putting an additional $19 million into a youth suicide prevention strategy. When you add that to the $13 million that was already there from the previous government—they also acknowledged it as a problem—you come up with a $31 million strategy seeking to address five key aspects: supporting research into the complex causes of youth suicide; increasing access to early intervention programs for parents; increasing access to counselling and telephone support; placing increased emphasis on the needs of families and young people in rural areas; and, last but certainly not least, training professionals and improving the reporting of suicide by the media.

I very much hope, Senator, that the remarks made by your colleagues and Senator Margetts, in order to get themselves a headline, associating themselves with youth suicide, do not in fact work on some autocue basis. I am not suggesting that that is what would happen. I do realise that research indicates that you cannot say there is a direct causal link. But there is certainly research that indicates that when reporting of suicide goes up it might in fact be in line with an increase in suicides.

If your party is genuinely concerned about youth suicide, then you will be genuinely concerned about making sure that young Australians, instead of leaving school early and going on the dole, have an incentive when they do leave school, having stayed there for as long as they could, to go straight into education and training, because there is no better way to build them a chance of a real job and a brighter future. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the minister acknowledge that, for some of these young people, full-time education will not be their first choice and that they will stay on in schools just to qualify for the new youth allowance? If so, do you acknowledge that this will create additional problems and costs for many schools? Will the government provide extra funds to address the specific needs of these students?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you rightly highlight one of the problems with Australian schools, and that is, they are far too focused on the outcomes for students who will go to university and they do not give enough attention and focus to the 75 per cent who will not. That is another debate we could have. If you ask people what is a good school, often they will use the example of a very wealthy school like Senator Stott Despoja went to. They say, `This percentage of year 12 students went to university,' without focusing on all the other kids.

ANSWER.PARA: If, Senator, you are telling me, in your question, that the schools are not catering for these other children, then your message is not to me but to the schools. You go back to the schools and you tell them to lift their game and start offering real opportunities to the 75 per cent of students who do not want to go to university. Give them real opportunities. Take that back to your teaching union and tell them that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), to a question without notice asked by Senator Childs today, relating to apprenticeships.

As a tradesman, I asked a question about apprentices from Qantas, who are members of my union, the AMWU. The problems that they face are typical of the problems that young people, apprentices and trainees face in this country.

BREAK.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has flown away from his responsibility to solve the problems of young people—of apprentices and trainees. He has left the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) here today to answer questions.

I asked a question about the decline in apprenticeship positions by 1,000 last year, and the minister does not know about it. Even though there was an article on this in the Daily Telegraph at the beginning of this week, this minister did not know about it. She is going to get an answer, like the other answers she has been going to get. She has a record of being the second slowest minister in a very slow ministry. She cannot answer questions relating to areas with which she is directly involved.

The case of the 53 Qantas apprentices is a symptom of the problems that we have in this country at the present time. The minister is capable of quoting her junior minister in the gobbledegook we heard today but she is not capable of answering a specific question when she is the minister who has responsibility.

There is a mean spirit in the land. The mean spirit starts with the Prime Minister and his ministers, and it is beginning to permeate society. Already, some of the largest corporations are infected. You see it in what Qantas has done with its apprentices. At Newcastle in my state of New South Wales, BHP, one of the largest companies in Australia, is being irresponsible in threatening employment. This is happening at a time when the Prime Minister, who also comes from my state, is leading us overseas on a cricketing tour. Unemployment has gone up in New South Wales from 7.7 per cent at the time of the last election to 8.3 per cent. That is an example of what is happening in my state, with an absent Prime Minister and with a minister who cannot address the issues that we face.

The significance of the question I asked is that the minister does not know the information that was given by her officers at the estimates committee. The figures were given by her officers at meetings at which she was sitting. She just is not in touch. She was sitting at the meetings but she does not know the figures.

Unfortunately, she has left the chamber. I hope she is looking up the estimates records that will show that the figures which I put in my question to her are based, quite properly, on figures that were divulged by her own officers. Those figures cannot be hidden any longer. This government is betraying young people, betraying the victims of its own policies, and the figures cannot be denied.

No amount of bluster can deny this. This minister is very good on bluster. We have just seen her bluster to Senator Stott Despoja. Last month alone 40,300 jobs disappeared: 23,000 of them were full‐time jobs. Since the coalition's first budget, 57,400 jobs have disappeared—the result of conscious policies of this government. The government cannot avoid facing up to the fact that, in the very last month of May, the participation rate dropped to 63.2 per cent. It is the lowest rate since November 1994. Bluster is not good enough at question time from Senator Vanstone, the minister. She has to come back into the chamber and address the questions we put to her. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Childs talks about apprenticeships and traineeships. Isn't it fascinating? Once again he is complaining about what the Liberal coalition government is doing about apprenticeships and traineeships when, under the Labor government, apprenticeships and traineeships fell to their lowest level as a percentage of the work force in three decades—not just over the last couple of years; it actually fell to the lowest level in three decades. Senator Childs says, `Woe is me. We have a few apprenticeship and traineeship problems in the work force.'

SPEECH.PARA: If he has identified a few apprenticeships and traineeships in the work force, why didn't he seek to do something about it when he was part of a government that for 13 years presided over the greatest drop in apprenticeships and traineeships in three decades? What has the coalition government done? As the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Minister Kemp, has said, there will be 55,000 new TAFE places in the coming year and 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships in the year after.

Here we have a clear program directed at 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships, and yet Senator Childs comes in here and complains about it, having presided over the greatest decline in three decades. Where in the world is the logic of the Labor Party? It completely escapes me to think that this is what they can do every single solitary day after question time, when they have actually created the problem, and they come in and blame the coalition government for resolving the problem. We did not create these problems, but we have certainly undertaken to fix them. And that is the difference between that government for 13 years and this government in 15 months.

What has happened in the last few days is that the coalition government has actually made a conscious decision to reverse the circumstances that the Labor government put in place, and that is where young people got paid more not to work than to train. That could not be allowed to continue. Therefore, both ministers, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), have sought to do something about it, and have received nothing but criticism from that entire side of the chamber—from the Democrats right through to the Labor Party—since the announcement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just think that.

—And to think that someone in a position such as Senator Kernot, who purports to be the be‐all to end all of the Senate, can possibly say that the taxpayer should actually pay for everything—as the Daily Telegraph says, `everything from the army to a night at the pictures'.
—I did not say that.

—Maybe Senator Kernot did not actually use those precise words. But the fact of the matter is that the precise words that she did use are these. Let me quote them: `Excuse me, Mum, excuse me, Dad, can I have the money for a bus ticket? Can I have the money to go to the movies? Can I have the money for a milkshake?' I can just hear it in that typical carping way of Senator Kernot. Therefore, by exact definition and extension of that statement, one must only presume that Senator Kernot expects the taxpayer to pay for the bus ticket, the movie ticket and the milkshake—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Calvert interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the chewing gum, Senator Calvert, and the lollies, and everything else. Senator Kernot has simply lost the plot altogether if she believes that it is the responsibility of the taxpayer to pay for movie tickets and milkshakes. Goodness gracious me; Senator Kernot and the Labor Party have completely lost this. And then Senator Woodley says that something that is going to pay kids more to be in training than to be on the dole is going to create suicide. That is despicable. At a time when youth suicide is increasing and has increased, he should not be talking in that fashion. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to take note of Senator Vanstone's answer to Senator Childs's question. It appears that a couple of forecasts made by Senator Vanstone are in the process of coming true. The first forecast was that the government would lose the next election if it failed to fix the jobless problem. The second forecast was that there was no instant fix to the current unemployment in this country. We certainly know the latter is correct.

SPEECH.PARA: What is surprising is that the government appears not to care about its unemployment drive to extinction. One asks the question: what are the direct responsibilities of this government? Forty‐three thousand jobs have been lost in a single month—23,000 of those jobs full time, with 20,000 part‐time jobs lost. There are now 242,000, almost one‐quarter of a million, long‐term unemployed people in Australia, with few adequate labour market programs—the highest figure in two years, and 28,000 more since March 1996.

If we look at each of the states one by one, we see that the unemployment rate is up in New South Wales to 8.3 per cent, up in Victoria to 9.2 per cent, up in Queensland to 9.7 per cent, up in South Australia to 9.8 per cent and up in Tasmania to 10.4 per cent. Nine-tenths of Australians are living in states of rising unemployment, states of insecurity and states of lost hope. The only healthy state is my own state. The unemployment figures are down there because of lower participation rates. You have driven them out of the work force. That is why the unemployment rate is down there.

Decisions announced yesterday will result in 35,000 young Australians losing their unemployment benefit. Another 33,000 will lose welfare or Austudy payments or will have them reduced. What does this government do? It reduces labour market program outlays.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Deputy President. I draw your attention to the question of relevance. Senator Bishop may be taking note of another answer, because the actual question that we are now debating is the one to which Senator Childs referred, which relates specifically to apprenticeships and traineeships.

—On the point of order, Madam Deputy President: Senator Knowles herself referred to Senator Kernot and many other issues way beyond the issue that Senator Childs raised. I think she has a cheek to raise that point of order, and I hope you will dismiss it.

—Order! If you must interject, which you should not, do not do it from outside your chair. This is a wide ranging debate. Senator Bishop is redressing a number of the issues that Senator Vanstone raised in her answer. Continue, Senator Bishop.

—I was coming to the issue of what this government are doing about unemployment. They are reducing labour market outlays. They have axed labour market programs for the long-term unemployed. They are reducing overall funding for TAFE. They are continuing the reduction in apprenticeship and traineeship numbers. What does the Australian say of this? I will quote from Mr Alan Wood of the Australian on Friday, 13 June. He is not a friend of the Labor Party—not a card‐carrying member. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Instead we are likely to see more bad policy decisions as the Government tries to cover up its inability to deal with the real issues that need to be tackled.
This is bad news for the unemployed, because a lot of them will remain unemployed for a long time yet.

It also means that there is a real risk that Australia will continue to turn inwards, retreating into a surly economic nationalism at a time when we are under particularly close watch from our neighbours, thanks to Hansonism.
John Howard had better be right when he says an economic upturn is just around the corner.
At least most economic forecasters agree with him; you can make up your own mind whether that is correct reassuring.

What does the Prime Minister do in response to that advice? We know he has gone off to the United Kingdom and the United States to watch the cricket and the tennis. He is going to meet with new Prime Minister Blair in the United Kingdom. What will Mr Blair say to him? We can forecast exactly now the advice that Mr Blair will give to our own Prime Minister. He will advise Prime Minister Howard to implement labour market programs and to pay attention to the social contract in his country, in his own society. He will suggest that Prime Minister Howard provide extra funding for schools, extra funding for the technical sector and extra funding for the TAFE sector. He will suggest that he allocate ongoing funding for training and retraining. Finally, he will make the point of the absolute need—the absolute urgency—to invest in young citizens through extra funds for apprenticeships and traineeships.

What are the real issues behind this massive rise in unemployment that the government fails to address? There is a correlation between low growth and low business confidence. There is a correlation between fat wages for executives and job security at the coalface. There is a contrast between high returns for big business while small business struggles and increasingly goes under. There is a gap between rich and poor. There is the plight of a generation devoid of opportunity. These issues require a purposeful, strong, considered response. This government gives us a Prime Minister watching the cricket and tennis, ignoring the real problems that are occurring in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit disappointed in Senator Childs today because it is not usually his style to take cheap political points and to make the sorts of comments he made about the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) going overseas. When Prime Minister Keating went overseas, you did not hear this side carping about his going away. We did complain when he went away and bucketed Australia from overseas, but we did not complain when he went overseas because it is absolutely vital that our prime ministers of either persuasion go overseas, particularly when a prime minister is going to two countries which are two of our largest trading partners and two of our largest investors. It is important for jobs. Those opposite would not understand that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister going to the cricket is better than the feigned interest that Mr Keating had in the Collingwood football team, flying at taxpayer's expense to Melbourne. I do not think he has been to football again since then. At least the Prime Minister has a genuine and long‐term interest in cricket, more than the previous Prime Minister had in Collingwood when he travelled to watch a game at taxpayers' expense. You would think that that was all he was going to do, the way you go on. When a cricket team or a sporting team wins in Australia, confidence goes up in Australia. So it is important for the Prime Minister to show interest in our sports men and women overseas.

Let me get back to the issue of apprenticeships. Despite the fact that I disagreed with quite a bit of what Senator Kernot said yesterday on AM, at least she had the good grace to actually acknowledge that there were some good parts of this package. There were one or two things she said that I would take issue with—she disagrees with us on some things—but she actually outlined some of the positive points in the package. The Labor Party has not had the good grace to do that on one occasion. There are many points here and, if they would actually look at, address and turn their minds to what we are doing, they would see that we are making improvements on the mess they left traineeships and apprenticeships in, the mess they left the social security system in—despite the fact that minister after minister kept saying that it was trim, taut and terrific—the mess they left Austudy in and the disarray and lack of coordination facing young people in finding their way through that maze.

Senator Knowles, when she was addressing the issue, said that, under Labor, apprenticeships, as a proportion of the work force, fell to the lowest level in three decades. What record does Labor have in traineeships? What did the Labor Party do about trying to put in place a program that integrated a transition between school and work? There are many programs being introduced by the coalition.

Dr David Kemp announced on 13 May, after the budget, that $265 million more will be spent for 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships in 1997‐98. The new apprenticeships and traineeships will be in high‐growth industries such as technology, finance, tourism and hospitality, sport and traditional trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose spending is it? You're only telling half the story again.

—Senator, through you, Madam Deputy President, you will get every opportunity to speak if you want to rather than shouting across the chamber. The funding is a part of $415 million in 1997‐98 for the new national apprenticeship system. Dr Kemp said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are expanding career options and opportunities for the 60% of students not going on to full‐time university or TAFE.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why doesn't he increase the budget to meet the demand?

—You sound tired of it, too, Madam Deputy President, as is the whole Senate. All Senator Carr can do is stand there and carp in interjections. Dr David Kemp also said:

BREAK.PARA: The Federal Government will provide a total of more than $1.3 billion for vocational education and training in 1997‐98.

He went on to say there will be:
