That is the government's record on traineeships and apprenticeships. What was the disaster left by the Labor government? They left the apprenticeship system in disarray, the traineeship system in disarray, Austudy in disarray. And the benefits that were available for young people under all the sorts of social security allowances that were available to them are now integrated as part of an integrated approach by this government. They do not like the fact that we are actually getting in there and doing something—cleaning up the mess and giving young people an opportunity. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I take note of the same matter, and Senator Patterson will be pleased that I am speaking on this matter. The decline in apprentices we are talking about is another example of the government's record across the board on unemployment. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) continues to claim that all sorts of his measures will generate jobs, but his credibility is waning under the heavy weight of evidence. Let us look at some of those claims.

SPEECH.PARA: He said that the Workplace Relations Act would create jobs. Where are they? He said that the unfair dismissal changes within the Workplace Relations Act would create jobs. Where are they? He said that further unfair dismissal changes, the exemptions for small business, would create jobs. Small business does not seem to agree, if you take comments from the MTAA and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and research such as the Yellow Pages small business report. Now he is saying that tax reform will create jobs. I am sorry, but the line is getting a little too long.

Now let us look at the real evidence on these issues. In the 15 months since the Howard government took office, the number of people unemployed has risen by 39,000; the unemployment rate has risen from 8.5 per cent to 8.8 per cent; and youth unemployment—since we are focusing on youth—has risen from 27.4 per cent to 27.5 per cent. So where is the evidence to support these claims? The government simply has to stop copping out. This is why, as Senator Patterson refers to it, some people seem to be referring to some of the petty issues—although, I note, she went back to pettiness herself. People are obviously concerned about the fact that the Prime Minister is leaving the country to go to Lord's before he goes to Newcastle.

There is good reason for that sort of concern. The new youth allowance, which he launched just before he left, will not create jobs; it just blames victims—something this government is getting very good at doing. We have read in the media that the Prime Minister is going to Britain to talk about employment measures. He seems to have forgotten that Tony Blair came to Australia a couple of years ago to look at what we were doing under Working Nation and took with him our training initiatives and labour market programs. But the British do not have a great record on long-term unemployment. We certainly do not want to use it as a model here. It is about the last model we would want to put in place in Australia.

Let us remind the Senate that a year ago this week this government began slashing away at Working Nation programs such as skillshare, which targeted the long-term unemployed. Since the dismantling of these programs, 28,000 more people have joined the long-term unemployed queue. The Howard government's laughable program—the work for the dole scheme for 10,000 people—will do nothing for the highest number of long‐term unemployed in two years. This is no record.

I want to conclude my comments by going back to apprenticeships—since it was raised by Senator Knowles as being the key point of relevance in this matter. However, she does not seem to understand the difference between apprenticeships and traineeships and perhaps other forms of vocational education when she talks about the 100,000 new TAFE places. What the government is doing in this matter—and the states have been complaining about it, too—is shifting responsibility and funding to the states, and this is not a new concept. In fact, 50,000 of those places, which have previously been a matter of Commonwealth responsibility, will become the burden of states.

State governments are upset about this. Conservative state governments are upset about this. The Victorian tertiary education minister, Phil Honeywood has said that `the hypocrisy in this is there for all to see'. The hypocrisy of the government's action in vocational education and training for young people is there for all to see; the hypocrisy in the government's record on jobs and job creation is there for all to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jacinta Collins talks about hypocrisy. Let us have a look at the hypocrisy of opposition members when they start talking about employment records and training records. Let us have a bit of a look at what happened under 13 years of Labor compared to what is happening now as we try to turn this around.

BREAK.PARA: Labor had an absolutely shocking record on not only employment but also training. If you have a look at the number of jobs that were lost during the great Keating recession between 1990 and 1993, you will find that the net new jobs over that period from the peak of one boom to the peak of another was about 50,000. In a period of four years that is all we gained in employment under the best part of the Keating years. Yet the people on the other side of the chamber have the hide, given their total failure in this area over 13 years, to come in and talk about employment records.

The other area where the previous government failed dismally was in training, particularly in the area of apprenticeships. Over Labor's 13 years, the apprenticeship system in this country totally collapsed. What we are now creating in this next budget—something which Senator Collins very conveniently forgot to talk about but was reminded of by Senator Patterson—is 100,000 apprenticeship places. This government will be spending $260 million on this area because it has set it as a priority. The areas of vocational education and training are a priority of this government.

The last government got it totally wrong. Former Minister Dawkins spent a fair bit of his reign—a reign of terror, particularly with the universities—on trying to change the university system, totally confusing it in the process and setting wrong directions by giving a whole series of edicts from on high, particularly relating to amalgamations and central direction. Before he turned his mind to universities, he should have turned it to vocational education and training in this country.

He very belatedly discovered this in about 1992, when, in the desperate dark days of the Keating recession we had to have, the then government finally turned their mind to training with the creation of the Australian National Training Authority, and then a little bit later they started on Working Nation. An enormous amount of money was spent on Working Nation, which had incredibly poor work outcomes and which focused on the long-term unemployed, of whom only 30 per cent got jobs, and the other 70 per cent were picked up off the scrap heap and then dropped back again. There were terrible outcomes for those people, not only in respect of work and income but also in respect of the psychological effects of what happened to them.

What this government is about is creating real training and real jobs. That is why the measures for the youth allowance, announced yesterday, are most welcome. What we are going to focus on is young people not just automatically going to get the dole but being put back into training. Why is this the way to go? It is because the statistics have told us about the work outcomes for people who are trained versus those who are not trained: those who are trained are three times more likely to get a proper job. That is why the whole focus of our programs is towards doing that.
We call on the school system in Australia to refocus their efforts to support this.

TALK.START.PARA: —And where's the money coming from?

—I am talking about a change in curriculum, Senator Carr. I am talking about a curriculum that is not just focused on the assumption that everyone is going to university. As you well know, Senator Carr, only 25 per cent of the student cohort goes to university. What about the other 75 per cent, Senator Carr—the 75 per cent which you consistently ignored over the years?

BREAK.PARA: What we want schools to do is to emulate excellent training programs, like the TRAC program in Newcastle. That curriculum is in high schools and is moving through so that students get vocational education and training in schools and have an opportunity to move on to vocational education, if that is their wish, once they leave school. Everything that we are setting up now with our training programs is the way forward for the youth of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Community Affairs References Committee on the consequences for older Australians and their families arising from proposed changes announced in the 1996-97 federal budget to the funding of aged care institutions in Australia, together with submissions and transcripts of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard and to move a motion relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
The inquiry into the funding of aged care institutions was referred to the Committee on 13 February 1997 on the motion of Senator West, the former Chairperson of the Committee.
The Committee received 118 submissions from many parties with an interest in, or associated with, the provision of aged care services in Australia and held three days of public hearings.
In the 1996-97 Budget, the Government announced a major structural reform of residential aged care, scheduled to take effect on 1 July 1997 (and since postponed until 1 October 1997).

The reforms were proposed against a backdrop of the increasing ageing of the Australian population and the pressures this will impose on the community's ability to care for this sector of the population.

The Government's Budget announcement responded to the financial situation outlined in the 1994 report by Professor Gregory which reviewed the structure of nursing home funding arrangements and outlined options to address the deterioration in the nursing home capital stock.

During the course of the inquiry, many groups and organisations expressed concern at the inadequate time allowed for comment on the draft Bill and Principles and the lack of detailed information that has been released on the reforms.

The exposure draft of the Aged Care Bill provided only 11 days for public comment, while the exposure draft of the Aged Care Principles was released for public comment with an indication that a further 9 Principles had not been drafted.
The Committee is concerned that major issues concerning the reforms are still unresolved (such as the prudential arrangements).

The Committee believes that while there are so many issues yet to be resolved and with such widespread concerns still being expressed over aspects of the reforms and their implementation timetable, the commencement of the legislation should be delayed until 1 January 1998.

The Committee is also concerned at the Parliamentary difficulties in conducting an informed debate on the legislation without the benefit of having available all the details relating to the reforms and their operation.

The Committee believes that there is widespread community opposition to the proposed introduction of accommodation bonds for entry into nursing homes. The Committee has grave concerns that the charging of accommodation bonds effectively imposes a charge for the provision of health care on those who are most vulnerable in the community—the frail elderly.
The Committee has therefore recommended that the proposed introduction of accommodation bonds not be proceeded with by the Government.

The Committee believes that the level of bonds charged may well be substantial and impose a significant burden on the elderly. Evidence received by the Committee indicated that the amount of bonds charged by nursing homes may be up to $100,000.
The Committee notes that entry contributions for hostels currently average around $40,000 per resident.
The Committee believes that many pensioners, especially single pensioners who own their own home, may have no other viable option than to sell their home to pay the accommodation bond.

The Committee considers that for these pensioners, especially if they have no significant other assets than their home, there is little possibility that the various periodic payment options would be feasible.

The Committee also recommended that a person's home should not be included in the assets test. The Committee believes that this ignores the reality of the psychological value of the family home on the health and well-being of older people.
The Committee is also concerned that the proposed legislation will not guarantee equal access to nursing homes for financially disadvantaged people (confessional residents).

The Committee believes that the allocation of places for concessional residents (set at 27 per cent of places nationally) needs to be closely monitored to ensure equality of access for these residents, particularly to aged care facilities within the prospective residents' locality.

The Committee is particularly concerned at the amount of the concessional resident subsidy (set at $5 per resident per day). The Committee believes that the subsidy does not provide any real assistance to nursing homes, especially in the not-for-profit sector who cater predominantly for financially disadvantaged people, to maintain and upgrade facilities.

The Committee believes that unless the concessional subsidy is substantially increased it will lead to a two-tired system where financially disadvantaged people will be accommodated in lower standard accommodation with no real prospect of facilities being upgraded in the future.
The Committee also addressed the need for effective user rights protections to be an integral element of the reform package.

The Committee considers that user rights protections would be enhanced by the establishment of an independent complaints mechanism which would be independent of all stakeholders, including the Department of Health and Family Services.

The Committee also recommended the that the role of advocates be encouraged and that advocacy services be supported by funding sufficient to fulfil their important role in the protection of residents' rights.
The Committee was also concerned that the reforms have the potential to compromise the standards of care in aged care facilities.

The Committee considers that as nursing care is the essence of residential aged care, the reforms need to guarantee the highest quality nursing care will be available to residents and that this nursing care will be delivered by appropriately skilled and trained staff.

The Committee also believes that the new Aged Care Standards Agency should be established with the necessary investigative powers to ensure that the quality of care and rights of residents are protected.
The Agency should also have monitoring and enforcement mechanisms in place to ensure industry compliance with care standards and should be funded to meet those objectives.

The Committee also expressed concerns at the loss of acquittal through the abolition of the Care Aggregated Module (CAM) funding formula. The Committee therefore recommended that nursing homes continue to be required to acquit that proportion of their funding expended on nursing and personal care.

In respect of prudential arrangements, the Committee considers that the prudential arrangements should provide an unconditional assurance that the balance of the accommodation bonds is able to be refunded and that the arrangements be able to be complied with at the least cost to providers so as to ensure that the monies received by way of accommodation bonds can be used for the intended purpose of capital improvement.

The Committee also believes that prudential arrangements should be mandatory for all providers of aged care who receive accommodation bonds, except for certain church run facilities where the facility is properly backed by the relevant church organisation.

As stated previously, while the Committee is strongly opposed to the introduction of accommodation bonds, it believes that should the Aged Care Bill be passed by the Parliament with the inclusion of accommodation bonds, the Committee's other recommendations to improve the functioning of the legislation and the overall operation of the Aged Care Structural Reform Package should be implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

COMMONWEALTH VEHICLES (REGISTRATION AND EXEMPTION FROM TAXATION) BILL 1997
This legislation is one of two bills arising from issues associated with the sale of DASFLEET. The other companion bill is the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill.

Madam President, the Government announced in 1996 its intention to either sell its vehicle fleet business, DASFLEET, or refinance the vehicles which DASFLEET operates. The Government decided to approach the market for bids based on both sale and refinancing to ensure the best possible outcome for the Commonwealth.

This Government is committed to public sector reform and has sought to identify functions where direct Commonwealth involvement can no longer be justified. In the case of DASFLEET and the other Department of Administrative Services business units currently being offered for sale, the Government has identified areas which do, or could, compete directly with private sector suppliers. It has decided to divest itself of these functions, while at the same time ensuring a fair return to the taxpayer for these quality businesses.

The operation of the Commonwealth motor vehicle fleet has historically been undertaken internally and the origins of DASFLEET can be traced to the Department of Defence in the early 1920s. At that time, the options available to the Commonwealth for the provision of motor vehicles were limited. Today, however, the provision of motor vehicles and fleet management services is undertaken by a dynamic and competitive industry and the case for maintaining a Commonwealth‐owned vehicle fleet is no longer compelling.

The Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill and the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill, have been prepared in the context of the Government's decision to sell or refinance DASFLEET. The ongoing measures in these bills will, however, apply to vehicles leased to the Commonwealth by any company, not just the purchaser of DASFLEET. In addition, because DASFLEET currently provides only half of the vehicles in the Commonwealth's fleet, the ongoing provisions in the bills will extend to any future sale and lease‐back of Commonwealth vehicles.

The two pieces of proposed legislation are intended to ensure that registration, taxation and third party insurance arrangements which currently apply to vehicles used by the Commonwealth can continue once those vehicles are privately owned and leased to the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill will establish a Commonwealth register of motor vehicles in which vehicles owned by or leased to the Commonwealth may be registered rather than being registered under State or Territory law.

The use of Commonwealth number plates allows ease of recognition of Commonwealth Government vehicles and has proven to be an effective mechanism for the regulation of their usage. This bill will allow for the continued use of `Z' and other Commonwealth number plates on vehicles once they are no longer owned by the Commonwealth, but are leased for a period of at least three months to the Commonwealth for its use.

The bill also allows for the making of regulations which will provide for details of how the motor vehicle register will be kept and other matters such as how registration plates and labels should be displayed. Further, I intend that public trading enterprises will be exempt under regulations from the coverage of this bill and its companion bill. This will ensure that the proposed legislation does not impact on the competitive position of Commonwealth business enterprises which operate in the market place.

In addition to establishing the motor vehicle register, the bill contains measures to exempt the transfer of assets, as well as the ongoing provision of vehicles to the Commonwealth, from State and Territory taxes.

Under the Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill, the transfer of DASFLEET assets, including the motor vehicle fleet, will be exempt from State and Territory imposts. This will allow all Australians to benefit from the full proceeds of sale, rather than a proportion of those proceeds being distributed to those States and Territories in which the transfer of assets happens to take place.

The Commonwealth currently operates several thousand vehicles which it registers under State and Territory law, most notably vehicles which are provided under the Senior Executive Vehicle Scheme. While the Commonwealth pays registration fees, by virtue of its Constitutional exemption from State and Territory taxes, it does not currently pay stamp duty on the registration of such vehicles. The Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill will maintain this position by extending the exemption to the private owner of vehicles where those vehicles are leased to the Commonwealth for at least three months.

In addition, where a vehicle is leased to the Commonwealth for a continuous period of three months, these leases will be exempt from State and Territory taxes levied on leasing arrangements. The three month period is intended to capture leases which could be considered to be long‐term leases, and exclude the short‐term rental of vehicles for which the taxation exemption would be overly complex to administer.

Madam President, the measures in the bill now before the Senate are not intended to change the Commonwealth's position with respect to the States and Territories. They are merely intended to ensure that the Commonwealth is in the same position with respect to State and Territory law and third party liability coverage after the sale of its vehicle fleet as it was before the sale. This bill together with its companion bill will ensure a minimum of disruption to the supply of vehicles to the Commonwealth once these vehicles are privately owned.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
COMMONWEALTH MOTOR VEHICLES (LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1997
This legislation is one of two bills arising from issues associated with the sale of DASFLEET. The other companion bill is the Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill.

The Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill will ensure that the provisions of the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Act 1959 will continue to apply once vehicles used by the Commonwealth are not actually owned by the Commonwealth.

Generally speaking, the Commonwealth self‐insures against third party liability arising from the use of vehicles which bear Commonwealth number‐plates. These self insurance arrangements are embodied in the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Act 1959 which provides for third party liability coverage where vehicles are not otherwise insured. The Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill now before the Senate will extend the coverage of this act to vehicles which are leased to the Commonwealth.

Madam President, as I indicated during my speech concerning the companion bill, the measures in the bills now before the Senate continue the present legal status of cars used by the Commonwealth whether or not they are directly owned or leased.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of these bills be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the spring sittings 1997, in accordance with standing order 111.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Faulkner) seeking to vary the membership of a committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senator Jacinta Collins be appointed a member of the House Standing Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the most recent Yellow Pages Small Business Index, which indicated that 80 per cent of small businesses considered the economy was either not growing, or was actually in recession,

(ii) the comments of Dr John Marsden, who conducted the Yellow Pages Small Business Index, who on national television in answer to the question `. . . what are the big issues worrying small business?', replied, `very simple, lack of work, lack of sales, cashflow, consumer confidence and competition from big business',

(iii) the Australian Certified Practising Accountants small business health index survey, which stated that small business was more pessimistic about the future than at any time since the survey began, and

(iv) the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Finding a balance: Towards fair trading in Australia , which recommended that the Government:

TAB.TAB: (a) introduce uniform retail tenancy codes underpinned by the Trade Practices Act,
(b) enact specific legislation to protect franchisees from franchisors, and
(c) amend the Trade Practices Act to protect small businesses from unfair conduct by larger firms; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Government to implement without delay the recommendations of the report.

Of course, electors faced with a choice at the last election are aware that the headline promise of the coalition at the time was to `resurrect the future for small business', as they put it. In quoting what the coalition promised, in no way do I reflect upon the fine performance of the Labor government leading up to the last election. Many small business people now are lamenting the absence of several of our ministers for small business who had, in fact, opened the doors for opportunity for this industry sector in Australia. Yet, as a political gimmick at the election, the coalition, now the government, promised a new dawn for small business.

BREAK.PARA: The small business community in Australia now feel betrayed and let down. Many of them may have believed the glowing promises made by the government for the new dawn that it offered but they all now know from their own bitter and personal experience—an experience that cannot be gainsaid by rhetoric, by any miscalculation or allocation of statistics, or simply by jawboning up the prospects for the sector—that small business is doing it hard in Australia. The reason why they are doing it hard is the economic settings the coalition government have foisted on the economy and the negative confidence that has been imbued around the nation.

Bankruptcies among small business are climbing and the confidence of the small business sector is down. The media release on the Yellow Pages survey entitled `Small business sees no economic recovery—survey finds' of 27 May 1997 captures the sense of frustration and anger that the small business community in Australia feel. It says:

Australia's small business sector reports no sign of economic recovery. Proprietors' confidence has reached its lowest level since August 1993, according to the latest Yellow Pages Small Business Index.

The Index found that at the beginning of May, a net 40 per cent of small business operators were confident about their business prospects for the coming 12 months, compared with a net 44 per cent three months ago and 57 per cent a year ago.
In line with this finding, more than 80 per cent of small businesses see the economy as being in recession or at a standstill.

Those remarks were encapsulated in summary form in an interview on Channel 9, shortly after the release of these figures, in an interview by Paul Lyneham, who asked Dr John Marsden, the compiler of the report:
What are the big issues worrying small business?
Dr Marsden replied:
Very simple, lack of work, lack of sales, cashflow, consumer confidence and competition from big business.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's about everything, isn't it?

—As Senator Schacht, a former and distinguished minister for small business, interjects: that just about covers everything. Lamentably it covers a hell of a lot of the bleak future facing small business in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The truth is that this government promised a stronger economy but the economy is underperforming in a devastating and humanly frustrating way. The 1996‐97 budget forecast economic growth for this nation at 3.75 per cent. The actual outcome, we learnt when the last budget was put down, was a growth rate of 2.4 per cent. Many of us said at the time the 3.75 per cent forecast figure was announced that it was unrealistic. We said that the state of the economy and the cuts that had been engaged in by the coalition government would bring down demand in the economy to the extent that the economy could not realise those growth figures.

During the course of the year, in debate in this chamber, we have echoed those comments but we have been reassured by government spokespeople that that is not true. The outcome shows that it is true. It is dismally true, it is unfortunately true and it is sadly true that the economy underperformed by 1.35 per cent below the level of forecast growth. There is not, in the 3.75 per cent figure, enough growth in the economy to employ school leavers at the end of the year. As a consequence of pitching a budget to achieve that level of growth, the government was making a positive choice to increase unemployment. It was also making a positive choice to lower aggregate demand in the economy. But because the economy performed at even less than what was forecast, unemployment will be even higher and aggregate demand for goods and services in the economy will be even lower.

We have seen in last month's unemployment figures that unemployment rose by 40,000 people in one month. We know, as I have said, that bankruptcy has continued to rise. In response, we hear from the government that interest rates are continuing to be cut. The reason why they are being cut is that it is a desperate effort to stimulate greater demand in the economy. Nothing much is going on out there and nothing much looks like going on out there to give consumers confidence to buy. So interest rates fall not because of some grand policy setting of the government but because the economy is too flat and too lacking in growth to stimulate the necessary demand to create jobs or to create growth for small business.

That is why interest rates are falling and that is why people do not trust the future in Australia and are saving and not buying. And if consumers do not buy, business does not sell and small businesses face going to the wall. It is a bleak outcome. It is an outcome that the opposition takes no joy in, but it is a fact of life. It would be better for the national economic debate if the government faced those facts, were honest about it, stopped trying to jawbone their way past the truth and dealt with the real issues that affect small business.

I might say, at this point, that one of the real issues that affect small business is the leadership this government provides to it in the form of the minister, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Prosser. As I speak in this chamber, Mr Prosser is the subject of a censure motion in the other chamber, the House of Representatives. He is the subject of a call for his resignation. That is because he has misconducted himself as a minister under the code of ministerial conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

Under that code, Mr Prosser was required to indicate areas where he, in the performance of his ministerial duty, would have conflicts of interest in terms of his private holdings and private ownership of shares. We now have the explicit fact that Mr Prosser, as the owner of a company in Western Australia that owns shopping malls, has had that company affiliated to BOMA, the Business Owners and Managers Association, which in turn, on behalf of its affiliates—including Mr Prosser's company—made representations to Mr Prosser about what the law governing the operation of fair trading should be. Through an association, a company he owns makes submissions—which will go in the end to his private pecuniary advantage—to him about what he as a law‐maker with an obligation to Australia should do.

That is a clear conflict of interest between ministerial obligation and private pecuniary interest. In those circumstances, the Prime Minister—or the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) in this case—now has no option. If he wishes to retain the confidence of the small business sector, he must act. He must chop Mr Prosser out of the ministerial loop, put him back on the back bench and try to find someone within coalition ranks whom he can appoint as small business minister who will stand up for small business within government, reviving the confidence of the small business sector. Many in the small business sector, through their organisations and associations, have passed resolutions or called for Mr Prosser's resignation. Small business needs a champion and, from the performance I have so far had a chance to describe, it is obvious that it does not have one within the structure of the government as it stands—that champion is certainly not Mr Prosser.

But this is a motion about the problems that face small business in the economy. Therefore, in this debate I do not want to talk simply about the minister. I can say much more about this, but I conclude by saying again that this is a clear breach of ministerial responsibility and a clear case of a conflict of interests. Under the guidelines that the Prime Minister proposed to us that he would enforce to ensure and restore public confidence in the parliament and the ministry, he has no option now but to act and cause Mr Prosser to resign.

The opposition—and the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Kim Beazley—in the first few months of our being in opposition, brought on a private member's bill to deal with the issue of fair trading. This is a major issue for small business. Increasingly, the overwhelming majority of small businesses find that their businesses take the form of a franchise. That is, they franchise a name or trading label from a franchisor. Small businesses also find, overwhelmingly, that many of them are domiciled in major shopping centres and malls around Australia—the preferred way in which Australian consumers go about their retail purchases.

For those small businesses who are franchisees and for many of the small businesses who are tenants in major shopping malls, there is a gap in the law. Those small businesses are often exploited. They often have their rents jacked up in unfair ways and in ways in which the efficacy of their own business is brought into question. Franchisees and franchisors are among the most litigious sections of the business community. If one looked for a new growth area of law, one would see an amazing growth in litigation involving the rights of franchisees conflicting with those of franchisors.

Franchisees are an under‐represented group within our community. They are small business people, but often the terms of their franchise are held by the franchisor and they are exploited—the terms are varied, the conditions are made unrealistic and they are subject to harsh and unconscionable acts at law. The Beazley private member's bill was aimed at rectifying these things. Did the government support that bill? Did the government—which proclaims and trumpets around this nation that it is the champion of small business—stand up for the interests of that sector of the small business community? It did not. It rejected the Beazley bill.

It inaugurated the parliamentary inquiry into fair trading, the result of which is this parliamentary report. The motion I have moved today is for the Senate of Australia to call upon the government to implement the findings of this report. This is a report of a committee of the House of Representatives, a committee which comprises members from all sides of the parliament—the Liberal, National and Labor parties. This report is unanimous in its conclusion that what the Beazley bill was trying to rectify is a major problem and should be fixed. Kim Beazley was prepared to argue it and have it fixed last year. The inquiry that has been conducted into it has found that it is a serious problem and should now be fixed. This government should move posthaste and forthwith to fix that gap in the law and adopt the recommendations of this report.

The main recommendations of this report would result in the introduction of uniform retail tenancy codes to underpin fair trading within the Trade Practices Act. This report shows that there is a clear need in Australia to protect tenants in major shopping centres from being unfairly prejudiced by the conduct of the owners of those shopping centres. If the recommendations of this report were enacted, there would be specific legislation enacted to protect the interests of small businesses who are franchisees from predatory actions by the owners of the franchises—the franchisors. As I say, this is one of the most litigious areas in small business law in Australia.

If the recommendations of this report were enacted, the Trade Practices Act would be amended to protect small businesses generally from the unfair conduct of larger firms. Larger firms, because of their monopoly of market power, can put conditions and circumstances on small businesses which are harsh and unconscionable.

There is an urgent need to do those things now because, as I said at the beginning of my remarks, bankruptcies are up, business confidence is low and the economic outlook is bleak. In those circumstances, a shot of confidence needs to be injected into the economy for small business. One of the things the government can do immediately to achieve that is move to set the legal framework for fair trading in Australia right, and I trust the Senate will adopt the motion that I have moved in order to ensure that.

In the few minutes remaining to me, I want to say a couple of things about what Labor has done for small business, because in the rhetoric, in the advertising and in the sloganeering being engaged in by the government, there is a tendency to forget the solid detail of achievement of Labor's record in government.

We established the AusIndustry scheme. We maintained the export market development scheme at high levels of funding so small businesses could get into export. We introduced and maintained the research and development tax concession to enable small business companies with a scientific or intellectual idea they wanted to trade in the market to develop and expand that idea and create an industry, a good or a service that was marketable. We did those things.

We did a number of other things that ensured that the economy was out of recession and growing at a healthy rate. Through Chris Schacht, the minister for small business in the Labor government, and under the Small Business Council, we had the ear of small business which enabled us to work with them to make the law more effective, to create growth prospects for them, to increase opportunity and to increase employment.

When we came to opposition and the coalition came to government, the coalition promised as one of their headline offerings to the electorate that they would reduce the provisional tax uplift factor. It was this opposition, supported by the minor parties in the Senate, that kept the government honest.

The government proposed to reduce the uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent, but they legislated for the six per cent to apply only for one year and it would then revert to 10 per cent. That was not their promise. Their actions on that occasion were duplicitous and misleading. You could say that, when one looked at the detail of their legislation, the coalition government at the time lied to the community about what they proposed to do.

This chamber amended that legislation to maintain the uplift factor at six per cent, so the government was kept honest and opportunities were made available for small business. I conclude by saying that it is about time the rhetoric of this government was matched by its deeds. So far it has not been. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —What gall Senator Cook in particular has, but the Labor Party in general have, in coming into this chamber and moving this general business notice of motion. They are beating up the alleged negative perceptions of the economic situation for small business, when the Labor Party are clearly most directly responsible for whatever those perceptions might be.

SPEECH.PARA: First, prior to this government coming into office 12 or so months ago, we suffered the tax and spend mentality of 13 years of Labor government. Small business suffered 13 years of an absolute failure by that government to initiate much needed reforms to reduce the cost of doing business.

Let us have a brief look at what was required to provide a better environment for small business and Labor's record at doing something about creating that environment. We needed a less regulated and more flexible industrial relations system and labour market; Labor failed to provide that. We needed less onerous unfair dismissal laws; Labor failed to provide that. We needed less onerous capital gains and fringe benefits taxes; Labor failed to provide that. We needed less costly tax compliance provisions; Labor failed to provide that. We needed lower interest rates; Labor failed to provide that. We certainly, as far as small business was concerned, needed reduced government red tape; Labor failed absolutely to provide that. Need I go on about the failings of the previous Labor government in relation to small business.

But, sadly, Labor has learnt nothing from its experience in government. Failing to deliver these reforms so desperately needed by small business to allow it to prosper during their 13 years in government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support the fair trading report?

—was not enough failure for Senator Schacht and his colleagues on the other side. Since losing government about 14 or 15 months ago, Labor have worked tooth and nail to frustrate the new Howard Liberal‐National government in getting on with the job of reform. SPEECH.PARA: Do I have to remind the Senate yet again of the travelling circus that Labor initiated about a year ago to delay and frustrate industrial relations reform? The Senate economics committee was dragged all over this country to hear repeated, like a cracked record, the identical, centrally orchestrated false claims about that legislation coming from the union movement and provided by union after union. Despite that circus that went around week after week in June and July last year, we came back to this chamber and then had an extended filibuster on the legislation before an amended form of it finally got through.

We now see the same attempt being made to thwart the much needed reform of unfair dismissal laws specifically aimed at giving small businesses encouragement to employ more people. Currently, employers have a three‐month period of grace to sack staff without fear of unfair dismissal claims. The government wants to extend this employment period to up to one year for small businesses with fewer than 15 staff.

Currently, staff can be sacked without notice for theft, fraud, assault, drunkenness or refusing to comply with a contract or reasonable request. However, for all other complaints, employers must prove that the complaint is valid, they must notify the employee and they must allow time for correct behaviour. The government's proposed unfair dismissal exemption for small business will overcome the fear which small business has in employing people because of its being subject to this particular piece of legislation. It is therefore pro-jobs and it is pro-employment. It is saying to employers that the government is going to put in place a system which is fair to both employers and employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you do that last year?

—As a consequence of that approach, the South Australian and Queensland state governments have introduced mirror legislation to provide similar significant benefit to small business employers, subject to state legislation, which will be of benefit to those who employ about 520,000 people in the small business sector. Yet we see Labor indicating their opposition to those proposals. Senator Schacht asks, `Why didn't you do it last year?' They would have opposed it then. They are opposing it now. Let us see some support for some much needed reform, Senator Schacht, instead of this mindless interjecting we are getting from across the chamber.

BREAK.PARA: We are talking about small business—firms that employ fewer than 15 people. We are talking about increasing an exemption which we put in place last year. Do I have to remind the chamber of Labor's attempts to oppose the 1996 federal budget, which commenced the desperately needed task, which has continued in this year's budget, of restoring Australia to budget balance, restoring our federal finances to balance, and, indeed, creating a modest surplus by the end of our third year in government?

TALK.START.PARA: —Who put them in the red?

—Indeed, those across the way here when they were in government: the Labor Party. This move has delivered the lowest interest rates in a quarter of a century—much needed lower interest rates for small business.

BREAK.PARA: Let us turn to the matter that is under debate here today, this Yellow Pages Small business index survey.

BREAK.PARA: The Howard government has also introduced capital gains tax roll over specifically for small business, again in the face of a hostile Labor Party attitude. That is a significant benefit for small business and a significant incentive for investment, savings and job creation for the engine of job creation: small business.

Shortly after the election, the government established the small business task force. It delivered its report in November. The recommendations in that report were speedily considered by the cabinet and largely adopted, as announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Prosser, in March of this year. As a consequence of that, the government is moving to remove the burden of unnecessary paperwork, to simplify tax and corporate legislation, to reduce the complexity in compliance costs and paperwork with regard to fringe benefits tax and indeed to abolish fringe benefits tax with regard to car parking—again a bane of small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —When do they start?

BREAK.PARA: I also mention in the context of this motion that today the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs has introduced a new kit to better inform small business on the opportunities and challenges provided by competition policy. Let me simply reinforce that the Howard Liberal‐National Party government is strongly committed to the welfare of small business, strongly committed to making the necessary reforms and changes to reduce the cost of business, which is particularly needed by small business and will be particularly beneficial to the growth of small business, the growth of their profits and growth of the opportunity for them to provide much needed employment in this country.

We have a plan for small business. We developed that plan over a number of years. It is a comprehensive plan; it is a beneficial plan. That plan is now being put into place. I hope, given their statements of concern for small business today, that the Labor opposition will give their support to those so that we can get what remains to be done in terms of policy initiatives through this parliament in legislative form and the benefits for small business can be provided, small business can grow and jobs can grow. That means overall economic growth to the benefit of all Australians. I simply reject this motion that has been put up by the opposition. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I always pay some attention to the speakers list, because it does indicate the seriousness with which such matters are viewed by government. I think one of the problems with this speakers list is that it reflects once again a lack of sensitivity and a lack of alertness to the feeling in the small business community, particularly amongst the leaders of their organisations, concerning what is going on in that constituency.

SPEECH.PARA: Without casting any aspersions on the quality and character of the government senators who will speak, who are all perfectly capable and articulate people, nevertheless we are presented here with a situation where we have on the Labor side two former ministers prepared to debate this, accompanied by two of their colleagues, and on the government side there is no sign of the minister representing the minister for small business, Senator Parer, and there is no sign of any frontbencher apart from one who gets, I suppose, a little closer, namely, the whip.

We have amongst these three a farmer who is a leading light in the small and fundamentalist HR Nicholls Society; we have an exceptionally wealthy farmer who is an investor in big agribusiness; and we have another wealthy farmer who is involved in agribusiness. I really think that, when you have something like half the Senate to draw from, whilst it is good for various members of the Senate to get their airing whenever necessary, it does show the lack of seriousness with which the government is viewing what is going on.

The problem with this government, in my view, is that it says one thing and does another. It says it is supportive of manufacturing, yet it follows policies and activities which attack that sector. It says it supports families, and then it follows policies and does things which result in an attack on families. I say to you that in my opinion the same thing happens with small business.

It is no good, if you are the coalition, talking up your constituency; it is no good raising expectations, if you are not going to satisfy them. In one respect I am extremely grateful to you for doing that job, because I think the result of it will be such anger and such pressure that you will have to do something about what small business needs. I think you will be forced to react appropriately. You have talked up that constituency so far and you have satisfied its expectations so little that I think you are going to feel the effects of that. Already you have lost its confidence overall. Already the minister—who, incidentally, is another big business landlord—has lost its confidence.

We have to give you credit, of course, where credit is due. You have done some things which are good for small business. You did make reforms through the Workplace Relations Act, particularly in regard to the unfair dismissal changes that you have introduced, which are now six months old. They have had a particularly good effect on small business. When they find out what you have done, they feel that that is a wonderful job.

But, unfortunately, members of the coalition suffer from political senility. Your highest representative, the Prime Minister, could not even remember that he had actually got those laws passed; he still went ranting and raving on about the Brereton laws. Now again we hear a similar theme—when the unfair dismissal changes are delivering the goods already for small business, and small business thanks you for it.

What else have you done? You have made the capital gains tax changes. I recall hearing the first expression of them, defended in a somewhat misunderstanding way, if you like, by Senator Parer in the estimates process, when we told him in that process that what he was proposing in terms of `like business' and a very restricted process was entirely wrong. I congratulate you. You listened to the Democrats, you listened to Labor and you listened to small business, and you have changed it and you have improved it. So you have done well on capital gains tax. You have done well to introduce fringe benefits tax changes. Again, the small business constituency is grateful for that.

You have embarked upon cutting the paper trail for small business, on cutting down on regulations and so on. Again, you should be congratulated. You are fortunate, as a government, in being in an economic cycle where you have been able to accelerate trends, which were already established under the previous government, of interest rate cuts. I think you have added to the climate in which those interest rate cuts could have occurred. You should be congratulated for that as well. And you should be congratulated for reinforcing a low inflation climate which had commenced under the previous government. For all those things, yes, you should take some credit.

What have you done that is bad for small business? You have hammered the hell out of them in terms of R&D. You have shrunk the best export program we have ever had in this country, the export market development grant program. You have done a disgraceful job there. You have slashed business and labour programs, you have cut tens of thousands of jobs, you have lost jobs and you have damaged confidence, appallingly. It is no accident that, in reply to the question of what are the big issues worrying small business, Dr John Marsden said:
Very simple, lack of work, lack of sales, cashflow, consumer confidence and competition from big business.

That is it. Senator Chapman, Dr Marsden is not a discredited person when he says that. He is correctly reflecting the views of small business. I say to you: it is within your power to change that; it is within your power to advance the cause of small business. You have been delivered a fair trading report on a cross-party basis, which is singularly effective in terms of its recommendations.

I do not believe that the backbench of the coalition are a bunch of mugs. I believe that they do know that small business are uptight and upset and want these things changed. So instead of defending the indefensible, why don't you grasp the opportunity with both hand and say, `Yep, that's ours. We're going to do the job and small business will be grateful.' If you do that job, by God, they will be grateful. If you attend to those things in that fair trading report, you will go down, for small business, as the best government they have ever had. This is what will happen if you deliver, and deliver well, on every one of those recommendations. Do not resist them, do not vote against them and do not cringe and whine and complain on your way whilst you are doing so. Grab the opportunity with both hands. It has been presented to you.

What have you still to do? You have a problem: small business still experiences the highest real rates of interest in the OECD. Some interest rates are still running at up to 14 per cent on fixed loans which were arranged some time ago. Small businesses are still not getting the cheap finance they deserve. Yes, if they are granted the cheap finance they deserve, bank profits will drop. It will be a direct transfer from the shareholders of banks to the pockets of small business. That is the choice you face. I do know that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has been talking that side of it up, but that is not enough. They want action which is effective in delivering cheap finance on a wide basis to small business.

Let us talk about the franchisors and the franchisees. It is no good having a minister who has gone very close, cheek to cheek, with franchisors and their interests and has acted against the interest of franchisees. It is the franchisees who represent small business, not the franchisors. You are talking there of a $42 billion industry. It is such an easy thing to fix. They just need a mandatory code underpinned by legislation, qualified privilege for an independent board governing them and harsh and unconscionable provisions in the act that covers it.

But what is your problem? Your problem is that those are contrary to the interests of big business. It is a $42 billion industry. If the advantage to big business of fixing that deal the way they have is one per cent, it is worth $420 million. The three wealthy farmers who have spoken, or who are to speak, will understand that language. But small business wants the franchise thing fixed. Grasp the opportunity with both hands and respond to the fair trading report. Do the job.

Let us talk about retail tenancies. In my view, commercial tenancy and retailers' tenants rights are an extension of human rights, because those people are oppressed by large numbers of landlords and lawyers as the weak end of the chain. They are the weak; they are the afflicted. For that reason, you need to pay attention to their needs. Do not pay attention to a minister whose entire interest is in keeping the landlord side of things jacked up. Pay attention to the fair trading report.

BREAK.PARA: Some of the retail tenancy stories in the fair trading report brought tears to my eyes. You are talking there about people who have lost their homes and their businesses. They have turned to alcoholism and their families have broken up because of the way the law is fixed up at present to favour the landlord against the tenant, and because of the way they have been stitched up, particularly by the cartel, the oligopoly of big business landlords. Respond to that, for goodness sake. Understand the issue, deal with it, take the opportunity to fix the retail tenancy thing. Get out of the pockets of your big business donors and get into the hearts and into the morality by supporting the retail tenancy needs of small business.

Let me go along to harsh and unconscionable conduct. For 20 years, for over two decades, small business has battled to get into the Trade Practices Act. It has said, `Please, give us the same privilege, the same protection, that the law gives ordinary consumers. Please protect us from big business franchises. Please protect us from big business landlords. Please protect us from big business suppliers. Give us the protection which is recognised in that law for others.' For over two decades—I am afraid, Labor, it is to your eternal shame, and I know some of you fought to do it—that you did not change that law. Give them the black-letter law, the black-letter protection that they demand.

I say to you once again that that cross‐party fair trading report has recommendations which you should embrace with both hands. Instead of running off overseas or wherever your ministers like to go, why didn't they come out and say, `This is great. This is a report we can support, and we will do something about this as soon as possible'? That is the reason, I am afraid, that your minister and your government do not enjoy the confidence of small business, because you have talked up their expectations but you have not delivered on the things that matter to them most.

They are not mugs out there and they know that those things that I have outlined—the things which affect finance; the things which affect their relationships with franchisors and landlords and big business; the things which affect their tenancies; the things which affect their daily relationship with the law and the protection they should enjoy under the law—would deliver them a safe and secure future. Those things would deliver them the confidence they need.

You have got such a wonderful opportunity. You have a year and a half to go before you get back into that election. If you deliver on those things, small business will bless you. That package of recommendations, put together and delivered, would make small business exceptionally pleased with this government, instead of disappointed, upset, aggravated, insecure and often in dire stress.

Your government is fixing up a legacy out there of people who are getting hurt by your policies. All you ever say to us in this chamber is, `Oh, but we balanced the books.' That is an important goal, but it is not your goal as a government. Your main goal as a government is to make the lives and opportunities of Australians better. We are talking here about small business. We are talking about nearly one million small businesses. We are talking about six or seven million people who are employed and who work in small businesses. We are talking about the fundamental wealth of Australians. We are talking about businesses which are defined as being below 20 employees or below 100 if they are manufacturing. We are talking about the backbone of Australian commercial, family, cultural and community life.

These things we talk about, these things which were referred to in my previous motions—which grudgingly got through the Senate, with no help from the coalition—and which are going to get through today, hopefully, through Senator Cook's motion, are what matter to small business, not this carping, aggravated, resistant, whingeing grunge that I hear. For goodness sake, get out there and take this opportunity in both hands, because you have talked up the constituency, it has high expectations, and what is happening is that you have failed them so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this motion of Senator Cook's and I do so with considerable enthusiasm. I do so, unlike Senator Chapman, who I do not think got onto the second page of the motion, page 18, of the Notice Paper . Part of the motion does deal with the Yellow Pages index, Senator Chapman, that is true, and the comments of Dr Marsden. Over the page, it deals with the comments of the Australian Certified Practising Accountants, and then it deals with the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology report called Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia .

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that there was not much coverage in your remarks towards the recommendations of that report. I am not surprised. I think there are many Liberals—many coalition members—who would be dry economists, economic rationalists, who would find many of these recommendations too interventionist for any government, let alone a coalition government, even though those recommendations, if adopted, would clearly assist small business get a better deal in this community against the power of big business and other groups with large economic power.

I think it is most apt to move the motion this week when the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) is making a real mess of himself in trying to explain to the Australian parliament how he can be a major shopping centre owner, with several scores of tenants who are franchisees who are in retail tenancy arrangements with himself, explaining how he is the minister for small business responsible for instituting the report from the House of Representatives committee. He gave the committee its terms of reference. He made remarks at the end of last year about the range of issues that are in here, including retail tenancy issues, including franchising issues. He then says, `There is no conflict of interest.' When you examine his pecuniary interest list, he does not declare—and has not previously declared—that he was a significant shopping centre landlord.

As many commentators have written in today's and yesterday's press, if Mr Howard's ministerial code of conduct means anything, this minister should resign. He has misled the parliament in the conduct of what he has declared his interests are, and has clearly not been under Mr Howard's own rules—no‐one else's rules, but the rules that Mr Howard laid down that, if he was elected Prime Minister, this is what he would impose on all his ministers.

Clearly, there is a different rule for Mr Prosser than there is for most other ministers—or, conversely, the ministerial code of conduct, as announced at the last election by the then leader of the opposition, now Prime Minister, does not stand for anything. It is a disposable document. Now it is an embarrassment to the Prime Minister. He now has selective amnesia about its conditions and the rules that are in it. I think he probably feels that he is very lucky this Thursday to be in Great Britain. He will be able to enjoy himself at Lord's cricket ground rather than dealing with this issue of the conflict of interest that the present minister for small business has clearly got on this issue.

As a former minister for small business, I wanted to say that this is a report on which the coalition members had a clear majority in the House of Representatives, yet its recommendations are absolutely unanimous. I congratulate all members in the House of Representatives who put this report together and made unanimous recommendations. The recommendations, though occasionally worded differently, as Senator Cook pointed out, are absolutely in line with Mr Beazley's private member's bill that he introduced into the House of Representatives last year on unconscionable conduct and fair trading under the Trade Practices Act.

The recommendations are absolutely in line with the draft bill that I introduced into the parliament in late 1995 as minister for small business, a package which I called `Better business'. Every relevant small business organisation in Australia which was represented at the small business forum—some 30 plus—unanimously supported this package.

I notice that yesterday the so-called Small Business Coalition, which is administered by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry but represents a similar number of small business organisations—a very disparate group of small business organisations, who disagree with each other on many issues— unanimously endorsed every recommendation in this report, just as nearly two years ago they endorsed every recommendation of mine to amend the Trade Practices Act to strengthen the unconscionable conduct provisions to protect small business against the economic power of big business. There is not a word from any of the coalition speakers today about whether they support this report or not and/or the Small Business Coalition's unanimous support for these recommendations.

Senator Murray, in his remarks just finished, hit one nail very clearly on the head, amongst many that he clearly and accurately identified. He was dead right to say that the problem with the coalition is that some backbench members, and even some frontbench members, such as Senator Ron Boswell, who is a dedicated supporter of small business interests, will get rolled by the interests of big business, as represented by the Treasurer of this country, Mr Costello, and the big end of town coming out of Collins Street in Melbourne and Pitt Street in Sydney, particularly the big business Melbourne establishment.

I was consistently told on a number of occasions in 1995 by many people in the small business community, `Minister, we absolutely support your recommendations and the legislation. We will do everything to lobby the coalition to support it and to get it through quickly, but the problem you will have is that the big business interests in Melbourne and Sydney will put the weights on the coalition to run dead on it and not support it.' One would have thought that with a report such as the report now before us, Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia, and the recommendations unanimously put forward, the government would not wait several months to respond. They would be able to respond if they had all this knowledge and interest about small business in a matter of a very few weeks because every one of these issues has been debated in this parliament and in the Australian community for several years now.

BREAK.PARA: There is nothing in this report that is a surprise. The arguments about the amendments to the Trade Practices Act on unconscionable conduct have been debated endlessly. There is no constitutional or legislative surprise in here. I find it very instructive that the coalition government will wait several months before they even respond. What they are being told now by the big end of town in Melbourne is, `Forget it; can you find a way to let this document with these recommendations gather dust in some pigeon hole and let's just hope it drifts away.' That has been the track record of the coalition whenever there has been a move to strengthen the law to help small business where it really counts. They go on endlessly saying, `The only thing we're going to do is reduce paperwork.' They have not reduced the paperwork; they said they were going to reduce it by 50 per cent. There has been no indication that it has been reduced by five per cent, let alone by 50 per cent.

When Mr Prosser became minister after the last election he said that there would be 100 days of action for small business. There was no action in the first 15 months, let alone the first 100 days. We can see from the opposition side—and I think we have the support of the Democrats on this; in view of Senator Murray's remarks, I think he would absolutely agree—that this coalition government is trying to work out a way to have the report dropped in the bin and ignored. We will certainly make it an issue. We will certainly campaign on it. We endorse all of these recommendations because they are in line with the private member's bill that Mr Beazley introduced last year. They are in line with the Trade Practices Amendment (Better Business Conduct) Bill that I introduced in November 1995. There are a few minor word changes and so on, but the intent is absolute.

Where this minister, Mr Prosser, has made such a mess is in the franchising code area and in codes generally for things such as the petrol code. During 1995 I met with the petroleum industry. We had the big petrol companies on one side—the refiners—and the small retailers on the other side. I chaired a number of meetings to get them to accept a voluntary code so that both sides would agree to a code of conduct between them as franchisors and franchisees. It became clear to me that the only way that code could work is if it was underpinned by strengthening the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act so if there was a breach, a small business could go to the law and get remedy without going broke. That was clear. I indicated to the small business community and to the petroleum companies that that was why we wanted to amend the Trade Practices Act at the time.

I also indicated, despite the pressure from the petroleum companies, that we would not repeal the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act. I notice in this report that there is a specific recommendation not to repeal those two acts until the unconscionable conduct and the franchising amendments are already in place. If those two acts are repealed, and there is no amendment to the Trade Practices Act, the petrol retailers of Australia will be at the absolute mercy of the petrol companies. They will have no defence in the restructuring of their industry, and some of it will have to be restructured. Both sides agree that there are probably too many petrol retailers in this country. The way in which the restructuring is done, the small business people will not be left without any recompense for the lifetime of work they have put in to running those petrol stations.

This minister has failed at getting that code up. He does not understand that petrol retailers will not come on board unless these amendments go through first. Why would they? Why would they take on trust the word of the petroleum companies who, through multi‐site franchising and so on, are restructuring the industry and, in many cases, making offers to the petrol retailers of ridiculous and paltry sums to buy them out of remaining leases or when the lease runs out just saying, `Goodbye, your contribution to our industry and our company as an efficient franchisee comes to nothing'.

Let us turn to the franchising code itself. Last year, Minister Prosser had no idea what he was doing when he cut the money to the Franchising Code Administration Council of Australia. He collapsed that organisation, after we increased the funding to it at the request of the franchising industry so that the code, a voluntary code, could work where the franchisors would be registered and signed on to a code that outlined transparent rules of how to conduct a franchise arrangement in Australia. This minister, by saving $600,000, collapsed a voluntary code for a $40 billion industry. It is an astonishing decision. It showed that he did not know what he was doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or that he did know what he was doing.

—Last year I gave him the benefit of the doubt of stupidity. Now that I find out he is a major franchisor, a major retail landlord, maybe he had another motive, maybe he did understand what was going on.
—Senator Schacht, you cannot impute matters like that to another member of parliament. I ask you to withdraw that unreservedly and to withdraw the earlier statement about stupidity.
—Stupidity is a reasonable description of this minister.
—It is unparliamentary, Senator Schacht.

—I withdraw. When the minister made this decision, I thought he did not understand. I still think that is the best construction you could put on the decision. As a result, the franchising code of Australia collapsed. The 400 or 500 franchisors who tried to do the right thing and sign up to the code now have no code to sign up to and cannot say to their franchisees, `There is a genuine code here which we want to apply in the conduct of our business with you.' Some people in the industry say that they still apply that code voluntarily.

BREAK.PARA: This recommendation of the fair trading report makes it clear that there should be specific amendments of legislation, including unconscionable conduct, so that the code has intent, has a standing, and can be used to ensure that the economic power of big franchisors is not used against the power of small franchisees.

It is an astonishing thing that a coalition government that prides itself on supposedly helping small business would show such an abject lack of knowledge and allow a $40 billion industry code of practice to collapse for the sake of $600,000. It is also astonishing that they do not understand how the franchising industry works. If properly managed, franchising is an excellent way to encourage people to go into business because it has rules and arrangements that give them a better chance of success—but only if it is properly organised and only with proper transparency in the rules. This minister has overwhelmingly failed in those two areas.

I now want to turn to the Yellow Pages report that came out on 27 May. When Senator Chapman spoke in the debate, he made a number of remarks which Senator Cook and I found provocative, and you, Mr Acting Deputy President, quite rightly pulled us up and said that remarks should be made through you, that interjections were disorderly. The reason Senator Cook and I got quite agitated about the remarks of Senator Chapman is that he was implying that we did not know what we were reading, that we did not understand what was in this report. In his press release, Dr Marsden, in the third paragraph, third sentence, says:
In line with this finding, more than 80 per cent of small businesses see the economy as being in recession or at a standstill.

I find that unambiguous. Senator Chapman tried to claim we were misquoting that figure. When I was small business minister I had the honour of launching, on behalf of Yellow Pages, the first survey results. When Yellow Pages came to me and told me that they were establishing a databank where about 1,100 businesses across Australia would be surveyed on a quarterly basis—properly and statistically balanced—with some additions and some deletions every quarter to make sure that the same businesses were not being surveyed, I said, `I think that is an excellent idea.' Every government of the day—this parliament—should welcome any information it can get about what is going on in small business.

As small business minister, I had to occasionally put up with criticism in the Senate when small business surveys came out that had results in them that were not comforting for the then Labor government. I never bagged the report. I may have disagreed with some interpretation, but I never attacked the validity and statistical basis of these reports. I knew that you could not do that because they were structured on a basis of transparency which could not be questioned; although you could certainly question the interpretation occasionally. Overwhelmingly, I took my lumps as well as my cheers when the reports came out—sometimes with good news for the then federal government, sometimes with bad or modest results for the federal government.

So when this government stands up and says, `This report is being misinterpreted by the opposition,' that is just nonsense. When they try to destroy the credibility of this report, that is just nonsense. This report is an excellent one and cannot be ignored. Clearly, from quarter to quarter, there will be different trends. But one line in the report which says:
. . . more than 80 per cent of small businesses see the economy as being in recession or at a standstill—

is unambiguous in its description of why small business has a lack of confidence in our economy. That is why there is no growth and no increase in employment—small business does not have confidence. This shows it. I hope that the government learns from such surveys and adopts some initiatives to encourage growth of at least four per cent to get growth in the economy and jobs going, as they overwhelmingly will come to the small business sector.

I support Senator Cook's motion. It is a very apt motion and I commend it to the Senate. All I know is that this government has let down one segment of the Australian community which it promised everything to in the last election. It has not delivered. This is just the beginning of the debate, and the opposition will bring this government to book over how it has failed small business so miserably.

BREAK.PARA: Small business is only too aware of how they were savaged by the previous government with high interest rates, fixed rates of up to 17 per cent, overdrafts of 20 per cent to 25 per cent and the Laurie Brereton unfair dismissal laws—you have heard that a few times in this chamber.
