Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that just an interjection, Senator Conroy, or are you trying to get a serious message across?
—Just an interjection.

—I will not take it as a serious interjection. I would like to take my full time, if I can, to outline our government's performance. If small business employed just one extra person, we would not have an unemployment problem. To that end, we have put in a strategy to encompass that motto that we hold dear.

BREAK.PARA: Almost the first thing we did when we came into government was to introduce the Workplace Relations Bill to totally abolish, totally get rid of, the unfair dismissal laws and also to introduce far more flexible and workable workplace agreements. Added to that, we brought in many tax relief policies directly targeted to small business, going to the heart of their bottom line. We could not have done it quickly enough. Regardless of how this Senate obstructs this government's legislation, miraculously we have almost been able to get through our tax policy for small business.

In our first term we reduced the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent, which is calculated as $80 million worth of tax relief for small business. The introduction of the capital gains tax rollover from 1 July 1997 is going to allow small business with assets of $5 million or less to be sold or the assets of the business to be sold and rolled over into another business. Also, the small businesses with remittances of less than $25,000 from 1 July 1998 will now be able to pay quarterly rather than monthly. This is an estimated $500 million cash flow advantage for small business in the years 1998‐99.

We have abolished the fringe benefits tax on taxis to and from work for small business. We have abolished the fringe benefits tax on car parking, which was one of the great frustrations of business and had an enormous compliance cost to it. We have kicked out about half of the account keeping requirements for small business.

These sorts of advancements have all gone to the bottom line of small business in a very short time. But we have not just rested on our laurels in regard to tax reform. We have now opened up the debate for major tax reform in this country—and not before time. It took a coalition government to have the courage and the dare to raise this debate in the public forum. We have done this because we know only too well that our tax system has its difficulties and it cannot go on in its existing form. It has three major failings. Firstly, the tax burden falls overly on business inputs in ways that damage competitiveness. Secondly, it allows so much scope for avoidance, particularly the cash economy. Thirdly, the revenue base is eroding away, which the parliament is well aware of.

But we also acknowledge that tax reform in itself is not enough. The burden of the cost of money is also a high priority of small business—namely, interest rates. BREAK.PARA: All this has placed a downward pressure on interest rates. It has given confidence to the Reserve Bank that we are serious about maintaining a balanced budget in surplus so that they can carry out their job of maintaining low inflation and reducing interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that small business in this country does feel betrayed. Here in the ACT we had an example of not only a prominent member of the information technology business community but the Vice President of the ACT branch of the Liberal Party actually resigning in disgust from the Liberal Party as a direct result of their appalling policies in relation to small business. I think that that, above anything else, is the greatest indictment upon this government because, effectively, what Mr Cadogan‐Cowper said was that he was a member of the Liberal Party because he believed the Liberal Party represented the interests of small business.

BREAK.PARA: When Mr Cadogan‐Cowper resigned from the Liberal Party he said that he was totally disillusioned with the government of Prime Minister John Howard. This same person was once an adviser to former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser! In running his computer business now, he made these observations from a point of view of a commitment to small business in Australia and a belief in a party he felt and understood to be committed to that sector.
He said he had tried to get the message through to the federal government without success. He said:

They have stopped listening. They don't have an industry policy. They are putting representatives of big business on committees to investigate small business. I've got to the position where I can no longer tell people the Liberal Party is the best option. We really don't know what we're doing.

Mr Cadogan‐Cowper went on to state that there was little coordination between ministries and that he was deeply troubled by the threat to the privacy of Australians, as confidential information about them would be sent overseas to be processed by multinational companies.

I will leave it there but, in my opening remarks on this issue, that—above anything else—is one of the greatest indictments of this government and their business. This is a sector of small business that is critical to future growth. At this point in time, what other industry has the potential that information technology has to grow, expand and establish itself in the global economy? And what greater indictment of the government is there than the changes to the incentives for small business with respect to research and development, with respect to the syndication system and the EMDG in promoting and allowing small businesses to expand and improve themselves? All those measures taken by this Liberal government in reducing that support for small business have been felt very hard by small business. If they were not directly affected, it still sends small businesses a very clear message that they are not on the priority list of this Liberal government.

One of the more interesting observations I have been privy to recently was a report called The knowledge economy, which states the fact that to invest in industry development and the growth of small business is to invest in the whole economy. Specifically targeted industry development programs have the effect of benefiting a whole economy. To take away such benefits has a synergistic effect of decline in that sector. The net effect of taking away three programs with respect to incentives for R&D is worse than it appears to be on paper. For those reasons, small business is quite frightened about this government, which got elected, effectively, on the back of private sector industry, which has now been betrayed by that government.

One of the biggest decisions taken by this government that is impacting on the sector I want to focus on—information technology—is the decision by the Minister for Finance, Mr Fahey, to outsource a significant proportion of government work. Apart from all the implications relating to the flawed justification behind that activity itself, it is a very interesting exercise to analyse the way the government is handling this outsourcing process, if you look at the implications for small Australian businesses and for large transnationals in that sector. It is a good case study, because it epitomises this government's approach to business in Australia. The evidence—as I work through it—will demonstrate that there is a massive weighting towards the interests of large corporations against those of small indigenous Australian businesses. I am using one example in the IT sector, but you would find similar stories elsewhere. This is something the small business sector is just starting to realise the full implications of.

Minister Fahey has structured the process of outsourcing of IT to effectively discriminate against indigenous companies. I do not make this assertion just off the cuff but on the basis that I have studied the Hansard transcript of the estimates hearings of the committee which looked into the government department handling this process. As part of the Department of Finance, the Office of Government Information Technology have put on the public record the guidelines within which they are operating in their consideration of the outsourcing of the IT business.

The first quote I will give is from the hearings of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee on 3 June, 1997. This goes to the issue of what preconditions the Minister for Finance places on contracts for the potential vendors who are going to be tendering for the IT outsourcing contracts. I asked Mr Macdonald, the Chief of the Office of Government information Technology:
To what degree of formality has the minister provided advice that regional employment initiatives will actually constitute a favourable assessment to potential tenderers?
Mr Macdonald responded:

There have been no tender documents yet so there has been no formal advice. We would anticipate that in the tender documents there would be reference to the fact that the government considers the involvement of SMEs and regional development to be important aspects of the bid. Opportunities to leverage the investment in the Asia‐Pacific region to create jobs in Australia would be favourably looked at as well.

That statement, by its very definition, would suggest that small to medium enterprises have been overlooked in getting in on the first base. The implication of that is that some involvement with them would be desirable—and Minister Fahey has gone on the public record to that effect as well—but they have been excluded already.

With respect to that, I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a statement Mr Fahey made which was quoted by Senator Kemp at the estimates hearings of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee:

It is important to note that part of the criteria for the outsourcers will be to demonstrate a commitment to providing employment in regional Australia and a capacity to partner with local small and medium information technology companies.

Again, that reinforces the point. It seems to me that the minister had already decided that small to medium Australian IT companies were going to be excluded from the opportunity to tender for these large contracts.

The point I would like to make is that capability is one thing, but the government have specifically structured those IT outsourcing contracts on a cluster basis, which means those contracts can only be dealt with by partnership arrangements or by a large firm. So by the way they have structured the whole process, they have excluded local industry.

The government have also not allowed enough time for industry or market development to occur so Australian businesses can get themselves in the position to tender for these large contracts. This clustering arrangement came effectively out of the blue and, while it has been discussed for quite some time, it is effectively a mechanism to make it very hard for local indigenous IT firms to compete for those contracts.

In terms of what happens next and the future of those small to medium enterprises in that sector, it is interesting to note that, when challenged on this point, the Office of Government Information Technology responded with comments to the effect that they recognised this was an issue. Mr Macdonald indicated that they had engaged the cooperation of the Australian Information Industries Association to help them resolve some of these issues.

It is interesting to note that, now they are starting to receive complaints from IT firms in this area, they are not turning to their own policy makers, their own bureaucratic structures or the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser)—who knows where he is in this process—they are actually going to the industry association and saying, `You'd better help us out here because we haven't got it right. Provide us with some advice.' It seems to me that that is the lazy way out and it shows they have missed the mark. They have to now go back to the industry and seek a process that will allow them to squirm out of this disastrous situation they have got themselves into.

In terms of opportunity provided to these companies, there is no doubt that the complaints have been falling on deaf ears. I would like to turn to some quotes made by industry representatives with respect to these problems. On 13 May the Australian reported that the outgoing manager of Oracle, Mr Neil Weston, in response to a question about the outsourcing initiative, particularly in the UK, said, `Some people are comfortable with it and some aren't.' The journalist's interpretation of subsequent comments made by Mr Weston was:
The change meant some companies would have to significantly invest in their businesses to meet the demands of government contracts.
Because of this, many tenders would not be won by local companies but by multinationals.
Mr Weston went on to comment:
If not handled properly, it will create many problems and generate friction between the successful bidders and the losers.

Mr David Merson, the managing director and founder of Queensland developer Mincom, said that he was concerned about the procurement policy, as it could be biased towards multinational policies. An IT consultant, Mr Crisp, in an article also from the Australian on that same day, was quoted as saying:
The smaller specialist IT companies will do well to hone their skills to work better with the big companies.
A director at another company was quoted as saying:
In Australia, this market sector is growing at twice the rate of the rest of the world.

That was in response to the actual IT consultancy sector. We are not talking about an industry that is in trouble. We are not talking about a small business sector that is floundering in the market. We are talking about a vital sector. From those quotes, you can see that the perception out there in the industry is that the small business end of that sector is being left out in the cold by this government in favour of the interests of the larger companies.

I would like to take the opportunity to focus more narrowly on a particular occurrence with respect to IT. This does not relate specifically to these information technology cluster contracts; it goes back a bit further than that and relates to the situation that a records management software company—GMB Research and Development Pty Ltd—found themselves in as a result of some of the decision making of the Office of Government Information Technology.

To put this in context, remember that we are not talking about government policy impacting on the private sector per se and trying to put in place mechanisms to trigger growth or enhance investment. We are talking about government contracts and we are talking about procurement policy. So this is one of the opportunities the government really has to foster and grow small business.

This issue involves the portfolio of the finance minister, who you would think would have more of a grip on the potentiality of the growth of the small business sector. It is interesting to note, I have to say, that Minister Prosser—who is supposed to be representing small business—is nowhere to be seen and is deaf to the complaints and the concerns of small business in this area.

Anyway, let me give the Senate a little background on this issue. GMB are a 100 per cent Australian company. They are profitable, they are debt free and they have had all the government appropriate endorsements and approvals with respect to procurement under the Commonwealth government, and every other state and local government, as I understand it. Their product is used in every state in Australia, the UK, the USA and Canada. They have customers all around the world. But for some reason this company's product was rejected by the Office of Government Information Technology on the grounds that it failed to meet a mandatory requirement.

The company have put out a public statement which opens with the comment, `OGIT opens Australian market to foreign companies and shuts market for (previously successful) Australian companies'. Not only did this company lose out previously, but also this company have been left off the select tender list with respect to their product. They claim that they are not the only ones—that these lists are now dominated by firms associated with transnational companies; and that they, along with many other Australian companies who have proven success in this area, have effectively been cut out. GMB have had no other recourse but to take this issue to the Federal Court, and that action is proceeding. They believe they have been treated unfairly by OGIT. Not only are they concerned with respect to their case, but also they have raised questions with respect to process in handling that.

So here we have an example of where the government has the ability to treat Australian companies with equity. We are asking not for favours, but equity. We find that companies are challenging the government's ability to do that and are claiming that they are being excluded unfairly from that process. What is becoming very clear with respect to information technology in Australia is that, unless you are associated with one of the large transnational companies, you have not got a hope of securing what has in the past constituted—(Quorum formed)

I would just like to make a couple of concluding remarks with respect to this motion regarding small business. Quite clearly this government's interest in representing business does not fall into the small business category; it falls into the large business category—that is becoming obvious. To see that, you only need to look at comments about any changes to taxation that will equate with a reduction in the tax of large business. I will conclude on this point, and I quote from the statement by GMB Research and Development Pty Ltd:

Why isn't RecFind, arguably the world's best records management product with a thousand major sites across Australia, New Zealand, the UK and the USA, good enough for OGIT? Doesn't anyone in government care that OGIT is intent on destroying our indigenous software industry? Where is Mr Howard, the champion of small business, now?
(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Heffernan, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been curious in recent months as to why Senator Peter Cook has been coming into the chamber all hot and flustered after returning from the gym. I can see why; the opposition is considering providing a team for Australia's Olympic gymnastics squad, because today Senator Cook and his mates over there are considering doing a gigantic backflip.
—That was a long lead into a pretty weak joke.

—It has presented you with a pretty big challenge, Senator Collins. You can demonstrate on the floor of the chamber, if you like. Today Senator Cook is calling for the immediate implementation of the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology report entitled Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia . What a turnaround!

SPEECH.PARA: In 1990 the government was presented with a report titled Small business in Australia: challenges, problems and opportunities. Chaired by David Beddall, the report recommended, among other things, the introduction of legislation to protect franchisees from franchisors. What did Labor do about it? Not a damn thing, of course—not even when the chairman and the author of the recommendations became the minister for small business! In an interview on 20 May 1990, Maxine McKew asked:
In terms of specific government help for small business, I think your report prepared something like 66 recommendations. How many of those are likely to see the light of day?
In response, Beddall said:
We don't really want to see the success of this ministry being judged on if you've got 51 or 39 recommendations—
up. The minister's report was hardly cold when he was backing away from his own recommendations.
I will tell the Senate how we can judge Labor's small business ministry, and that is on its record. And its record is poor.

In 1994 the Gardini report saw a similar fate to the Beddall report. Once again, Labor ignored recommendations for legislation relating to franchisees. But the backflips started not in 1990 or 1994 but in fact back in 1986, when Labor dropped two draft bills from the legislative program.

So what can we make of Senator Cook's motion today? It is a poor attempt at cheap political opportunism, especially if we ask him to go back to his own party platform and explain their support for self-regulation in this industry.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Schacht, in his part in the debate today, promised to support the government to deliver the recommendations of the report through legislation, but why didn't Schacht—I notice he has had his ears lowered also—support the earlier recommendations when he was minister for small business?

The coalition government is not backing way from anything. Its commitment to small business is on the record. So too is the government's delivery on its commitment. We have given small business capital gains tax relief. Small business owners will be able to gain relief from the capital gains tax when they sell a business to expand and buy a similar business.
We have reduced Labor's paper burden on small business, giving hardworking Australians more time to get on with their business.

We have reduced Labor's legacy of high interest rates—and don't I know it—crippling to small business. I remind the Senate that four official interest rate cuts have occurred since we came to government 16 months ago.

The opposition certainly should look red‐faced and uneasy in their chairs over there. All that all bar a few of them have known in life is a union delegateship. They know nothing about small business; they know nothing about the bush.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stick to the script.

—But wait, there's more, Senator McKiernan. We have scrapped Labor's unfair dismissal laws. Our legislation ensures a fair go all round, for bosses and their workers. But we will never say, `This is as good as it gets.' This government will continue to address the problems facing small business as they continue to recover from one of the most prolonged recessions that Australia has ever had—the recession that the former Treasurer said we had to have.

BREAK.PARA: We did not create the problem; but we have taken responsibility for solving it. Our solutions are medium‐ to long‐term solutions—not short-term pastings. This government is listening to small business, evident through the small business task force and the microbusiness consultative group. We are not saying it is not tough out there. Of course it is tough. But, when the flowthrough effect of our reform reaches small business, it will be easier—and hopefully we will also get a shower of rain in the Riverina!

The report Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia is receiving the attention it is due from this government. A response will come within three months from tabling, after full consultation with all parties involved, including federal ministers and the states. However, the opposition is getting all hot under the collar over state responsibilities. The report has 12 recommendations relating to retail tenancy. Regulation here rests with the states.

If the opposition have forgotten what Commonwealth responsibilities are, they are kidding themselves if they think they can manage government. I pity small business and the rest of this country if they manage to con their way back in. The former government failed small business, evident in the very index they are quoting today. In February 1996, the Yellow Pages Small business index reported a rating of minus 61 per cent. That is 59 per cent worse than the current index—59 per cent!

Now that they are in opposition they are trying to pass themselves off as the champions of small business, the party for the battler. They were too good for the everyday Australian. That is why all their mates were the high‐flying entrepreneurs of the 1980s who got rich off the back of ordinary Australians. Now all their mates are in the can or overseas hiding, and they are out there looking for some new mates. They will not find them. Our policies, initiatives and reforms are helping the small businesses that Labor neglected.

Why has the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) been so successful in helping small business? Because, unlike Labor, he knows what it is all about. To hide their own inadequacies, Labor knock a man because he is good at what he does. They knock a man who built a successful business, starting as a mechanic on the work shop floor. Without fail, the opposition knock at any opportunity just for the sake of opposition.

The Yellow Pages Small business index is a regular favourite. As soon as it is out, there they are spouting the results—but not, as Senator McGauran said earlier, all of them. Although the information contained in this report is interesting—and I will get to some of it shortly—the opposition should not put that much weight on it. I could not agree more with Senator Schacht's comments this afternoon that `the more information the government can get the better'. However, Senator, once again you and the Labor Party fell short when you had the chance, because the index does not survey the small business men and women from the backbone of our economy: the farmers, the members of an industry which includes fishing, farming, forestry and mining, which continues to contribute 75 per cent of Australia's net external earnings.

But, again, it is not unusual that Labor ignores the bush. The Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, thinks Canberra is regional Australia. The worn‐out union delegates opposite think the bush is two trees in their backyard. They know nothing of the bush. Their former leader thought pigs could fly!

Senator Murray thinks all farmers are rich. He is out of touch with the transfer of wealth that occurred in the 1970s from the bush to the city. I invite him and Senator Collins to spend a week in my state of New South Wales with the farmers who are struggling to educate their kids as El Nino and another bad year approach. That is as far off the mark as the propaganda that says that pastoralists of Australia are all Sultans of Brunei. Unfortunately, the Democrats have got to refer to the Parliamentary Library to learn where the bush is.

As I said, I find some results of the index worth reporting in this place. The most recent Yellow Pages small index reports that 62 per cent of businesses now expect to expand, as Senator McGauran said earlier. That is good news for small business. Sixty‐one per cent of businesses expect an improvement in profita bility over the next 12 months. That is good news for small business. What is good for small business is good for Australia.

To say that Labor can support small business and understand what small business is about when they are entirely composed of a generation of gurus from the union world, a party that applies the same rules to super‐unions as it does to super‐business, is absurd and obnoxious to the ordinary Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President Foreman, this is the first occasion I have had to speak in the chamber when you have been in the chair. Congratulations on your elevation to the exalted position of Acting Deputy President of the Senate. I am sure you will do a very good job of providing me with the protection I sometimes need from the people opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend Senator Cook for bringing this motion to the chamber tonight. It is a motion that is in a number of parts. It notes the recent Yellow Pages Small business index—not `small index', as Senator Heffernan called it—and notes also a very important report that has been recently presented in the other place by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology—a report called Finding a balance. It is not only a very useful document now but it will be useful for quite a period of time.

It is a useful document but it is also a very sad document. For those people who have not had an opportunity to read it, I particularly draw their attention to those stories from those people in small business who have suffered, and suffered dramatically and suffered dreadfully, at the hands of big business, at the hands of the owners of shopping centres where they have tried to run their businesses and from which they have been run out.

It is very unfortunate that the minister who started the inquiry, who gave carriage of the inquiry to the committee, jumped the gun and, only five days after the report was tabled, actually came in and said that he was not going to accept the suggestions and recom mendations contained in the report. It was reported in the Weekend Australian of 31 May on page 2 of an article by Natasha Bita under the headline `No to Franchise Law Code'. The minister jumped the gun. We know since why the minister has jumped the gun. That has been revealed in the last few weeks.

Before I get on to that, I do want to correct one of the things that the previous speaker, Senator Heffernan, had to say in talking about Mr Beddall, a previous minister for small business. He indicated that nothing was done about the Beddall report Challenges, problems and opportunities. That is completely and utterly false. Indeed something was done. The author of the report, who later became Minister Beddall, actually listened to industry, listened to the franchisers, and at their request introduced a voluntary code of conduct. I think you have to give credit where credit is due. The minister of the day did act. After consulting with small business, after consulting with franchisers, he acted on their wishes.

A parliamentary committee not led by a member of the Labor Party has now said in a unanimous report that the voluntary code has had its day and it is now time to move on; the franchisees now want protection. It is a very serious recommendation of this report of the committee chaired by Mr Bruce Reid. Unfortunately, the minister has tossed that out.

There have been suggestions around this place that, because we in the opposition and others have asked questions about the minister's declarations of interest, we are actually attacking him. I do not think we are attacking him, either because he is a minister or because he has a successful small business. I had the opportunity of meeting Mr Prosser before either of us came into this place. We were adversaries: I was from the trade union side; he was from business. We were talking about matters of industrial relations. We were able to have reasonable conversations and after the conversations were over we were able to speak, and I suggest that even after this debate is finished Geoff Prosser and I will still be able to exchange civil words.

BREAK.PARA: That is not to say that we cannot question the information that Mr Prosser puts into his declarations of interest. That is not to say that we cannot, in asking questions about what Mr Prosser declares to the public and declares to the parliament, question the Prime Minister's code of conduct. When I asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, a question earlier this week, he interpreted my question as being an attack on Mr Prosser. It was far from an attack on Mr Prosser. Among the questions I asked was this:

It is also a fact that Mr Prosser has failed to fully declare his business interests in the register of members' interests and has retained company directorships which conflict with his public duty, in defiance of the Prime Minister's code?

That is a simple question, not a personal attack on the individual at all. I did not get a proper answer from Senator Hill but I did get a proper answer from the Prime Minister himself. The Prime Minister's answer was reported the next day in the Canberra Times and other media. The headline to the article in that paper says, `Howard reallocates retail tenancy role as Opposition turns up the heat.'

The Prime Minister, in taking that action that was reported in the Canberra Times on Tuesday 17 June, was agreeing that what was happening previously was not in accord with his particular code of conduct and he, to his commendation, belatedly took action to rectify the situation. Senator Hill, in response to the question, said that he understood that Mr Prosser had maintained his records in the register in accordance with his obligations and in the terms of the register. Attention has been brought to that and how it was noted in the register of members' interests. Apart from the residences that Mr Prosser holds, he did list that he held, in the city of Bunbury, in my home state of Western Australia, various lots. It states `Bunbury—various lots' and the purpose for which these various lots is listed is `commercial, investment and rental'. It would have been more honest to say that Mr Prosser actually owned three shopping cen tres—not one, not two, three shopping centres—which were commercial properties with about 80 tenants in them.

Why would the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, take action on the same day as I asked my question and reallocate ministerial responsibility for retail tenancy? Why would he do that if Mr Prosser was acting in accord with the Prime Minister's code of conduct? I would suggest that the reason is quite obvious: the Prime Minister, after having his attention drawn to the matter in the press, in the parliament and in other places, realised that, no, Mr Prosser was not acting in accord with the code of conduct. The Prime Minister, after putting down a code of conduct which he expected, and indeed instructed, his ministers to comply with and abide by, realised that one of his ministers was not complying with that particular code of conduct and he did take action to ensure that the code of conduct would be complied with.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian National Railways Commission: Equal Employment Opportunity Program

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to raise concerns that I have with what is happening in the railways at a federal level in this country and I wonder about the impact that this may well have on equal employment opportunity. The proposed sale of a number of railways is of grave concern to many communities. It is leading to a great deal of upset, concern and worry about the future of a number of these places and these communities. There are many small communities in Australia whose livelihood depends on the lifeline of the east‐west rail link through Broken Hill from Sydney to Perth. It is of major importance.

The city of Broken Hill has rail services from both Adelaide and Sydney. People may say, `Oh, they can catch a bus.' Having talked to Broken Hill people, and having visited there on many occasions, I know that they do not like the bus service. It is a long bus trip. A bus trip from Broken Hill to Sydney takes more than 12 hours. That is a very long trip. If you get cramps, if you are old, if you need to move around, or if you have young children, it is very disruptive and very hard for people to travel in this way. Even the trip to Adelaide is five to six hours, and that is a lengthy trip.

Elderly people also have problems getting on and off buses and moving around buses when the buses are moving. If you are getting on a train at Broken Hill, you walk up a very gradual ramp straight onto the train. You do not have to climb stairs, you do not have to climb high steps, and this is something that many people in Broken Hill have expressed their concerns to me about. It is an issue that I know that the people of Broken Hill will continue to canvass very hard and continue to push very hard for.

The people of Broken Hill fear that, if there is the sale of AN, the train may not run through Broken Hill. They fear that the Indian Pacific may in fact start to run via Melbourne and Adelaide. Whilst we do not have any problems with trains running through Melbourne and Adelaide, people in the western parts of New South Wales will have trouble if they lose a rail service.

On that line between Parkes and Broken Hill, you have a small community called Ivanhoe. The only all‐weather land means of access to that town is on the rail. Even the Cobb Highway, which is a main highway in this country that runs to and from Ivanhoe, is a dirt road. It is a black soil road, and, if you get more than about 10 points of rain, it is impassable. So the rail link from Ivanhoe becomes an exceedingly important link for those people to be able to get in and out, to get produce in and out, and to be able to get fresh food and goods and services in and out.

Their nearest major centre in terms of health care is Broken Hill. The flying doctor operates that service, but the flying doctor is not a taxi service for family members. Therefore, people who have families who are in hospital in Broken Hill will often use the rail link, and particularly so if there has been rain and inclement weather. I think it is a very important issue that people should look at very carefully.

With the sale and privatisation of companies, one also has to look very carefully to see whether there are going to be any requirements in there to maintain equal opportunity programs. Less control and fewer restrictions can be placed on the organisations, and less encouragement can be given to the organisations that may take over the company to uphold, in a very true and meaningful way, EEO programs and EEO commitments. That is of major importance to people who are in the industry. This is a very important service that runs, and that is provided, to a lot of people in western parts of New South Wales and other remote areas of Australia. I urge people to watch this problem very closely.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The report from the Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council entitled Foundations for Australia's future: science and technology in primary schools is a very important report. Having one of my children at primary school, I have seen the impact of both science and technology on my young daughter, who currently is in year 7. If science is presented in a fair and reasonable way, children react in a spontaneous and positive way to science. I have seen this happen in particular at my daughter's school in more recent times.

Whilst there is a growing focus on the issue of technology, this report sounds a bit of an alarm for us, in that I doubt that we are paying the due attention that needs to be paid to our young people in the development of both science and technology. It is pertinent to look at the introduction in the report, which says:

Raising children who are well prepared to cope with life in a future world is not an easy task. There can be little doubt though that their education is a vital component of this upbringing. While the value of the `three Rs' is undeniable, the totality of the knowledge and skills that today's children will require over the course of their lives is difficult for most of us to imagine. Their world will, however, be no less complex than ours, or the role of science and technology in their daily lives any the less significant.

That encapsulates the dilemma that our society is in today. Whilst there is a focus on the three R's, there is a real need for our young children in their formative years to develop an understanding of science and technology.

I have not read this report in its entirety, but I have read enough to understand the effort that has been put in by the various participants. In its main finding, it came to the conclusion that there is a strong level of support among school principals, parents, teachers and children for primary science and technology education. On page 11, in table 1, the report refers to `Principals' and parents' goals for primary science and technology education'. It has ranked in order a number of categories that the committee believes should be achieved.

It is interesting to look at the priorities. In the top three, it lists: understanding scientific or technological concepts; developing an inquiring mind; and developing problem solving skills. Those three areas rank as the top for primary science and technology education. To a lesser degree in rank, it lists: learning about scientific or technological achievements; encouragement to be innovative; link/apply science or technology to everyday life; and gain knowledge and skills as a basis for future citizenship. So the report focuses on developing that understanding which, I believe, is so important in giving our children a very basic but, nonetheless, good education.

One of the disturbing features of the report, though, was that it was found that there was a disparity between the in-principle support for science and technology and that which occurs in practice. Firstly, while some people are fairly good in talking about the need for this, there is a reluctance on the part of some to do anything about it. Secondly, only four per cent of teaching time in a weekly timetable was found to be devoted to both science and technology. There are gaps; there is a long way to go. This report should be taken seriously and it should be something that people pay attention to for the betterment of our young people.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 June, on motion by Senator Forshaw:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the report of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee entitled Helping Australians abroad: a review of the Australian government's consular services . I have been in this place for about seven years. I have served on many committees and have had to deal with a number of very sad and difficult committee reports. This would be one of the hardest ones and in some cases we have had to deal with some of the saddest things we have ever had to deal with.

SPEECH.PARA: This was a report brought about by some people because they felt that the response they had got from Australia's consular officials had been less than they desired and expected. Some of these involved deaths of family members in circumstances that were traumatic, that were highly publicised, including the Wilson case and a number of others, that were very sad and that caused the families a lot of grief. It was also hard committee work because, in questioning these people about their concerns to come to some conclusions, we had to not aggravate or intensify their upset.

I think it is a very good report. It is a unanimous report of the committee. There were some recommendations and findings on which some members would have placed a different weight of emphasis, but it is a very good and comprehensive report.

I pay tribute to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for the assistance, time and effort they put in in providing information and a very lengthy submission to the committee on this inquiry. Unlike the submission that they did not provide for Radio Australia, this time they provided a very significant and huge submission. During the time of the inquiry they also took action to change and improve their processes and practices that had originally been in place.

It was a difficult inquiry because we had a number of cases that dealt with deaths in families. When we called for submissions we found that not all of the families wished to make submissions because they did not feel that they had any problems with the assistance they had been given by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. We also found that families ranged from being antagonistic towards the department to being very grateful for the assistance that the department had also given.

Everybody needs to recognise that the death of a close member of a family is a very painful and traumatic experience in the best of times. When it occurs overseas and when it occurs in circumstances where reports appear in the media for weeks on end, it must be doubly or trebly more painful for those families. They cannot grieve privately because they do not know what is going on. It must be an extremely difficult time for them.

One of the things that I hope come out of this is that some mechanism will be set up, though not necessarily by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, because I do not think they are the people to do it. But civil authorities at the state levels must look at how they provide support to grieving families, particularly in the circumstances that we heard about.

We also heard of some of the expectations that the community has of what types of services Foreign Affairs should be supplying. We often get into strife as members of parliament for being frequent travellers around the world. But I am sure that most of you here have heard stories from foreign posts about some of the phone calls that they have had, with people saying, `Please help me; I'm at a border. I haven't got a visa, but you can come and fix me up.' There are totally unrealistic expectations on the part of Australians travelling overseas as what our consular officials are able to do.

I think it is very important for people to realise that when they go overseas they cease to be the subject of Australian law and become the subject of the law that operates in the country they are in. In some of the countries that they choose to travel in—particularly some of the adventurous people—the laws are very vague, the laws may be open to local interpretation and the laws may not be upheld.

There are other areas in this world, whether we like it or not, that are trouble spots—where there is instability, where there are rebels, where there is fighting, where people are taken hostage, where people are murdered and where the price of life is very low. People in other areas sometimes do not place the same sanctity on life as we do and as those in the Western world do.

That was very much the case with the Wilsons—David Wilson and a national from France and a national from England were captured by the Khmer Rouge and ended up being killed. We only have to go back and look at what Pol Pot did in the killing fields. I for one would not want to ever meet a Khmer Rouge fighter on their territory, because for them life is not very precious. They choose to kill their own people in cold blood, in large numbers and for very trivial crimes. They do not place the same sanctity on life as Australians do.

That is something that people need to be conscious of. On occasions, people visit places where this is the situation. They have to be aware that if they get into trouble in some areas there is very little anybody can do to get them out, particularly if they are visitors. If they have lived in an area or worked with a non-government organisation and have built up some very close personal relations with local people, then it may well be a different situation.

During this inquiry, shortly before the Wilson kidnapping, we heard that there had been an American female NGO taken hostage and she was released. But she had been working with an organisation out in the field for some considerable time and was known and liked by the local people. They were able, at the local level, to exert more power and more pressure.

Hostage cases raise the issue: do you pay a ransom or do you not pay a ransom? That is a very hard question for people to have to answer. It is even harder for the families of people who may well be the hostages. Very difficult decisions have to be made.

Getting away from those sorts of traumatic times, it is vitally important that people remember that the services that can be provided by Australian consular officials are limited by what can be afforded. They are limited also by the position and the placement of consular offices. We do not have consular offices in every country in the world. We have developed a very close relationship with Canada and actually have official reciprocal representation agreements so that in a number of places Australia provides consular support for Australian nationals and Canadian nationals, and vice versa. We also get a lot of support in some areas from the UK consular offices, and in a number of other places the US one helps as well.

The report also deals with child custody and the Hague convention. It is a great pity that, with an increasing number of breakdowns in marriages, we see an increasing number of abductions of children—children being removed out of Australia and being brought into Australia. Australia has signed the Hague convention, which means there are reciprocal treaties that are recognised by the 40-odd countries that have signed it. But many more countries need to sign that Hague convention so that children can be returned to the jurisdiction under which the original orders were given.

There is a need also for people who are travelling overseas to recognise the need for insurance. If you cannot afford the insurance you cannot afford to travel. There is a need also to look at how the information in travel advices is spread around, and there are some recommendations relating to that. I suspect, on occasions, that some travel agents—maybe not very many, but a few—are not terribly fussed about making sure that the general public know about travel advices because they are in the business of selling trips and tours to places and these travel advices could well be warning people about the dangers of going to a place. The Internet is being used. They are going to be using more—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report Helping Australians abroad: a review of the Australian government's consular services as a member of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee, along with Senator West. Senator West has said many things about this report which I am totally in agreement with. It was, as Senator West has alluded to, a particularly difficult inquiry that we conducted. I do not know if some of the participants who had very well-founded personal dispositions really understood that the panel of senators before them were sympathetic towards their problems. At times I think it became very difficult for them to realise that we were really sympathetic to some of the problems that were confronting them.

SPEECH.PARA: They had lost loved ones overseas, they were not there at the time of the loss of their loved ones and they were feeling a grief, as Senator West has outlined, that we could not really relate to ourselves. However, I did share a real sympathy with them. This is not really something that comes out in this report. The problem with a report such as this is that it can never express the emotion or the sadness that is part and parcel of those people's lives. I just want it recorded here, whilst they will not hear these words, to let it be known that there is a real sympathy with these people, a real empathy with them, as to what they have been through. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TITLE.XREF: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (INTERCEPTION) AND LISTENING DEVICE AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Brownhill) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
The bill has two primary purposes.
The first is to introduce new arrangements by which agencies are able to obtain warrants authorising the interception of telecommunications for the investigation of serious criminal offences.
The bill's second principal object is to strengthen arrangements for dealing with police corruption.
The interception of telecommunications by law enforcement agencies, and subsequent dealing with intercepted information, are regulated by the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
That act provides a detailed scheme of control designed to protect the privacy and confidentiality of communications passing over the Australian telecommunications system.
A general rule of our society is that a communication of this kind is private to the participants.
Intrusion into a communication, even by the government's law enforcement agencies, is subject to strict control.
Interceptions can only be carried out by declared Commonwealth and State law enforcement agencies and only under the authority of a warrant.
At present interception warrants may be issued by an eligible judge of a court created by this Parliament.
An eligible judge is one who has been nominated by the responsible Minister after having consented to perform the function.
The statutory requirement for individual consent underlines that issuing a warrant is an administrative power conferred on a judge as a designated person.
The bill proposes to provide for categories of persons, in addition to judges, who may be authorised to issue warrants.
These amendments are necessary because the eligible judges of the Federal Court have decided that they should no longer perform this function.
I understand the judges have expressed a quite proper concern that the workload involved should not interfere with the performance of their judicial duties.
In addition, there is a more fundamental issue involved.

The High Court has recently indicated that the use of judges as designated officials to perform certain administrative functions may be incompatible with the judicial function as it can undermine public confidence in the independence and integrity of the Judiciary.
The High Court has also specifically advised some judges against agreeing to issue interception warrants because of the risk that the judge may subsequently be involved in a related proceeding.
The amendments will confer the authority to issue interception warrants on certain members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal who are nominated for this purpose by the responsible Minister.

The potential pool of nominees would be the Deputy Presidents and full-time Senior Members, as well as those part-time Senior Members and Members (all of whom are part-time) who have legal qualifications.
This new arrangement takes into account the special character of the authority to issue an interception warrant.

The purpose of the issuing process is to provide an opportunity, before the event, for the conflicting interests of the state and an individual to be assessed, so that the individual's right to privacy will be affected only where the appropriate statutory standard has been met and the needs of law enforcement are demonstrably superior.
For such a process to be meaningful, the person making the assessment must be capable of doing so in a neutral and impartial manner.
The Government believes that the specified members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have both the independence and experience necessary for this role.
However, an individual will only be given the authority to issue warrants after he or she is nominated by the Minister.
There will be an opportunity, before an eligible person is nominated, for consultation with the President of the Tribunal concerning their experience and background.
The Government believes that the new arrangement set out in the bill will maintain the integrity of the warrant issuing arrangements.
I should also point out that the amendments do not in any way alter the provisions which permit judges to issue warrants should their views change at some time in the future.
The bill introduces similar new arrangements for issuing listening device warrants to Commonwealth law enforcement agencies under the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 and the Customs Act 1901.
These warrants are also issued at present by federal judges.
I now turn to the provisions in the bill that are directed against the serious problem of police corruption.
Most significantly, the bill contains a number of provisions relating to the New South Wales Police Integrity Commission.
The Commission has recently been established as a permanent authority to continue the work of the Wood Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service.
Senators will be aware that the Wood Royal Commission uncovered disturbing instances of corruption and other serious police misconduct.

The Commonwealth supports the government of New South Wales in its efforts to excise the cancer of corruption from within its police service and is ready to assist in providing the new Commission with appropriate and effective powers.
Experience has shown that covert surveillance is one of the most powerful investigative tools for uncovering and prosecuting police misconduct.

The bill will amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 to permit the Commission to receive and use intercepted information originally obtained by other law enforcement agencies where the information relates to a matter the Commission may investigate.

The amendments also open the way for a declaration to be made which will permit the Commission to apply for warrants on its own behalf once the Attorney-General, as the responsible Minister, is satisfied that the statutory pre-conditions of a declaration have been fulfilled.
These amendments do not involve any effective widening of interception powers.

The responsibilities of the Police Integrity Commission for investigating police misconduct have generally been transferred to it from the Independent Commission Against Corruption and the New South Wales Police Service. Both these latter agencies are already able to apply for interception warrants for this purpose.

The bill further supports the Police Integrity Commission in other ways. Amendments to the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 will give the Commission, as well as the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, access to the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre's database of reportable transactions.

In addition, amendments to the Customs Act will permit the Australian Police and the National Crime Authority to communicate information those agencies obtain by means of a listening device directly to the Commission where the information relates to the Commission's functions.
Without this amendment, the Commonwealth agencies would only be able to pass listening device information about police corruption to the Commission via the New South Wales Police Service.

Several of the amendments deal with more general aspects of police misconduct. The bill will permit the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to use intercepted information in deciding whether to appoint, re-appoint or dismiss a member or staff member of the AFP.

This amendment is a response to a decision in the Federal Court to the effect that the Commissioner was not permitted to rely on intercepted informa tion relating to corruption by an AFP officer in a decision not to re-appoint that officer.

The Government considers that position to be inconsistent with the Commissioner's responsibilities to keep the AFP free of corruption and the power given to the Commissioner over appointments within the AFP.
The bill also contains an equivalent provision in relation to other police services.
I now turn to other amendments.

The bill will permit intercepted information to be given in evidence in three categories of proceedings that relate to the commission of prescribed offences. One category provides for an application for bail that relates to a prosecution for a prescribed offence.

This amendment is a response to a decision by the Court of Appeal of New South Wales in the case of Director of Public Prosecutions v Serratore which held that a bail application is not part of a related prosecution.
The bill will also permit intercepted information to be given in evidence in applications for restraining orders made under Commonwealth and Sate proceeds of crime legislation.

The effectiveness of this legislation, particularly in relation to drugs offences, depends on the ability of prosecuting authorities to obtain orders preventing assets from being dealt with pending the outcome of related criminal proceedings.
This amendment is to clarify the legislative position following the Serratore decision.

The third category of proceedings is a coroner's inquest if the coroner considers the subject of the inquiry, for example a suspicious death, may have been caused by the commission of a prescribed offence.
The purpose is to avoid a situation where a coroner is prevented from receiving evidence that may be vital to the coroner's determination.
Finally, the bill contains a number of other minor amendments related to the use of intercepted information and record keeping obligations.
The amendments have no significant financial impact.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned to the first day of sitting in the Spring sittings 1997 in accordance with standing order 111.

for the constitutional convention—

I presume that this clause has been placed in the bill so that you do not end up with the situation where a person could be elected to a state or federal parliament through a by-election before the convention is held and therefore, in a bizarre or long‐shot set of circumstances, become a politician elected to the convention. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Senator Minchin) is saying no, so he will be able to clear that up for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Brown's sensitivity to my leaping up and down. I can clear that up. The reference to `election' requires you to look at the definition of election in the bill, where it states that `election means an election for a state or territory under this act', which is the normal convention of interpretation. SPEECH.PARA: What this section is designed to do is prevent people nominating in every state and territory. So, if you nominate, you nominate in only one state or territory for the election governed by this act, and the only election governed by this act is an election for delegates to the convention. So it does not prevent a candidate for any other electoral process, or any future election, from running; it simply prevents people from nominating in more than one jurisdiction for this particular election, as defined by the act itself. I hope that clears up your confusion about what this provision is designed to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

SPEECH.PARA: I would ask the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) to look at this clause when the legislation goes from here back to the House of Representatives to make sure that it is quite clear‐cut that it is the intention that it should refer only to people who might intend to stand in a number of states and territories for the constitutional convention and that it does not prevent somebody who might want to stand for an election, if one should occur in South Australia, from standing for the constitutional convention at the same time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not a major sticking point for the government but, in considering the question of nominations for this election, we did seek to reach a sensible position on what requirements, if any, candidates should meet. TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —As previously indicated, we are withdrawing government amendment No. 4 because it is no longer relevant. It was only appropriate on the basis of the government's proposed modified Senate style ballot paper. That has been changed and therefore this amendment is irrelevant and we withdraw it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Page 34 (after line 9), after Part 4, insert:

At the time of the poll, the Electoral Commissioner must cause to be submitted to each elector who attends at a polling place or mobile booth or who applies for a pre‐poll vote the following question:
"Do you want an Australian to be Australia's Head of State?"
The Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 applies to the scrutiny of the plebiscite in so far as is practicable.
(1) The results of the plebiscite are intended to be indicative.
(2) No consequences follow from the results of the plebiscite.

I view this as one of the most important amendments coming forward in this debate. It is to provide for a plebiscite to be held at the time of the election for candidates to the Constitutional Convention. Just to reiterate, that election is likely to be held in August or September for the Constitutional Convention which is mooted to be in December.

As it stands, the Constitutional Convention is going to be a meeting of half government appointed delegates and half elected delegates. It is not going to have direction. There is no direction in this legislation as to what it should be discussing. What we take from that is that, at the outset, its direction will be given to it by the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). We have failed to get up an amendment which would have left it to the convention itself, under those circumstances, to determine its schedule.

Much better than it be given direction by the government is that it be given direction by the people of Australia. We think it is logical and sensible, seeing we are holding a national election—and this committee has successfully amended this legislation so far to ensure that everybody votes—that after voting for the candidates of their choice the Australian electors tick a box saying whether or not they want an Australian to be head of state. This would mean that the convention would have a direction from the Australian people about whether or not a republic was wanted in 1997. The opinion polls increasingly and resoundingly say `yes' to that question.

The Greens are concerned that, as this legislation stands, there will be a lot of time and effort and millions of dollars wasted on this convention as people debate the question of whether we should retain the monarchy or move to having an Australian as head of state. What a plebiscite would do is simply indicate to the people gathering at that convention that the Australian people do want an Australian as head of state; or it may be they will vote in the opposite direction. But if we take the polls, they indicate that an Australian is wanted as head of state, the convention can then get on with the business of determining what sort of republic it will be. This is sensible, logical and expeditious. It is taking account of the direction this nation is going in.

As it is, the government is going to hold a plebiscite but it is going to be after the Constitutional Convention. It is very likely it will lead to a referendum further down the line. We say that we should have the plebiscite first. We should have this convention working from the solid basis of knowing that the Australian people indeed do want an Australian as head of state as this nation of ours moves into the next millennium. It all seems so obvious.

A lot will be said about the cost of holding plebiscites, the cost of holding conventions and the cost of holding multiple elections over this business of determining how we move to a republic. I do not think there is much other than a very broad acceptance of the fact in this nation that we are moving to a republic. So let us get on with it. Let us have the people have their say at the outset.

We Greens believe a lot more trust should be put in the people. That is why we believe that all the candidates to this convention should be elected. That is why we believe that this convention should be able to set its timetable. Moreover, that is why we believe that a plebiscite, which would be of minimal cost but have a mighty positive effect on the outcome of that convention, should be held in conjunction with this election. Let us have the Australian people, at the outset, have their say. I can tell the government this: the Australian people will feel much more involved. They will feel that they are having a say from the outset. They will take this convention much more to be theirs if they are given the opportunity to vote yes or no for a republic at a plebiscite in August when this election is held.

I cannot understand how, with all the aforethought that has gone into this legislation and with all the aforethought that has gone into this process, the government is not itself legislating for this plebiscite to be held now. It is almost as if it is frightened of the Australian people. It is almost as if it is frightened to put its toe in the water of our republican future. Let us get on with it. Let us give the people a say. Let us have this convention determine what sort of republic we are going to have; how we institute an Australian as head of state in the coming few years; and how we remould, as best possible, using this historic opportunity, Australian democracy freed of the last remnants of its colonial connection with Britain and with this anachronism of having somebody from another country as our head of state.

I think that all parties in this chamber should support this amendment. It is thoroughgoing commonsense. It even makes economic sense—it makes dollars and cents sense. But, above all, it draws the Australian people into this historic process from the outset, and I cannot think of a better thing to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not someone who frequently calls for referendums. I am certainly not a fan of citizen initiated referendums, mainly because they can be used as a tool for powerful and well‐resourced lobby groups to push a minority view over a majority view. However, what Senator Brown is asking for is an indicative plebiscite, something which can give a direction in terms of whether or not the majority of Australians wish to have an Australian as a head of state. That gives a great potential for freedom within the ongoing process. It means that the people involved can then free themselves up to allow themselves to go back to the community and talk to people about what kind of republic they want, if that is what is decided in relation to a plebiscite. If the answer is, `No, not yet', then there is more work to be done within the community.

SPEECH.PARA: If the answer is yes, maybe we have the ability to bring in the excitement that I believe is in the community about what kind of Australia we want to have to go into the next century. Maybe we will not be held down by a wish to decide whether or not a minimalist solution is the only thing possible within the discussions here. Maybe this gives us an opportunity to open out the level of community input on this issue instead of being frightened of what the community might say. It certainly is something that as many people as possible should be involved in. And, because the Senate has now deemed that the election should be open, democratic and compulsory, that means, basically, that everybody will have a say. Why not use that opportunity to get as clear an indication as it is possible to get of what Australians want for the future and then work in the best way towards achieving that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support the proposal moved by Senator Brown. Our view is that a plebiscite is the way to go. We put that proposal before—and to—the last election. We still maintain that it is the appropriate way to involve all Australians in the process right from the start, but we realise that the proposal before us from the Greens runs contrary to the proposal put forward by the government at the last election—a proposal the government is keen to pursue. The government went to the election with their proposal for a constitutional convention without a plebiscite and, given the result of that election, there is some responsibility on us to look at the government's proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: We also think that meshing both together would not be the appropriate way to go. In the past we have not adopted a proposal to mesh a constitutional convention and a plebiscite together. We have been of the view that a plebiscite can perform a special and particular function but, after a plebiscite is held to get a reflection of the will of the Australian people, a process can be developed, based on the mechanisms of this parliament, to ensure the refinement of proposals to put to a subsequent referendum, with the participation of the Australian people and of all sides of this parliament. So we do not see Senator Brown's proposal as the appropriate way to go.

We expect the government to deliver on their Constitutional Convention. I know that we have had the odd threat in the last day or so about what the government would do if they did not get the totality of their package through unamended, but we are talking about an issue that will not go away. Although we have good reason to doubt the government's bona fides as to whether they want constitutional change—the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in particular has indicated that he does not see the need for change now—we are of the view that the issue will continue to stay with us. For instance, the Australian this morning made it very clear what its message to the government was when it said:
Yesterday's Senate vote is a reminder to the Government that the whole process should be fair, consistent and credible. It should not be used as an excuse to abandon the convention.
We also hold very firmly to those sentiments.

I also remind the government that this is not just an issue for the moment; it is one that is of concern to the community and to individual Liberal Party members. A copy of a survey of Liberal Party members—conducted in Queensland recently by Senator John Herron—arrived at my office this afternoon. Senator Herron says, `An identical survey has been conducted in South Australia, Victoria, WA and Tasmania by four of my Senate colleagues.' It is interesting that only one in three Liberal Party leadership members in that survey has a very firm view that Australia should stay a constitutional monarchy. That is a mere four per cent increase over the last four years—Senator Herron compares this 1997 survey to a 1993 survey.

In terms of those in the Liberal Party leadership who believe Australia should become a republic, there has been a fourfold increase from 1993 to 1997—from four per cent to 15 per cent. In terms of those who think Australia should only become a republic if the Constitutional Convention demonstrates clear benefit, those tending very strongly towards supporting a republic, that is another 19 per cent. So the party of government is divided and the government, if it were to pull the plug on a constitutional convention, would not be able to pull the plug on the move and the road towards a republic. That would be ongoing. A sign of that, as I say, is the support within the coalition government parties for a move towards a republic.

It is one of history's ironies that, while we are here debating the next important step to take to take Australia on the road to a republic, the Prime Minister is in England with the Queen, rusting himself onto the monarchy. It is ironic that, while we are here in Australia trying to sort out the next step towards a constitutional convention, we will have imagery of the Prime Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —We've got to go to bed some time tonight, Senator.
—He will not be in bed now, Senator Harradine, because the first ball is about to be bounced, and I hope Mark Taylor lasts a bit longer than we do with this debate tonight.
—I tell you what, it is going to be a very soggy bounce, Senator Bolkus.
—Is it raining?
—It is going to go splat.

—Anyway, I was not intending to talk at length here. The point is that, while the Prime Minister is there in London yapping about like one of the Queen's corgis, I am sure he will tell the Queen about the Constitutional Convention proposal. What he also needs to tell her is that some 67 per cent of Australians support the republic and have done so for some time. I think he also needs to tell her that there is a solid body of support for a republic for Australia within his own party.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister might tell the Queen how he and Senator Minchin have cleverly designed this proposal to keep Australia under the monarchy for the foreseeable future, but he should not just present one side of the story. He should ask her what her view would be if we were to become a republic. I think, as Senator Collins said, in one way or another she has given her view. If the Prime Minister were to ask her that question, I think he would find there would be very little resistance from the monarchy about Australia becoming a republic. It is indeed a matter for Australians.

I think he would also find that, if he were to ask her, he would probably find that he wants her more than she actually wants us—that he is a greater supporter of a monarchy for Australia than the monarch herself. I think it is important to keep that in perspective in terms of the debate.

The Prime Minister could also ask the Queen—given Senator Harradine's earlier interjection—why, as head of state for Australia, she is not supporting Australia in the test tonight. That is a fair question to ask. Why isn't she sweating on Mark Taylor's return to form, the fitness of Gillespie and Blewett or the form of Shane Warne? The fact is that her priorities are not ours.

We can probably best see that in Hong Kong at the moment. Once again, we are here contemplating this proposal. Very soon our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) will be in Hong Kong. I hope he will not be taking lessons from the Chinese there—in that he fully appoints a body to make decisions for our future as they are doing. If there are any conflict of interest issues between Australia and the UK—and there are quite often—I think Hong Kong epitomises that our priorities can often be quite different.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown, did you write this speech?

—I wrote this speech. One point that I did miss out on was the one that Senator Collins raised—which is, why doesn't the Prime Minister also ask the heir apparent to the Crown, Prince Charles, for his views on Australia becoming a republic? It is interesting that the Prime Minister is not spending time with Prince Charles. I do not know what degree of embarrassment he feels he may be subjected to if he does do that, but he should also ask Prince Charles that question and he would get the message from there.
