SPEECH.PARA: The point is that we believe Australia will continue to go down the road to a republic, but we do not believe that meshing the plebiscite and the Constitutional Convention together in this proposal is the way to go. If the government chooses not to proceed with the convention, I think that would be an enormous breach of faith with the Australian people. The republican moment, encompassing a whole range of diverse interests, would I am sure come up with a proposal to keep the issue alive.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to draw honourable senators' attention to standing order 193(2), which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator shall not refer to the Queen, the Governor‐General or the Governor of a State disrespectfully in debate, or for the purpose of influencing the Senate in its deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't.
—Just contemplate the last half of that standing order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have absolutely no idea what 90 per cent of Senator Bolkus's speech had to do with the amendment before the chair—which is to provide that there be a plebiscite—and I will not indulge myself by responding to most of his assertions, ill- founded as they were, on extraneous matters to this amendment. Ironically, we actually agree with Senator Bolkus that this amendment should not be supported.

SPEECH.PARA: I would mention in passing that, regrettably, the Greens have not provided us with an estimate of the cost of this proposal. They apparently make no estimate of the costs of their proposals that they bring to this chamber. But, as the government, we are responsible for these things.

There is a $7 million additional cost if you have a plebiscite together with the election for delegates. So with the up to $20 million extra which the Senate has added to the cost of this process, there would be another $7 million with the plebiscite and we have not yet got to public funding. So we are already up to $62 million for this election as a result of proposals put by the opposition parties—in this case, the Greens.

We think this is putting the cart before the horse. The government was elected overwhelmingly to implement its policy. The party that went to the election saying, `We are not proposing to turn Australia into a republic,' was elected overwhelmingly. The party that said, `We want Australia to become a republic,' suffered, I think, the second worst defeat in its history.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the reason, was it, Nick?
—It might well have been, Chris. You never know.
—Excuse me, Senator Minchin. Would you refer to the honourable senator by his surname, please?
—Of course, Madam Chairman.
—Senator Evans rather than Chris.

—Senator Evans, of course. The policy was that we have the convention. Then, depending on the result of the convention, we would have either an indicative plebiscite or a referendum by the end of the year 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: So we set down what we thought was a logical process. That is, the nation would discuss this very significant issue—an issue about which a lot of Australians do not necessarily have a view or about which they have mixed views because they see arguments from both sides—and that would be debated in the forum of a convention. If the convention reached a consensus in favour of a particular republican model, we as a government would undertake to facilitate that going to a referendum. If there was no such consensus, we would undertake to put a range of options to the people in the form of a plebiscite.

May I add that we do not agree that the plebiscite question should be whether you think Australia should have an Australian head of state, what we regard as a facile question. Even former Labor leader Bill Hayden regarded himself, I think quite properly, as the Australian head of state in wearing the mantle of Governor-General. So whatever your views, there are a lot of Australians who believe that the Governor-General is the head of state and the Governor-General is an Australian. So that is not, in our view, the appropriate question in any event to fairly and reasonably put to the Australian people.

But, for the reasons of cost, for the reasons of sensible process and for the reasons that the whole convention idea is to enable Australians to be exposed to the arguments for and against in the sort of forum that the convention provides before they come to cast a vote on this thing, I think it is sensible. The Senate has already decided that you are going to force people to vote for either monarchist or republican delegates to the convention. But now the Greens want to force people to vote on what we regard is the quite facile question of whether you want Australia to have an Australian head of state. Therefore, we reject the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two things that the parliamentary secretary has indicated here. He said that, in relation to the planning of an indicative plebiscite by the end of the year 2000, they have not agreed on whether or not the appropriate question should be whether Australia should have an Australian head of state. That happens to be in your legislation. Your legislation says that the terms of reference for this group are to find out what the nature of the republic should be and the timing.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, this means that this is a total sham. You do not expect this convention to have any say at all because you have already decided it. You think there is going to be an indicative plebiscite by the end of the year 2000. You have already worked out what they will be allowed to say. It does not matter what they say in December; you have already worked it out. You have just told us that you have decided what they are going to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, address your remarks through the chair.

—Sorry, I got carried away. The government has decided what the convention will be allowed to say. Apparently the government will agree to what the Constitutional Convention say only if it works out with what the government has already decided. This is a sham.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just respond to that rather hysterical intervention. The convention has been asked to determine and discuss whether or not Australia should become a republic—if so, what form of republic—and the timing and circumstances of the question being put. There are a lot of people on both sides, including republicans, who do not think that a fair question for any plebiscite is whether Australia should have an Australian as the head of state. What we are putting to the convention is reasonable. We have said quite openly and publicly in the second reading speech et cetera that the questions that will be put to the convention and discussed are whether or not Australia should become a republic, what form of republic we should be and the timing and circumstances for that question to be con sidered. That is quite reasonable and open. That is what we are on about. I really fail to understand the hysteria you have brought to this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be quite happy for the government to move to have the question changed from whether or not people want an Australian head of state to whether or not they want a republic. The honourable senator knows that that is irrelevant to the point of giving Australians a say as to whether or not they want a republic in the run‐up to this convention. It is not beyond our wit and wisdom to have a fair, clear question which says to Australians, `Say "yes" or "no" as to whether you want a republic.' That is what this plebiscite is about and that is what yours is going to be about.

SPEECH.PARA: But Senator Margetts is correct. The government is not being fair dinkum about this convention. It is not being fair dinkum about taking the people into account in the fullest way possible, otherwise it would have them electing the delegates to the convention and have them involved from the outset by having them say whether or not they want a republic.

What seems stranger still is the Labor Party's viewpoint on this. First of all, Senator Bolkus, for whom I have the greatest respect, says, `Our view is that there should be a plebiscite. It is just that we are going to vote against this proposal that there should be a plebiscite, which is our view.' Then he goes on to say, `Given the result of the election, the government had a policy that they'll have a convention. We accede to that.'

Every hour of the day in here Senator Bolkus and the opposition are taking on the government over the policies it is implementing, whether or not they be election promises. But when it gets to this critical question of the republic, the opposition have gone into reverse. I do not know whether it is an aversion which comes from the feeling that Mr Keating may have gone a bit strongly on it and it did not do them well; but, whatever it is, there is a great contradiction in the opposition's viewpoint on this.

BREAK.PARA: We are in here to take on the government in a positive way as far as possible to innovate and to make things better for the Australian people. That is what this amendment does. It says to Australians, `You give us an indication from the outset and you make this convention worth while.' I can tell you what this convention is going to do without the plebiscite. First of all, there is going to be a $50 million or $60 million election exercise. Secondly, a convention will come out of that. If that convention is based on the word `consensus' in the way in which Senator Minchin has meant it, there is going to be about a fifty-fifty or a two‐one split between those who favour a republic and those who do not.

Goodness gracious me; are we going to spend $62 million to find out what the split in that convention is going to be? I feel we are—instead of taking this opportunity at a 10 per cent extra cost to make that convention mean something, because it actually has a direction from the Australian people to work on what sort of republic we want. That is wise spending of money. That is a logical way to go. That is a sensible way to take the Australian people into account in this issue, on which every Australian either has a point of view or is developing a point of view, but about which everyone knows.

The opposition viewpoint, no less than the government viewpoint, is addled on this. I am trying to bring some commonsense into the process as well as give the Australian people the vote they want at the outset. There is going to be massive publicity about an election in late winter and early spring. People are going to be asked to go to the polling booths—or, as the government would have had it, to fill out their postal ballot form—to vote for candidates for a convention.

It is going to be a process of frustration because they are going to be denied answering at the outset the question they want to answer: whether or not they want an Australian as our head of state; whether or not—to put the question differently, and I would be quite accepting of this—they want a republic. So there it is. We are wasting money. We are wasting an opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wasting a lot of time too.

—Senator Calvert—the only other government member occupying the government bench at the moment—interjects about time being wasted here. I say to you, Senator Calvert, $60 million could be better spent here, and I say to you that this convention's time would be much better spent if you took into account the people.
—Order! Senator Brown, could you direct your comments through the chair, please.

—With pleasure, Madam Chair. So there it is. It is a great opportunity but we are being denied it because a Green has put it forward. It is not much more than that. That is a silly way to be behaving. This is pure commonsense, and this place would work a lot better if, when a cogent, sensible and democratic idea comes up like this, the government had the gumption to rise to the occasion and adopt it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats proposed originally that there should be an indicative plebiscite because it was our belief that that would have been extremely helpful in developing the process of advancing towards a republic by the turn of the century. However, that view was rejected by government and the government decided to introduce its Constitutional Convention proposal. All six parties represented in this chamber have accepted that process and are participating in it.

SPEECH.PARA: For as long as there was a voluntary postal ballot facing us, we continued to have doubts about that process. But, now that we have a compulsory attendance ballot, we are of the view that, depending of course—and it is a crucial dependence—on the way in which the tickets are titled, the compulsory attendance ballot will itself deliver the equivalent of an indicative plebiscite because, when the Australian republican movement puts its delegates up, nobody who votes for that will be a monarchist and, when the Australian monarchist movement puts its members up, nobody who votes for them will be a republican. So, to a large extent, we believe that the votes which will attach to the tickets that come up will provide for the indicative plebiscite idea.

The other point is that we are aware that there is a danger that the government may try to find a mechanism to squirm out of the changed bill. We hope it is all bluster and threat, but one thing we do not want to do is to add additional cost. Their sole justification for squirming out of the changed bill will be on the grounds of increased costs. We have already heard from Senator Minchin extraordinarily inflated mathematics. I would remind listeners that the downside increase in the cost of running the convention on the basis of the changed bill is between $7 million and $9 million and not between $18 million and $20 million. If it suits Senator Minchin to push the higher figure, it suits me to push the lower figure—and the truth may well be somewhere in between.

Having said that, I point out to Senator Margetts and Senator Brown that we as the Australian Democrats strongly support the idea of an indicative plebiscite but we believe that the compulsory attendance ballot will now fulfil much of that intention. It is our intention to barrack as hard as we can for anybody who has `republican' against their name on the ticket. Accordingly, we will oppose the Greens' amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for the Democrat viewpoint, but again it falls on the premise that the convention will take note of and be guided by the election of delegates in the same way as it would be guided by a very simple vote on whether or not there should be a republic. Senator Murray might reflect on the fact that half the members are going to be appointed to this convention. His argument would be much stronger if all members were being elected, but it is very much weakened by the fact that that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are going to get an equivalent indication from the compulsory vote being applied to the election of delegates, why don't we just clear the air and give people a straight vote? Why don't we just say, `Do you or don't you want an Australian as our head of state,' or, as Senator Minchin would prefer, `Do you or don't you want a republic?' It is just such commonsense, and it does involve people so much more fully in the process of determining the constitutional change which is inevitable as we move to a republic in this country. I believe it also puts definition into the trajectory of that change.

So far the people have not been able to speak. Governments are able to put their foot on the accelerator or take it off because the people have not had an opportunity to speak clearly on the basic question about a republic. Here is the opportunity. It should be taken. I have not heard yet a good argument as to why this amendment ought not be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things that I really love about Australia is that at times ratbaggery has come to be a fine art form. One of the things that I really expect to see as a result of this election, in relation to the way the government would like to control the outcomes and control what people say and do not say in this election, is that that is not what is going to happen. I do not believe, as Senator Murray asserts, that it will simply be like a plebiscite between the Australian Republican Movement and the monarchists.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I do not believe that is because, as I said at the beginning of this debate, it is not called the republican convention, it is called the Constitutional Convention. And, despite the government's efforts to control it, there may be people who cannot and will not be controlled, who can and will think for themselves, whether or not they are on the other end of the ballot paper and whether or not they get themselves elected. My guess is that we might get some Aboriginal people who believe that in a constitutional convention they ought to be there looking to protect their rights and interests. There might be people from the gun lobby who believe they ought to be there to protect their interest. There might be activists from human rights—

TALK.START.PARA: —There may be people from the Pauline Hanson One Nation Party.

—Indeed. There might be a whole range of groups of people who believe that in any major Australian event in relation to discussing the constitution they ought to be there listening to the arguments to make sure that their interests are looked after.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is naive to suggest that this will be able to be controlled directly by the government. I think it is going against all sorts of lessons of history in terms of people doing what governments tell them to do. This is not going to be a law; it is going to be an attempt to control people and to gag people. Guess what: I do not think it is going to work. And I do not think it is the right thing to do to suggest it is going to be a nice little controlled outcome which says yes or no. It may just possibly still be a useful discussion that may lead to something else—that is, it may lead to more of the community being involved in discussions at a later date and then working later on into something beyond an indicative plebiscite.

But to suggest that the Australian Democrats ditch their own policy on the basis of, `Trust me, I am with the government,' when the government's intentions clearly are to go with their own agenda, no matter what the community is saying, is naive. I still support Senator Brown's amendment here.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (55) Page 80 (after line 25), after Part 7, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 113A Appointment of agents by candidates and groups

SPEECH.PARA: (1) A candidate (including a member of a group of candidates) may appoint a person to be the agent of the candidate, for the purposes of this Part, in relation to the election.
(2) The members of a group of candidates may appoint a person to be the agent of the group, for the purposes of this Part, in relation to the election.

(3) During any period during which there is no appointment in force under subsection (1) of an agent of a candidate, the candidate is to be taken to be his or her own agent for the purposes of this Part.

(4) During any period during which there is no appointment in force under subsection (2) of an agent of a group, the candidate whose name is to appear first in the group in the ballot‐papers is to be taken to be the agent of the group for the purposes of this Part.
(1) An appointment of an agent under section 113A has no effect unless:

PARA.TAB: (a) the person appointed is a natural person who has attained the age of 18 years; and
(b) written notice of the appointment is given to the Electoral Commission by the candidate or each member of the group making the appointment; and
(c) the name and address of the person appointed are set out in the notice; and
(d) the person appointed:

TAB.TAB: (i) has signed a form of consent to the appointment; and
(ii) has signed a declaration that he or she is eligible for appointment.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) A consent or declaration under subsection (1) may be incorporated in, or written on the same paper as, a notice under that subsection.

(3) Where a person who is the agent of a candidate or of a group is convicted of an offence against this Part in relation to the election, subsection 290(2) of the CEA applies to the person as if the election under this Act were an election under the CEA.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 113C Revocation of appointment of agent of candidate or group

SPEECH.PARA: (1) A candidate or the members of a group may, by giving written notice to the Electoral Commission, revoke the appointment of a person as the agent of the candidate or group, as the case may be.
(2) A notice under subsection (1) has no effect unless it is signed by the candidate or by each member of the group, as the case requires.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 113D Notice of death or resignation of agent of candidate or group

SPEECH.PARA: If the agent of a candidate or group dies or resigns, the candidate or a member of the group must, without delay, give to the Electoral Commission notice in writing of the death or resignation.
(1) Subject to this Division, $1.50 is payable for each first preference vote given for a candidate or group in this election.
(2) A reference in this section to a first preference vote is to be read as not including a reference to a vote that has been rejected as informal in the poll.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 113F Payment not to be made in certain circumstances

SPEECH.PARA: (1) A payment under this Division must not be made in respect of votes given in the election for a candidate unless the total number of eligible votes polled in the candidate's favour is at least 4% of the total number of eligible votes polled in favour of all of the candidates in the election.

(2) A payment under this Division must not be made in respect of votes given in the election for a group unless the total number of eligible votes polled in favour of the group is at least 4% of the total number of formal first preference votes cast in the election.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 113G Amount of payment not to exceed electoral expenditure

SPEECH.PARA: The amount of a payment under the Division must not exceed:

PARA.TAB: (a) where an amount is payable to the agent of a candidate—the electoral expenditure in relation to the election incurred by or with the authority of the candidate; or
(b) where an amount is payable to the agent of a group—the electoral expenditure in relation to the election incurred by or with the authority of the members of the group.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Where an amount is payable under this Division in respect of votes given in the election for a candidate, the Electoral Commission must make the payment to the agent of the candidate.
(2) Where an amount is payable under this Division in respect of votes given in the election for a group, the Electoral Commission must make the payment to the agent of the group.
(3) Where the Electoral Commission is required to make a payment under this section in respect of an entitlement:

PARA.TAB: (a) at least 95% of the entitlement (calculated on the basis of the votes counted as at the 20th day after the polling day in the election) must be paid as soon as possible after that 20th day; and
(b) any balance must be paid as soon as possible after the amount of the full entitlement is known.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Where a payment is made under this Division and the recipient is not entitled to receive the whole or a part of the amount paid, that amount or that part of that amount may be recovered by the Commonwealth as a debt due to the Commonwealth by action against the person in a court of competent jurisdiction.

Where a candidate for whom eligible votes were given in the election dies, a payment under this Division in respect of the eligible votes given for the candidate may be made notwithstanding the death of the candidate and the payment may be made to the legal personal representative of the candidate.

Where a member of a group for whom eligible votes were given in the election dies, a payment under this Division in respect of the eligible votes given for the group may be made notwithstanding the death of the member, and if the candidate was the agent of the group for the purposes of this Part, the payment may be made to another member of the group as if the other member were the agent of the group for the purposes of this Part.
Amounts required or permitted to be paid under this Division are to be paid out of money appropriated by the Parliament for the purpose.

This is a very long amendment which, very simply, provides for public funding as in normal elections, so that citizens who stand for election, or the groups behind them or the groups with them, will get a return if they are successful in the same terms as in normal election campaigns. The Greens are simply following through with our belief that this election, all the way through, should mirror elections normally held for the Senate. That will be the case with the amendments the committee has made in just about every respect, except for the public funding component.

I believe the amendment should be supported because groups in the community who are not well heeled ought to be able to take part with the prospect of some return to them. They should be able to take part and spend money on getting their point of view across. They should be able to get their profile up and be able to attract voters to endorse them as delegates to the convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support this proposal. There are obviously long standing supporters of public funding. In this case, we think that, although there should have been some funding arrangement provided for by government, the mechanism in the Electoral Act is probably not the appropriate one. The levels in the Electoral Act are also not the appropriate ones for this particular circumstance. At the end of the day, the allocation of funds obviously is a responsibility of government. In the absence of us being able to persuade government to provide resources, we do not think this is the appropriate mechanism to pursue. We are not supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government obviously—I guess because we did not put it in our bill—does not support the proposition that there be public funding. I think there is a general understanding on both sides now that public funding and disclosure are part of the normal parliamentary electoral arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators will have noticed that, in their report on the 1996 election, the government members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters—of which I am one—did not propose to remove or destroy the whole base of public funding. Therefore, we accept it as part of our arrangements for parliamentary elections. But in this case, where we are electing delegates to a convention—they will be there for only 10 days—we did not think it was a responsible appropriation of taxpayers' money.

The Greens are proposing the $1.50 that is set out in the Electoral Act. That could amount to up to another $15 million on top of the $60 million—or the $62 million, I think—we are up to already. I concede that part of your proposition is to ensure that payments are not to exceed expenditure, but you would have to have very significant administrative arrangements to require the disclosure of all expenditure to ensure that you had accurate records of everybody's expenses. So all candidates would have to comply with all the normal requirements in relation to disclosure of all their expenditure in order that that provision can be properly policed.

On balance, we do not think it appropriate. What we have done is provide that there be a $1,000 tax deduction, which is the tax deduction provided for local government candidates. We think that that is fair. We also propose that delegates' expenses in the form of airfares and accommodation in attending the convention for the whole 10 days would be met. On balance, we thought that that was appropriate in light of having a cost effective arrangement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the thrust of what the Greens are doing. Indeed, the rest of the amendments from the opposition and the Democrats are basically trying to do the same thing, which is to get this poll as much in line as possible with your normal election.

SPEECH.PARA: In this particular case, I think we have to go a little behind the scenes and look at why. We have to look at why there is public funding and why it is put in place. It is basically put there to reduce the potential problems of parties relying heavily on donations, particularly from business and from people who believe that they may be buying influence. It is for that reason that the Democrats are not able to support this. We do not believe the same circumstances exist in this particular poll, particularly as the minister has said that we are looking at people basically being in their position for 10 days.

So looking at the type of election that we are having and the reasons for public funding, the Democrats cannot agree with this particular amendment. However, as I said, we support the basic thrust of where the amendments are going, and that is to not further confuse the public with different voting systems and different tickets. But, in this particular instance, we cannot support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point, in response to Senator Minchin, that the Greens have always stood for public funding to be a reimbursement of the amount that was spent. The Greens vigorously opposed the change, when it was made in this place, that the parties standing for election get reimbursed $1.50 regardless of whether they spend it or not, because we understood that was a simple way of getting the parties out of the red themselves—taking public money that was not spent on an election campaign and shovelling it into their coffers. Here we have simply reverted to the situation that pertained before the last election. So it is not any great shakes that that is being proposed. It is what was done before the last election anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to delay the committee any longer on this point. I think it would have been fair to have found some formula for some public funding to ensure that every group that wants to be represented could make a fist of standing candidates for this election.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the opposition will not be proceeding with amendments 60 to 62, 68, 69, 70 and 71. I foreshadow that I will be moving opposition amendments 66 and 67. This proposal in amended form seeks to establish a process for the selection of the 36 persons appointed to participate in the Constitutional Convention as community representatives. We have probably been through most of these arguments before in the course of this debate. We do not think the government's process to date is one that is, in any sense of the word, democratic. It is not transparent and, as such, it needs to be examined.

SPEECH.PARA: What the government have sought to do here is to appoint 36 persons to participate in the name of the community, and it has chosen to select them themselves. There are quite a number of inherently fundamental problems with this sort of approach. First of all, in the nomination process, a number of organisations were asked to nominate. In the Labor Party, of course, Kim Beazley was one of those. But we do not have an idea as to which organisations were asked. The process, therefore, was one that, in respect of such organisations, was in the dark. People had a capacity to self‐nominate but it was only in the last 36 to 48 hours before the official closure of self‐nominations that people actually realised that they had a capacity to self‐nominate.

Despite that, some 850 Australians at least, I gather, took the opportunity to self‐nominate. We do not know how many people of what background did either self‐nominate or were nominated. A lot of Australians missed out, and a lot of Australians missed out because of lack of information. Once again, there was no sense of democracy or full participation in the process.

It gets worse. We do not know who has conducted the selection process, we do not know what criteria were used for the selection process, and, of course, we still do not know who was appointed. When you talk about an issue like the republic, where the will of the Australian people in continuous numbers of polls has reflected 66 to 70 per cent support for the republic, you would hope that the persons appointed to participate by the government would represent that sort of will, that sort of expression of opinion, in the Australian public. We have no indication as to whether that is the case.

So all in all it is a pretty undemocratic process, one where the government seeks to appoint 36 people in the dark, under a process which we know absolutely nothing about. If that commitment by the Prime Minister to involve all the Australian people at all stages of the process meant anything, this process should have been much more transparent.

We think the best way to go is to set up a joint committee of 12 members of the parliament and not only give that committee the job of selecting such 36 people—and doing so with a two‐thirds majority of that committee to ensure there is a degree of cooperation, consultation and bipartisanship—but also charge it with the responsibility of setting down the procedures and processes for the convention.

With respect to those procedures and processes, the government has told us that they will work them out and they will tell us. I would like to warn the government that when you set up a body like this and when you get 152 people together, they actually have a life of their own in terms of what they would do with the processes and procedures of such a convention. It would be best for the orderly conduct of such a convention that there be a degree of bipartisanship in the formulation of those rules and regulations. It would be in the government's interest to pick up this sort of recommendation.

I will move amendments 66 and 67. We are not going to move amendments 68 and 69. Those amendments relate to the number of delegates to be appointed by the states and territories. Nor will we move amendments 70 and 71, which give the power to the joint committee to appoint a chair of the convention, since that appointment has already been made. We do say that 66 and 67 should be proceeded with. In recognition of an amend ment carried earlier, I will seek to move 67 in an amended form with deletion of 169A(2)(c)—that is, to delete from the joint committee's duties the approval of the state ment of information about the ballot prepared under section 33A. That was something that we did not proceed with earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting, Senator Bolkus, that you would like the two amendments put separately or do you wish to seek leave to move 67 in an amended form now?
—Madam Temporary Chair, there is no need to move them separately. As I move them, I do so by deleting 2(c) from amendment 67. Accordingly, I seek leave to move the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (66) Page 117, (after line 5), after Part 11, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Part 11A—Appointment of Joint Committee on the Constitutional Convention

SPEECH.PARA: (67) Page 117 (after line 5), after the heading to Part 11A, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 169A Joint Committee on the Constitutional Convention

SPEECH.PARA: (1) As soon as practicable after the commencement of this Act, a Joint Committee of 12 Members of the Parliament, to be known as the Joint Committee on the Constitutional Convention, must be appointed.
(2) The Joint Committee's duties are:

PARA.TAB: (a) to nominate to the Minister the names of 36 persons to participate in the Constitutional Convention as community representatives; and
(b) to advise the Minister in respect to the nomination of a person under section 169C to be the Chairman of the Constitutional Convention; and
(c) to draw up for the consideration of the Convention draft rules and procedures for the conduct of the proceedings of the Convention; and
(d) to perform such other duties as may be assigned to it by resolution of either House of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) The nomination of a community representative under paragraph (2)(a) is not effective unless that nomination is supported by at least 8 Members of the Committee.

(4) If the committee fails to nominate all or any of the number of community representatives required by paragraph (2)(a), the Minister may nominate the number of community representa tives necessary to fulfil the requirements of section 169B.

(5) As soon as practicable after the commencement of this Act, each House of the Parliament must, by resolution, determine further details as to the number of Members of each House to be appointed to the Committee.
(6) The appointment of Members by a House must be in accordance with that House's practice relating to the appointment of members of that House to serve on Joint Committees of both Houses.
(7) Subject to this section, all matters relating to the Joint Committee's powers and proceedings must be determined by resolution of both Houses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —While indicating that we will be supporting Senator Bolkus on amendments 66 and 67, I must take this opportunity to ask why he is withdrawing the amendments relating to truth in political advertising. I would have thought that that was an incredibly important part of the ballot. If the Democrats had realised that he was going to withdraw those amendments, we would have had amendments drawn up that at least reflected what is the case in South Australia—that is, a person must not, during the relevant period in relation to an election, authorise the printing, publishing or distribution of any matter relating to the ballot containing a statement which contains inaccurate and misleading statement of fact. I just ask Senator Bolkus why he has withdrawn his amendments.

—I was not happy with the final form of the amendment. Given the fact that more work was needed on it and we needed to look at some of the fundamental problems that have been found with such a proposition in other deliberations of the parliament, we thought we would not proceed with it in the context of this convention. That is the reason why we have not proceeded with that. There are some problems with the concept—problems the Electoral Commission has had for some time. In this particular instance, I had some problems with our proposal.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask either Senator Minchin or Senator Bolkus if they would be prepared to at least go as far as South Australia has gone in the prevention of deliberate misrepresentation, particularly relating to the printing, publishing and authorising of material. Surely we should be protecting this particular ballot from those—as we have already discussed, there are going to be a wide range of people involved—who in some circumstances may not fully understand the position or may in some cases deliberately twist and misinterpret the position of those whom they are opposing. I think it is quite dangerous to set up this ballot and not have some protection against deliberate misrepresentation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment has been withdrawn. Nevertheless, I would say that the government was not intending to support the Labor proposition. The Labor amendment proposed the introduction in this bill of the very clause of the Electoral Act which Labor quite extraordinarily introduced and then withdrew in 1984. It never had an opportunity to work. So we thought it was a bit rich for Labor now to propose that it be part of this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We agree with Labor that the wording of that clause of 1984 is not the right one. As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I have long championed the cause of introducing into the Commonwealth Electoral Act the South Australian provision, which does work, is effective and is properly worded. I hope that our government will bring to this chamber a proposition to introduce that provision into the Electoral Act.

In this case, in the spirit of the Democrats, we were operating on a basis of wanting to apply the provisions of the Electoral Act, unless absolutely necessary to change them. The Electoral Act does not currently provide any more than the misleading or deceptive publications provisions that are in this bill. The provisions in the Electoral Act now regarding misleading or deceptive publications are carried over into this bill. We accept that they have a restrictive interpretation and application but because we do not have in the Electoral Act yet the sort of South Australian provision that I hope one day will be there, we felt that, for the sort of arguments that the Democrats have been putting up in other amendments, in the case of this election, we would not propose to put that in. Therefore, we have not supported the ALP's proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin, do you have anything to say about the amendments before the committee—amendments 66 and 67 moved by Senator Bolkus?
—I do, but I was presuming that the other parties may wish to comment on those amendments—they have not yet done so—and I would comment at the end.
—Is there any further comment on Labor amendments 60 to 62 that have been withdrawn?

—I ask Senator Minchin, in responding to my proposal, to tell the Senate how many people either self-nominated or were appointed. What criteria were used to select the final 36, who actually did the selection, which organisations were asked to nominate and who was appointed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will precede my answers to those questions with some general remarks about the proposition before the chair—that is, that the parliament appoint a parliamentary committee, effectively, to take over the management of the convention and the appointment of all the delegates. We think that is quite an impracticable and, frankly, unreasonable proposition. We went to the last election with a clear policy—that half of the delegates would be elected by the government. That was made clear in John Howard's statement as opposition leader on 8 June 1995 in response to the then Prime Minister's speech on this matter where the policy was laid down. That stated quite clearly that the government would appoint half the delegates. We repeated that policy through to the election, and we were elected on that basis. We intend acting on the basis of the policy on which we were elected.

BREAK.PARA: We believe it is a legitimate prerogative of the government, as the elected government of Australia, to make these sorts of decisions—to set up a convention and to appoint half the delegates. As it turns out, 116 of the 152 delegates will be representatives of the people—40 will be parliamentarians elected by the people, 76 will be community delegates elected by the people, giving 116 of 152, or about two-thirds, who will be direct representatives of the people and leaving only 36 who will be non-parliamentary appointed delegates. So that is the implementation of the policy.

I think it is a bit rich and a bit unreasonable for the parliament to be subverting in this way what we regard as the proper role of the government—particularly, may I say, with due respect, coming from the Labor Party. What is being put before us today is not the way the Labor government operated. In the 13 years of the Hawke-Keating government, there were many examples of conventions, summits, meetings, conferences, whatever, established by the government as a matter of government policy which did not involve any legislation, which did not involve any parliamentary committees and which involved very significant issues and the members, attendees or delegates of which were appointed by the government.

The Constitutional Commission, which discussed the constitution, sat from 1985 to 1988. The Labor Party tells us that that was very important. We agree. That was established by the Hawke government and the members of it were appointed by the Hawke government. The economics summit was established in 1983 by the government with no legislation, no parliamentary committees and with government invited members.

There was the 1985 tax summit, which involved a major look at the tax system, where poor old ex-Prime Minister Keating was rolled—regrettably. That was also set up by the government with no legislation and no parliamentary committees and all members were invited by the government. Last, but not least, the Republic Advisory Committee was established in 1993 to advise the government on the republic. Legislation? No legislation. Parliamentary committee? No parliamentary committee. Who appointed the members? The government.

I therefore think, on the basis of the history of the Hawke-Keating governments, it is a bit rich for those opposite to come in here and so self-righteously claim that we are acting undemocratically in implementing our policy. I remind you that we are dealing with a convention which will have 116 out of 152 representatives elected by the people.

We think, in a practical sense, the proposition before the chair would not in fact work—to establish a committee, to get it working, to work out who the community delegates will be and put that in place as well as have an election. Presumably you would want to operate on the basis that we have been—that is, that the appointed delegates be identified before the election. You are putting the election way off into next year before it would be possible to put all this in place.

It is in fact the case that the government has commenced the process of inviting delegates to the convention that we wish to hold in December of this year. The 40 parliamentary delegates to be appointed are almost all identified. They are being appointed mostly by bodies other than the federal government—they are coming from the states, territories, the opposition and other parties. We have, because of the pressure from particularly the republicans but also the monarchists to identify the appointed delegates before the election, had to set in train the process of inviting community delegates. We are waiting for their responses before they are announced.

In a practical sense, because of the government's responsibility to put into place its policy, we have had to move on some of these things. On the track record of previous governments, we do think it is unreasonable for the parliament to attempt to take over the whole business of running this convention.

We have consulted with other parties on the question of the non-parliamentary appointed delegates. The Prime Minister wrote to the Democrats and the Labor Party and others seeking their suggestions. They have been given due account in deciding whom we should invite. I think as and when the list of 36 non-parliamentary appointed delegates is revealed, it will generally be well received in the community. We have gone to great lengths to ensure that they can not only make a constructive contribution to a discussion of whether or not Australia should become a republic but also take account of the need to ensure that young people, women, Aboriginals and others who would otherwise not be well represented in an election are well represented.

We also agree with Senator Bolkus that, in the conduct of the convention itself, if the convention is to work effectively there will need to be a good degree of bipartisanship. That was one of the reasons we appointed as Chairman Ian Sinclair and as Deputy Chair Barry Jones, the President of the Labor Party—to ensure that there is that degree of cooperation. We intend to consult widely with republican organisations, monarchist organisations and the delegates who will be attending as to how the convention should be conducted. But that is, properly, the prerogative of government and not of a parliamentary committee. We are therefore opposed to the opposition amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have commented on the appointment of delegates to the convention before. My view is that, in the absence of a full-scale election of delegates to the convention, the composition needs to be such that there is a quality of representation from the states. That argument has been lost. As I have said before, the majority of, if not all, previous delegations have been comprised on the basis of equality of representation from the states. I do not want to recanvass that particular issue; I just mention it.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a situation now where that is not going to be the case and there will be a predominance of delegates presumably from New South Wales and Victoria. Now the government has indicated their proposition in this legislation that there should be 38 appointed delegates. I can understand the point of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Senator Minchin) when he says that within the appointment of the 38 there should be an opportunity to ensure that there is proper representation at the convention by persons such as, as he mentioned, Aboriginals and women.

I can understand that point of view, but the government does not have a propriety right over the type of selection. The government supports this proposition before us, but there would be others who might make suggestions to the government which the government might find useful. My view has been that, in so far as it is possible, delegates to this convention should be selected by the people—by the electorate, by the voters. If that is not possible, then they ought to be selected and appointed by persons directly elected by the general electorate.

Senator Minchin quite clearly could say, `That's what we're doing; we, as a government, have been elected directly by the people.' But the government, as a government, has not been elected directly by the people. The government is appointed by the Governor-General. The government holds its position as government only whilst it retains the confidence of the House of Representatives. It has nothing to do with the Senate, unless the government chooses to go along the double dissolution track.

So we are now considering this particular proposition that is before us. At least the proposition that is before us enables a number of persons—that is, from both the House of Representatives and the Senate—to be represented on the committee that is to appoint the delegation. I think that is a reasonable approach because ultimately it is going to come back to this parliament to determine what is going to be put to the people by way of a constitutional referendum.

What is the question going to be? That depends upon what legislation is adopted by this parliament—the whole of the parliament, including the House of Representatives and the Senate. As you know, constitutional referenda are about questions that are contained in a bill which is adopted by both houses of the parliament. I would think that, under those circumstances, it is quite reasonable for both houses of parliament to be involved in the appointment of the 36 face—
Honourable senators interjecting—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, do we leave it for Hansard to fill in the missing words?
—I will say it for you—36 faceless men.

—I mean the 38 delegates to the convention. So, on balance I support it at this point of time, but I am conscious of the fact that there may be considerable embarrassment caused by this measure being put into operation.

BREAK.PARA: In good faith the government has gone ahead and sought the views of persons that it has considered to be appropriate delegates to the convention. That is fair enough. It may well be that those putative delegates who have been invited by the government to become delegates to the convention are embarrassed if they, too, are not nominated by the committee that is proposed by Senator Bolkus. At this stage, until I am convinced that there would be a serious embarrassment for those persons who have been asked by the government in all good faith to become delegates, I am prepared to support this proposal.

I ask Senator Bolkus, as I cannot find it in any of his proposed amendments, what the constitution of that particular committee will be. All the amendment says is that there shall be a committee of 12 members of parliament, to be known as the joint committee on the Constitutional Convention. It does not say how many to come from the House of Representatives, how many to come from the Senate, how many to be nominated by the government and how many to be nominated by the opposition, minor parties or Independents. I would be grateful to be informed, at some particular stage, perhaps not now, as to how the mover of this proposition sees the composition of that particular committee panning out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe I can answer the last part of Senator Harradine's question first and, in doing so, maybe give us some time to further crystallise it if we need to. Proposed section 169A(5) is the section that goes to the appointment. We have deliberately allowed flexibility for the parliament to determine the two issues that Senator Harradine refers to—that is, the proportion of House of Representatives as opposed to Senate and also the proportion of government as opposed to other parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, we say it could be left up to a resolution of both houses of parliament to determine, obviously through negotiation. But we are envisaging here the normal model for joint parliamentary committees whereby, if one was to put it in this particular clause—and we can embark upon drafting it if the Senate is so inclined—we would be looking at, for instance, eight from the House of Representatives and four from the Senate as a starting point for discussion and, of the 12 members, six to be government, four to be opposition, one Democrat and, say, one from other parties or individuals who hold seats in parliament. That is a formula that has been used for the normal joint parliamentary committee. As I said at the outset, we have allowed for a certain degree of flexibility, to be determined between the parties and the individuals represented in the parliament, to get the balance right.

Senator Harradine, if you have any views as to whether we should define it now, crystallise it now, or whether it can be left there for negotiation or whether it can be left there until this matter comes back—as we are told it will come back to this place—we have some time to do that. But the deliberate intention of the opposition was at this particular stage to allow for some flexibility but to follow the model that is often followed for joint committees.

With respect to your other point about good faith, can I say at this stage that we do not know the names of most of those people who have been approached by government. To that extent, they are protected. I do say, though, that the government was sent copies of our proposed amendments quite some time ago, before this week, before last week. They were on notice that there would be a consideration in the Senate of whether those elected by the people should have a say in selecting those appointed to this convention. I am concerned that the government at the start of this week, knowing this legislation was coming on, decided to send letters out.

Despite that, we need to be concerned about people's sensitivities and privacy. To that effect, I think we should be assured by the fact that probably the names of all the people, if not most, have not been made public. I do not know that we would be embarrassing all that many, but I do say this has been on notice to government for some time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just point out to Senator Bolkus, with respect, that the whole machinery of government does not come to a halt because of an opposition amendment. We are proceeding according to government policy and government legislation. We had to act if we are to put in place a convention in December and an election process leading up to it with the names of the appointed delegates identified as far beforehand as possible so that people have a reasonable chance to decide whether to nominate for election or not. So, despite your notification of the amendment, we had to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: This is really for you, because we are opposed to it, but it would appear it is going to have some support. I just point out that proposed section 169A(5) says:

As soon as practicable after the commencement of this Act, each House of the Parliament must, by resolution, determine further details as to the number of Members of each House to be appointed to the Committee.

We will bring this legislation back into the Senate next week. We will no doubt debate it again. I just have to say that you could have a problem with the commencement date and find that, as both houses are not sitting until the end of August, you may not actually be able to set up this committee until late August. I do not know when you are going to have the election on the convention on the basis of this proposition.

As I said before, we are at a point where this is quite impractical, as well as being absolutely unreasonable, particularly coming from a Labor Party which in government did not operate on this basis and is now self-righteously telling us that we must. I do think this is quite an unreasonable subversion of the proper role of government and a parliamentary takeover of what is a legitimate government prerogative in establishing a convention and overseeing the appointment of the delegates and the conduct of the convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —As they say in the classics, I was not proposing to speak at this part of the debate, but I have certainly been provoked by that extraordinary statement by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Senator Minchin)—that is, that this is an outrageous parliamentary takeover of the executive.

SPEECH.PARA: With reference to the previous government, which did not have this view—and I also want to refer to the complaints that were made just a short time ago about the time taken to proceed with this—I actually do feel that this is a matter of some import from my perspective, I have to say. We are actually talking about a convention, and Senator Margetts probably made the point a little earlier too. This is not simply a convention to determine whether an Australian should be head of state or not, and over the 10 days I am absolutely confident that, no matter who goes to the convention, the discussion is going to be far broader than that.

This will be a convention that will actually determine the constitutional basis for what Australia is going to be for the next 100 years, hopefully. If, indeed, the convention determines, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) clearly already has, that the status quo that we enjoy now is going to be the basis for the next 100 years, in my opinion it will be a failure.

Frankly, I could not think of a more appropriate institution to have some input into this than the parliament. This is an eminently reasonable and sensible proposal. I strongly endorse this amendment. I am not ascribing any ill‐will towards the government, either. I do not think that the government set out to monopolise the choice. My own knowledge of a number of people who have been proposed, for example from the Northern Territory, indicates that there is no bad faith in this. But this particular proposal enhances the arrangement, and it is wrong for Senator Minchin to suggest—and this is a dreadful quote—a `parliamentary hijack', or words to that effect, of the executive when you consider what we are doing. We are putting together what will be in every sense an historical occasion—the first time for almost a century that such a thing has happened.

Michael Coper, in his superb book on the Australian Constitution, which is as entertaining as it is informative, pointed out that the original Constitutional Convention not only consisted of an all male body, as indeed was the custom of the day, but that only one of the male delegates was clean shaven. From memory, that was Edmund Barton. So, in fact, the Australian Constitution, as Coper said in his book, was put together by a large group of hairy men.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a plug for Harry Evans!

—No, it is not a plug for the Clerk of the Senate at all. All I am saying is simply that that stark example indicates that the make‐up of our community today is diverse and multicultural. It is a world away from the world that put this constitution together almost a century ago.

SPEECH.PARA: We are actually talking about the process by which we are now formally going to reconsider the constitutional basis for this country and, hopefully, if they do a good job, for the next century. I do think that this proposal—and this is not a party political view, Senator Minchin, let me assure you—has got a great deal of merit. I think it deserves not only the support of the Senate but, at the end of the day, the support of the government.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Bolkus's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, we are up to opposition amendment No. 82.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to remind Senator Minchin that I put a number of questions to him and I would like answers to them. I do not think it is unreasonable of us to ask how many people self‐nominated or were nominated, on what criteria the delegates were appointed, who did the appointing and which organisations were approached. So it is up to you, Senator Minchin, to try to expedite the hearings tonight. At this stage, I will not ask who was appointed, although we should know that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MINCHIN (South Australia—Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister) (South Australia—Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister) (9.25 p.m.)—The government has appointed the delegates according to the criteria it laid down in announcing its policy. Primarily, the 36 appointed delegates will be people who can make a constructive contribution to the debate on the question of whether or not Australia should become a republic. They have been appointed on that basis.

We said that 10 per cent of the appointed delegates should be between the ages of 18 and 25. Of the 36 delegates we have invited, eight will be between 18 and 25 years old. We said there would be proper representation of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and you will find there is. We said there would be a proper balance between men and women and you will find, when they are announced, that there is. Further than that, I cannot really add much to what I have already said.

The cabinet made the final decision and, on the authority of the cabinet, 36 people have been invited. When we have a full list of 36 people who have accepted the invitation to be at the convention, their names will be announced—in due course. I do not think I can add any more. I am not sure whether I have missed one of your questions.

Yes, I have: you asked how many we wrote to and who they were. As I have said before—and it is on the public record—some 850 names were put forward, either self‐nominated or nominated by other groups. The government also had access to a whole range of names of people who were not formally nominated or self‐nominated, and it gave consideration to those. A very wide range of Australians has been considered for the 36 appointed positions.

BREAK.PARA: As you well know, we invited your party and the Democrats to nominate people, and those nominations have been given proper consideration. We also asked every other government in Australia—all state and territory governments—to submit names. We asked the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy and the Australian Republican Movement to nominate people whom they thought we should consider.

So we think it has been a very open process. We have been receiving names from people since last year. We said—in the election and during the course of last year—that it was our intention to have a convention, so people have been writing to us since then, suggesting their names or those of others. The convention was confirmed in March, and we have had a considerable increase in the flow of people who have been putting their names forward since March. In terms of what this is about, the process of choosing 36 non‐parliamentary appointed delegates has been quite fair, open and reasonable. I was pleased to hear Senator Bob Collins—obviously judging from information he has received in relation to some of those who have been invited—say that it was a very fair, proper, reasonable and representative group of Australians.

Senator BOLKUS (South Australia) (South Australia) (9.28 p.m.)—I did ask you who made the appointment, but the intent of that question was to find out what process was established to put names to cabinet. In other words, who was in the selection team that decided on the names to go to cabinet? Where were they—what department were they in or were they in ministerial offices? I did not quite get your answer in terms of which organisations were approached.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister is the minister who is ultimately responsible for the convention, and it was the Prime Minister who took the recommendation to the cabinet. The cabinet made a decision, and you know how cabinets work. There was plenty of discussion and plenty of suggestions as to what there finally should be. Ultimately, it was a cabinet decision.

BREAK.PARA: I have already said that the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats, every state and territory government, the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy and the Australian Republican Movement were specifically invited to submit names and did so, and those were given proper consideration. A whole range of other organisations, including the ALGA, for example, submitted names. There were, as I say, a total of 850 formal nominations—either self‐nominated or otherwise—and the cabinet had the prerogative of considering a whole lot of other Australians as well who were not necessarily formally nominated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, can I get a list of those organisations that were approached? You have mentioned a couple of organisations which we already know about, and obviously a lot of people self-nominated, but the government did initiate correspondence with organisations and individuals. Can we get a list of those? Secondly, can you tell us which public servants from which departments were involved in the process of actually selecting the names to go to cabinet?

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is reasonable to talk about which public servants from which departments were putting names to the government for this. I would have thought that was entirely unreasonable. The Prime Minister is ultimately responsible for the submission going to cabinet and the normal process of government would be adopted. We are not going to start naming public servants from particular departments in relation to that matter. I think that is a little unreasonable. What was the preceding question?
—The list of organisations.

—You raised this in the Legal and Constitutional References Committee and I thought I had written to you telling you formally which organisations had been asked to submit names. I am sure I did that in writing some time ago.

—I do not think it is unreasonable to try to ascertain whether the selection process involved public servants, though obviously you are refusing to give names. Can you tell us whether any public servant was involved in the actual process of selecting the names to go to cabinet?

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can quite confidently say that, no, that was not the case. They were not involved in the process of selecting the names to go to cabinet.
—We seem to have had a discussion about the previous amendment. Senator Bolkus, is there anything you wish to add about your amendment No. 82, which is the one before the committee at this stage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not moved it yet, so I will do that now. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (82) Page 1 (after line 11), after the title, insert:

This Act provides the necessary framework for the election and appointment of delegates to a Constitutional Convention to represent the views of all Australians about possible changes to the Constitution.
The Convention will provide a forum for debate about:
. whether the present Constitution should be changed so that Australia might become a republic with its own Head of State; and
. what republican models should be put to the voters of Australia as elements of the choice between the present system and a new system; and
. the timeframe and the appropriate circumstances for considering change.

If it is to be successful, it is vital that the Constitutional Convention reflects the diverse experiences, backgrounds, views, beliefs and aspirations of the Australian people. To that end, the appointment of non‐parliamentary delegates to the Convention should reflect the diversity of our nation. Furthermore, it is to be hoped that all groups standing for election to the Convention will draw upon our diversity when nominating candidates. In particular, and in light of the fact that the Constitutional Conventions of the 1890s which led to Federation were composed entirely of male delegates, it is to be hoped that all groupings will provide for the fair and equal representation of women.

Amendment 82 is the amendment that imports into the bill a preamble. We think a preamble is important as a reflection of the importance of this process we are involved in. We are in the process of working towards Australia becoming a republic, and we think this convention has a particular responsibility to help build towards that road.

As I said the day before yesterday, we think the objects clause that the government had in the legislation—the purpose of the act—is pretty barren and sterile and does not reflect the sorts of considerations that need to be reflected in the early part of a bill such as this. What we are suggesting is that a preamble should appear on page 1 after line 11 and the preamble should detail:
This Act provides the necessary framework for the election and appointment of delegates . . .
We should also set out what we think the convention should do, such as:
The Convention will provide a forum for debate about:
. whether the present Constitution should be changed so that Australia might become a republic with its own Head of State . . .
Other considerations relating to Australia becoming a republic should also be included.

The other important aspect of the preamble, and one that does pick up some of the debate we had earlier today, is that we think it should be reflected in the legislation that, for the convention to be as successful as possible, it needs to reflect the composition of the Australian society. The government have said to a certain extent that they have tried to do that with their appointments. Obviously, the constituent groups and individuals which will be running will try to reflect the diversity of the Australian community.

We think it is important that the preamble of the legislation reflect that we have come a long way since the 1890s—the time when the federation convention was entirely made up of male delegates, as Senator Bob Collins mentioned earlier. We should now reflect the fact that we are a diverse society with different backgrounds, views and aspirations. That diversity should be reflected in this particular convention to maximise the chances of its success and relevance to the community.

Also, we want to embody in our preamble the aspiration that groupings will provide fair and equal representation of women in their lists to be put up for election. We think this preamble is appropriate and relevant for a process like this. As we said earlier when we amended out clause 6—the purpose of the act—we thought a preamble such as this was much more appropriate than that sterile purpose put up by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support opposition amendment No. 82. We concur broadly with the remarks made by Senator Bolkus. I would indicate that the defeat of our amendment—as a result of Labor voting against it—to advance the cause of, as near as possible, equal representation from both genders means that this at least addresses some of that problem by referring to the need for fair and equal representation of women in the appointment and election of delegates. Accordingly, we will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I cannot resist the temptation, having heard the last statement of Senator Minchin, in respect of the previous matter, of how appalling a proposition it was that the parliament would usurp the power of the executive. I clearly recall—and I think it is fair to give Senator Minchin the credit for this—that Senator Minchin was the most trenchant public critic of the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in respect of his constant assertions that he was `hijacking this particular debate'. Those comments were made by Senator Minchin. I have to say that I do not know anyone, including Paul Keating, who could have asserted the rights of the executive over this parliament more aggressively than Senator Minchin just did. I just point that out in passing.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly support Senator Bolkus's amendment and preamble. Preambles do, where appropriate, play an important role. Nothing could be more appropriate than this preamble, in terms of this particular piece of legislation. This preamble will indicate clearly, if it is carried and supported subsequently in the House of Representatives, the will of this parliament as to the balance of this convention and, in a real sense, to the outcome of it.

BREAK.PARA: The Prime Minister, of course, is a powerful person in these debates. It is a matter of great regret to me that the current Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Howard), although he is absolutely entitled to his view, is so wedded to the past rather than to the future and has so clearly laid down his position on this matter. As I just said, if this convention determines—and I do not think it will—that the status quo and the constitution that has served us well for the last 100 years is in fact the appropriate basis for the next 100 years, it will have been a failure, and a profound failure. But the Prime Minister is certainly of that view.

Frankly, I do not think anyone could have summed it up better than how Laurie Oakes did in the opening paragraph of his Bulletin article on the Prime Minister's current visit to Great Britain when he said:

One federal Liberal MP reckons this is the trip of John Howard's boyhood dreams. `Pussy cat, pussy cat, where have you been? I've been to London to visit the Queen, and to watch the cricket at Lord's.' Howard whipped through a visit to China in four days, working the whole time, refusing even to go to the Great Wall because it might look indulgent. But he does not mind a bit of indulgence on his first trip to the old country as Prime Minister. The pace is leisurely and the symbolism is wrong.

That is the reason I have quoted it. This is symbolic. This preamble is symbolism, and symbolism is important in public life. This convention is, as other senators have made the point this evening, a Constitutional Convention. It is not simply, as some people see it, a convention to determine whether we remain as a constitutional monarchy or we have an Australian as our own head of state and become a minimalist or a maximalist republic. It is going to go far more widely than that, as I am sure Senator Minchin hopes. It is going to talk about the constitutional basis for the kind of Australia that we will have over the next century.

It is very timely indeed that it is happening. The make‐up of this Constitutional Convention, however selected, will be dramatically different from the one that was constituted at the turn of the century. I point out, as Senator Harradine knows full well in terms of his concerns a little earlier, that it is a cold, hard fact—having read widely of those constitutional conventions, particularly the earlier ones that failed—that, if it had been proposed and insisted upon that there be not the same level of representation from each state, no matter how different the populations were, there certainly would have been no Federation, not in 1901 at least, because there would have been no agreement on it.

But we do live in a different Australia today, and that is what concerns me about the make‐up of this convention. It is why I think this preamble is so important in at least giving some leadership at the federal parliamentary level to what kind of convention this should be. The reason I say that—Senator Margetts commented on this earlier this evening—is that there will be a lot of people at this convention with different views and different agendas for this country of ours. That is precisely what this convention is there to sort out.

Senator Margetts agreed that it could well be the first run around the paddock for the Pauline Hanson One Nation party. I will be amazed if that party, which are busily formally recruiting members right across Australia at the moment, do not use this election for this convention to try to get their candidates, as they are entitled to do, to put their view of what kind of Australia we should have.
