To my great dismay, I saw for the first time today the material that is being circulated in my home city of Darwin, where I have lived for 30 years. I am dismayed at the prospect of anyone from that party turning up at that convention and having any influence over it. The view that they would have—totally contrary to the terms of this amendment—would be that you cannot be an Australian unless you are white, you certainly cannot be an Australian if you are black and you certainly cannot be an Australian if you are Asian.

It is an extremist view. It is a view of bigots. It is a view of extremists. It is the view of peddlers of hate and division in this country. It is the view of a number of very dangerous people, as Senator Boswell very correctly pointed out yesterday, that are deter mined to destroy utterly the inclusive and tolerant society that Australia generally is today. It is dangerous, but it is happening right now as we are debating this bill.

There is a recruitment drive going on in the city of Darwin at the moment for members for Pauline Hanson's One Nation party. This emerged for the first time, I think, yesterday in Darwin. Advertisements are being placed and people are being direct mailed. I just want to advise the Senate of the letter that has been sent out which says:
Thanks very much for your letter. Please find enclosed enough membership forms—
these are membership forms for the Pauline Hanson One Nation party—
for you and your friends. I am not a One Nation Branch. I decided to run the ad out of my own private support for Ms Hanson. The response has been worth it.
What follows are all the contact telephone numbers and fax numbers for the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and her party headquarters. The final paragraph says:
I also include a magazine from Queensland, which caters to a white nationalist taste. If you are interested, it is really worth the while to read or subscribe.
Yours sincerely.
Ms J. Martin.

Her business card is enclosed. In fact, she invites people to advertise this widely. But what then is enclosed is this appalling document, a magazine printed every fortnight, which is called An eye for an eye . It is a fortnightly news bulletin described by the editor himself as, `This is your official bulletin of revenge!'

What then follows is the usual garbage, but it is dangerous garbage. What then follows is a reference in the golfing section to Tiger Woods, that outstanding athlete from the United States, describing him as `that black Asian‐American half breed Tiger Woods', et cetera. Included in this newspaper is an endorsement of our own Chief Minister's comments just recently in respect of Aboriginal itinerants, the drunken ones, needing to be `monstered and stomped on by the community'. He gets a pat on the back. There is the usual diatribe claiming the Holocaust never happened. There is an extraordinary attack on the front page, and I will quote it:

How long will it be before that repugnant and pregnant Nicky Buckley is removed from Sale of the Century? If John Howard is as old fashioned and morally pure as he says he is, then he should act on this breach of good taste.

What follows is a draft letter to be sent to politicians, saying that Nicky Buckley should be taken off television because she is pregnant. I understand she had her baby, a son, today. I wish both mother and son very well. This is an appalling document.

So that I will not go on at any length I will seek leave to table this document. I cleared this earlier with the whip, Senator Heffernan. People can read it for themselves. This material is being circulated along with membership forms for the Pauline Hanson party. The reason I wanted to make this point is I do believe this party will make a serious attempt at getting delegates elected to this convention. Of course they will. I seek leave to table this document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Boswell did this country a service by describing in some detail the people behind the One Nation party. Today the honourable member for Oxley responded to Senator Boswell by saying, `Senator Boswell's attack was a tirade of silliness.' Sadly, it was not anything of the sort.

BREAK.PARA: The city of Darwin, which I have been proud to call my home for 30 years, has had two Asian‐Australian mayors. The President of its first Legislative Council was also an Asian‐Australian. It is largely a tolerant and inclusive city. That is one of the major reasons I have chosen to make it my home for the last 30 years. I am dismayed and disheartened that this material, the first of this kind I have ever seen, is currently being circulated in my home city of Darwin in an attempt to recruit members to Pauline Hanson's One Nation party. With the greatest respect to the member for Oxley, if she seriously considers Senator Boswell's material yesterday to be silliness and is not prepared to pay any attention to it, she has literally no idea of what she has started.

In conclusion, I reject the kind of Australia that these particular supporters of the Pauline Hanson `One Nation' party want. I very strongly support the sentiments of this amendment and this preamble that what we want for the next 100 years is a tolerant, inclusive and equal society for all of us.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment relates to the opposition proposal for a preamble to the bill. Given that the Wik decision has now revealed that the preamble to the Native Title Act was irrelevant and wrong, much to the distress of the pastoralists of Australia, I guess we should not get too hung up about preambles. They clearly do not carry as much weight as perhaps Senator Bolkus would like preambles to carry.
—Do you want us to come in on it?

—No, I do not—and I will leave my remarks at that. My point was that I am not getting hung up about preambles, but there is a problem with this one in that the wording refers to the election and appointment of delegates. It has been written on the presumption that the clause which was to provide for the parliamentary appointment of delegates would be included. Of course, that is not part of the bill so those words no longer have any meaning or relevance. On that basis we would oppose the preamble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend the amendment by deleting the two words `and appointment'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment will now read:

SPEECH.PARA: (82) Page 1 (after line 11), after the title, insert:
This Act provides the necessary framework for the election of delegates to a Constitutional Convention to represent the views of all Australians about possible changes to the Constitution.
The Convention will provide a forum for debate about:
. whether the present Constitution should be changed so that Australia might become a republic with its own Head of State; and
. what republican models should be put to the voters of Australia as elements of the choice between the present system and a new system; and
. the timeframe and the appropriate circumstances for considering change.

If it is to be successful, it is vital that the Constitutional Convention reflects the diverse experiences, backgrounds, views, beliefs and aspirations of the Australian people. To that end, the appointment of non‐parliamentary delegates to the Convention should reflect the diversity of our nation. Furthermore, it is to be hoped that all groups standing for election to the Convention will draw upon our diversity when nominating candidates. In particular, and in light of the fact that the Constitutional Conventions of the 1890s which led to Federation were composed entirely of male delegates, it is to be hoped that all groupings will provide for the fair and equal representation of women.
Are you happy with that now?

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Bolkus, we do accept that amendment but, in speaking on behalf of the government, I would have to say that we would still be in the position of having to oppose this preamble. I do not want to sound unduly petulant, but the reference to the head of state raises issues about which members of the government and opposition do disagree. If it is said that Australia might become a republic, we might have less problem with it, but I think the totality of the wording is such that it is not capable of being amended on the spot now in a manner which I could on behalf of the government accept. Therefore, I would have to say we oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the point that is made by Senator Minchin. It may well be seen by some in the government that those are not neutral words and may not in fact reflect in totality the bill as currently amended. Also, I am rather hesitant to support amendments to legislation which have words such as `it is hoped that'. Legislation normally should be clear and concise. I do not like the words `it is hoped that'. Notwithstanding those two points and to allow the government to come back with perhaps a suitable amendment to this, I think the merit in this proposition is that in general it does put forward a preamble that is somewhat fuller than that which is currently in the bill. Therefore, I will support this proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will not be proceeding with amendment No. 63.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I now advise that the we will not be moving amendment No. 83. We will also not be moving amendment No. 1 on page 11. Since we have not changed the nature of the bill, that amendment is also redundant.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Minchin) agreed to:
That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
(Quorum formed)
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1997-98

The purpose of this bill is to appropriate the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the running costs and capital expenditures of the parliamentary departments for the year ending 30 June 1998. The total amount sought is $138.5 million.
Details of the proposed expenditures are set out in the Schedule to the bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1997-98
This bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1997‐98 totalling $32,549.6 million.

Appropriation Bill (No. 1) provides for proposed expenditure on the ordinary annual services of Government. The expenditure program of the Government, to which the provisions in this bill relate, was outlined in the Treasurer's Budget Speech, on 13 May.
Details of the proposed expenditure are set out in the Schedule to the bill, the main features of which were outlined in the Treasurer's Budget Speech.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1997-98
This bill seeks appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund in 1997‐98 totalling $5,867 million.
Appropriation Bill (No. 2) provides for proposed expenditure on:
the construction of public works and buildings;
the acquisition of sites and buildings;
certain advances and loans;
items of plant and equipment which are clearly definable as capital in nature; and
expenditure on new policy initiatives for which legislation has not been previously approved.
Provision is also made for grants to the States under section 96 of the Constitution and for payments to the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.
Details of the proposed expenditure are set out in Schedule 2 to the bill, the main features of which were outlined in the Budget Speech delivered by my colleague, the Treasurer, on 13 May.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 has been introduced into this parliament as a result of the budget last year when the government descended into a cost cutting frenzy without regard to the effect of that cost cutting. This bill should not be before the parliament tonight. It is a bill that has been substantially gutted by the government, and the amendments that the government has foreshadowed to its own legislation are huge. The government proposes to remove those sections of this bill which relate to ship construction. The government proposes to oppose its own amendments in this bill which relate to machine tools and robotics.

SPEECH.PARA: What the government has not explained is why it does not take the same attitude to the bounties that apply to the computer industry in Australia or why it does not take the same view that applies to the book publishing industry in Australia. The fact that the government is selective leaves the government open to the allegation, which in this case is profoundly true, that the government reacts to political pressure and does not act within a logical policy structure on industry policy.

As a consequence, I propose to move at the conclusion of my remarks an amendment to the second reading which I understand is being circulated in the chamber. That amendment will draw attention to the government's approach here and to the government's explicit duplicity when, in the 1996 election, it promised faithfully to the computer industry of Australia that the Labor government's extension of the computer bounty to the year 2000 would be honoured by the coalition. This legislation explicitly breaks that promise and it does so blatantly and without any justifiable explanation.

This government has plunged Australian industry into confusion and despair as to what its policy really is. This bill, in its original form, cut out bounty assistance to ships, to books, to machine tools and robotics and to computer manufacturing. It did so in a manner ahead of the time of the normal termination of these bounties as set down in statutes. Thus, it reduced the competitiveness of Australian industry by weakening the industry's confidence in the future. It reduced the competitiveness of Australian industry by disrupting industry's forward planning. It reduced the competitiveness of Australian industry by, in several cases, explicitly causing Australian companies to lose contracts. That is a documented fact.

In the case of the shipbuilding industry, contracts have been lost to overseas bidders because of the government's inability to act quickly to deal with the problems of that sector. The same is true in the machine tools area, the books area and, doubtless would be true, if one investigated it completely, in the computer area. Because the government has caused private sector companies to lose contracts, disrupted their forward planning and disrupted their structural plans, they have also put a brake on employment growth and on the optimum outcome for these industry sectors for Australia. That goes against the needs of a national economy and is a sad indictment of the government's attitude in this area.

This legislation went ahead without consultation with industry. There was no time to give notice to industry to adjust to the needs of the future, because this was imposed on them, out of the blue, on budget night without warning. Minister Moore remained imperious and aloof to industry entreaties upon the announcement after the budget. His door was closed and only prised open with selective pressure from various industry groups. Not all got in to see him and, when some of them did, they got a very cold reception indeed. Initially, that meant that the future for those industry sectors was cast into considerable doubt. Only after considerable pressure did some of those sectors gain some of the rights that they were obviously entitled to.

This legislation was justified on the grounds of fiscal consolidation. But it was done so without any consideration or analysis, any investigation or inquiry as to what the effects of these cuts would be on industry, what the effects of these cuts would therefore be in terms of the wider economy and, ultimately, whether the cause of fiscal consolidation would be achieved or not. By cutting the outlays on bounties, the government did not consider the brake it would put on growth in these sectors and, therefore, the contribution these industries could make to the income side of the budget by higher employment, by less reliance on unemployment and by a range of other profit taxes that these companies would pay.It only cut out negatively, and in a way which goes against the budget bottom line, these bounties.

On the grounds of fiscal consolidation, it cut out these bounties in the face explicitly of a report of the now Productivity Commission, which argued, in the case of the computer bounty, that that bounty should be continued. The Productivity Commission is notorious as the ultra dry economic advice agency of the government. After an extended review of 2½ years, that agency said that this bounty should continue.

The government cut this bounty out in the face of that advice and did not consider the ongoing inquiry that the Productivity Commission had into the book bounty at the time either. It did not wait for the inquiry to report; it cut out the bounty. It did so as well on the grounds of fiscal consolidation without any thought or recognition of the un‐level international playing field in the international marketplace that these industry sectors have to compete in. It just did it without thought, without consideration, without analysis and without concern for the impact on growth, companies, their profitability, the workers they employ and the prospects for employment in the future.

The government proposes, as I have said, to substantially amend this bill. It does so selectively, and the selection choice seems to be based on how effective the lobby was rather than on a framework of policy for industry. What is clear is that this government has a piecemeal approach to industry policy. It has not thought out framework structure for industry policy. In fact, it admits that itself. It is conducting the Mortimer review into industry policy in Australia to see what its industry policy should be. That review has not yet reported. That review will not be able to be encapsulated in the last budget. We will have to wait at least another year before the outcome of that review is implemented.

In the meanwhile, Australian industry wallows around not knowing the signal this government is emitting to them. It knows what it emits to some sections of industry that can bring pressure to bear. It does not know what the objective reality is for all industry.

Having said that, I, of course, applaud the decision in the case of the ships industry. I make no apology in this parliament that I align myself to the cause of this industry sector and that I campaigned in order that its bounty be restored, as I did with the other three sectors under this bill.

The fact that the ships sector was successful says a lot about the campaigning ability of industry leaders in that sector, about the spectacular growth that that particular industry had achieved, coming from nothing in eight years to currently earning half a billion in exports, and leading the world in the only area of complex sophisticated technology where Australia can say it is the world leader. Those facts put together create a stunning story of growth and achievement, which even this government had to recognise and finally concede.

BREAK.PARA: But having said that, the other industry sectors in their own way can produce equally compelling evidence as well. I will come to those in a moment. The machine tools and robotics industry is a key industry that supports the rest of Australian industry achievement in complex manufactures because it is at the cutting edge of modern day technology and equipment for manufacture. In the case of that industry, the fact that this bill has been delayed for so long meant that the individual firms concerned were able to still legally access the bounty. Now the government's change is to allow that to occur, it has been defeated on the ground by those companies, given the delay this legislation has had in coming to the chamber. The government rightly and sensibly recognises that it cannot claim the bounty back off those companies to the time it originally intended to prematurely remove this bounty.

The areas in which this government has decided to continue with its cuts to the bounty refer to the computer bounty industry sector and the books bounty industry sector. The government will chop their bounties and all of those things that I said earlier about lack of consideration, lack of analysis and the fiscal imperative that I cited earlier apply equally to these industries—and, in fact, more so.

In the case of the computer industry, following a Productivity Commission inquiry, the Labor government, at a time in which I had the privilege of being industry minister, put through a bill in this parliament to extend the computer bounty to the year 2000. I vividly recall the debate in this chamber on the night that legislation went through. I see, much to his personal discomfort, I am sure, that the minister carrying this legislation tonight on behalf of the government, is Senator Warwick Parer. Senator Parer at that time spoke in that debate on the computer bounty and said—and it is in Hansard, if anyone wishes to check it—that the coalition would support the government in extending the computer bounty to the year 2000. He went on to say—as his party did and as his Prime Minister and industry minister did in the election campaign—that they supported the computer industry by that solid, solemn promise.

Since the election, we have learnt of the reinterpretation of election promises by this government. It appears now that that solemn, sober promise made by Senator Warwick Parer is to be repudiated—and tonight, no doubt, or tomorrow, he will explain why it is that the government proposes to break it and why his personal speech in the chamber that night is to be repudiated. He will explain that that was not a core promise. It was just another promise that was disposable and it is in the trash can now, irrespective of the particular needs of this industry.

I want to say these things about the computer industry. The computer industry and the telecommunications industry together form the fastest growing industry sector in the world. In fact, together, they are the biggest industry sector in the world. Australia is a voracious consumer of computer equipment. Our level of technology literacy in the area of IT&T leads the world or is at the leading edge among the leading countries of the world. We have a trade deficit in computer and computer technology of $6 billion a year as we stand here now, and under the forecast growth of demand in the Australian domestic economy for computer and telecommunications equipment, by the year 2000, even with the bounty, we will have a deficit in trade of $20 billion.

A government that is concerned about the blowing out of its trade deficit would not do this, and tonight it should confess that it will not do this. If it is concerned about the blowing out of its current account deficit, it will ensure—by prematurely cutting a bounty that this industry had as a bipartisan political decision in 1995 and on which the industry planned its future development to the year 2000—that it stunts the growth of this industry, opens the door to imports, loses jobs from Australia, and pushes Australian companies overseas. It will mean that our economy is destabilised by the running up of an even higher current account trade deficit.

The impact and the damage to the economy will be huge. The impact on regional Australia will also be felt widely, because this industry is not just located in the major capitals of Sydney and Melbourne. It is located in country Victoria, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide, Tasmania and all around Australia. The damage to the regional economy in the sunrise industry of the 21st century will be huge, and this government has a lot to answer for for prematurely moving to strip down the Australian competitive ability in this industry sector.

In the case of the books industry, this is one of those industries that is a story of achievement by Australians. What is not commonly known is that Australian book publishers supply a lot of the curriculum in the United States school system for education purposes. Australian book publishers supply a lot of the basic texts for the Californian and Florida education system. They provide a lot of the current texts in terms of the writing and editing and the designing and presentation of those books for the Malayasian, Indian and Chinese education systems as well.

We have here an industry that has grown out of the intellectual capacity of our country and the multicultural nature of Australia. It is able to write high quality publications that succeed in the first markets of the world in the United States, and translate, adapt and sell them to the emerging economies of our region as well. It is a commitment that ought to achieve recognition by the government as the sort of thing that we expect Australian entrepreneurs to do. Instead, the bounty for this industry is to be cut out.

By the industry's own calculations, they have produced an illustration of how wrong‐headed and how bad the effect of that will be on their industry. By the industry's own calculations, it is an industry worth, at current dollar values, $450 million a year. The book bounty that will be saved by the abolition in this bill will be $5 million a year, but the negative impact caused by the abolition of the book bounty will create a deficit—and a deficit by a decline in PAYE taxpaying because of loss of employment in this industry sector—of $9.6 million by a loss of payroll tax of $2.7 million and by the payment of unemployment benefits to displaced Australians of $21 million: a total of $33.3 million. The net negative impact of the cut of a $5 million bounty in this industry sector to the national economy is $28.3 million. And that is not all of it either.

There will be a $120 million adverse effect on the balance of payments. In terms of employment, there is an expected loss of 1,500 jobs, mainly in Maryborough in Victoria and in Queensland. That is not the end of it either. Because of the arrangements that apply to tariff levels for imported paper—70 per cent of this industry's publications are printed on Australian paper; 30 per cent is imported—and the special quality papers needed, a tariff of five per cent is applied. So already, for this industry to be internationally competitive, it has to jump a five per cent cost hurdle to import its paper needs, to print its product in Australia and to distribute it to the world.

The Senate Economics Committee inquiry into this legislation was unanimous in saying that that is an anomalous position and it is a negative assistance to the industry of in excess of five per cent and that the government should remove that tariff in so far as the needs of this industry are concerned. We have seen a unanimous, bipartisan recommendation from this Senate's Economics Committee and a recommendation not responded to in any positive way from the government.

For those reasons and for the reasons that I have cited in the case of the computer industry and the book industry, I will be moving an amendment to the second reading which will call upon the government to consult with these industry sectors to develop industry sector plans so that all of the impacts in costs on these industry sectors can be considered and a plan for their growth and development with that industry sector can be developed to put these industries back on the line of further growth. The impact in the case of the book industry will not be felt only in industry; it will be felt in the cultural standards of Australia—in the education system of Australia—as well as in exports.

If we look at a model for the book industry and the type of psychology behind the cuts to the bounty that have been introduced here, the model would be New Zealand. What happened in the case of New Zealand? With the removal of assistance, there is now no book manufacturing industry whatsoever in the two islands of New Zealand. The industry has gone into decline and vanished. The same fate awaits it here with the removal of this bounty and with the failure of the government to do anything at all about developing a plan for this industry sector so that it can grow.

The issue here is that the government should withdraw this legislation, rethink its direction and then come forward after proper consultations with industry, after proper analysis of the industry impacts of this legislation and after knowing what will occur rather than hoping and guessing and leaping in the dark, with plans and legislation to support industry development in Australia. If this government fails to do so, all of its words about support for industry and support for small business are empty rhetoric.

While the government refuses to develop a framework for industry development in this country, it undermines the ability of Australian industry to have confidence in government direction and planning and to know the platform upon which they have to develop their own industry sector in order to grow. The government needs to emit a long, strong, clear signal of support for industry and the direction that it wants it to develop. We did that in government. This government abolished it in the budget before last. It is not too late, despite the loss of production, jobs and growth that has occurred in the intervening period, to come back to the aid of Australian industry. This government should do so. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate:

(a) rejects outright the Government's failure to develop and implement a policy for Australian manufacturing industry and is of the view that, because of the inevitable impact this bill will have on employment, the bill would be more appropriately referred to as the Bounty Legislation (Export of Australian Jobs) Amendment Bill; and
(b) calls on the Government to keep the ships bounty in place until the OECD Shipbuilding Agreement comes into force; and
(c) calls on the Government to develop with industry an industry growth plan to the Machine Tools and Robotics industry sector, the Book Publishing and Printing sector; and
(d) condemns the Government for breaking its own election commitment to maintain the Computer Bounty until the year 2000."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 covers the elimination of the ships bounty, the book bounty, the computer bounty and the machine tools and robots bounty. Basically, it is an attack on industry policy. The bounties were all set to terminate anyway. The government was just hastening it. Unfortunately for the government, I guess, it did not expedite the bill. The result ends up being a stupidity where, with a measure originally set to terminate in a month, the government will now try to backdate termination to 1996. It is therefore basically retroactive.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the ships bounty, the government was lobbied heavily and seemed to accept that it should leave this alone. The current termination date is 30 June 1997. With this change, they must have been under construction or contract by 20 August 1996 to qualify. If under contract, they must have been contracted for completion by 30 June this year.

There is a heavy subsidy of overseas industries. The United States refused to join an anti‐subsidy agreement. Therefore, there is none. Builders argued for a pro rata bounty for ships that were partly completed on termination. This will result in a slow escalation in price rather than a steep increase in price. This is, of course, yet another blow to shipbuilding and perhaps ships of a good standard in Australia, along with the elimination of tariff concessions, ship grants and accelerated depreciation. They are all going at the same time. The ships bounty has been valuable, particularly for the Tasmanian catamarans and for Perth industry. There are other examples that I am sure senators have been informed about.

This bill also relates to the books bounty. The current termination date is 31 December 1997; this legislation will mean that it terminated on 20 August last year. The transitional arrangements now are if production started or a contract existed. If they specify the title of the book by the termination date, they can still get the bounty up until 20 February this year. Industry had already planned for a wind‐down. Financing for the industry reflected that. Early termination threatens this.

The long-term contracts for paper and so on were taken based on expectations of the bounty. The book industry in Australia works on small margins. It is highly competitive in relation to costs of offshore printing. The loss of the tax revenue and higher unemployment in some areas will be a consequence of the decision. As was mentioned by Senator Cook, paper is taxed at five per cent and books are imported tax free, so it is obviously going to be cheaper to import with this change.

The Industry Commission's comments appear to be based on fantasy. They said that there was a growing book industry when in fact it was stagnant. There also seems to be an inflated reporting of customs administration costs.

In relation to computers, the current termination date is 31 December 2000; and the proposed termination is 30 June this year. Information technology is a critical industry. The bounty tended to be a compensation for the small local market.

The tariff concession changes, outsourcing and research and development concession all impact negatively on the computer industry. In 1996, parliament decided to extend the scheme to 2000. There was, as you can imagine, some expectation that this would be honoured and investments were made and loans were taken on that premise. Computers are imported duty free; components are dutiable. Once again, we are favouring imports.

In relation to machine tools and robots, the current termination date is 30 June 1997; the proposed termination was last year, 20 August 1996. Under the transition arrangements, if production started or if a contract existed specifying the title of the book by the termination date, the bounty could be available until 20 February 1997. The use of a bounty rather than a tariff allows the import of tax-free machines and keeps prices down. Costs of production are high in Australia and there is a small market.

We are talking about critical production tools. If we give an incentive to make the means of production here, we will move into much higher value added products and that will lead to export and import replacement. Often, very high skills are needed to make machine tools. Those involved in this process may move laterally to other industries, taking their skills with them. The research and development is of high intensity and it is a significant industry for other manufacturing industries.

I do not think, in these various areas, we are being particularly clever in the actions we have taken. I think what we are eventually going to have to do, some time in the not too distant future, is look at all the actions we are taking. We are going to have to look at whether we want to develop a high-tech industry, what we are doing in terms of value adding to industry and whether we want to forget our market altogether and import everything. In the end, something has to crack. We cannot continue to try to find primary goods—low price, high volume primary goods—to export in volume.

In the end something has to crack, and that something is employment. We know that that is what is happening. It is not about whether or not kids can be forced into schools when they feel they no longer want to go. It is about the fact that we have structured our industry. With this new love affair with internationalisation, it is inevitable that the kinds of industries we are getting are often capital intensive—they shed labour. The new ideology for the service industry is: fewer people, more machines, more computers, more centralisation. The reality is that this is the direction we are heading in. We are forgetting about our local market altogether. We are not necessarily meeting our local market needs. I think the consumer loses as well. That is a pity.

I do not think Australia should be going too far down this one-way path without ever sitting back and assessing where we are going, how we are going and why. In the not too distant future I will be coming up with some proposals for us to look in detail at trade policy and the impact it is having on employment, the environment, our social system, our regions, and so on. I think it is far overdue that we look at that. The WA Greens will not be supporting the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time before the adjournment starts, I rise to support my colleague Senator Cook. I believe there is real concern in the area of computers. SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight on the adjournment I wish to speak briefly about Marian Eldridge. Marian died in February of this year. She was a Canberran of note who should be remembered. She was born and educated in Victoria. She was a teacher of English and history. She had travelled widely in Australia and overseas. She had wide experience as a writer from the time she wrote first at university, although I think she had written much before that time as well. She was a woman of fine reputation. She was a reviewer of books of great standing and was a teacher and editor. She had worked on radio and had been involved in word festivals and many other things. She was a woman who was always thoughtful and always caring.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, she was a member of a group of Canberra writers known as the Canberra Seven Writers discussion group. In 1988 they published a book called Canberra Tales, in which Marian's contribution was called `Capital Gains', a story set around Old Parliament House. I am sure many of you, especially those who worked in that building, would enjoy reading it.

BREAK.PARA: The other writers in that group were Margaret Barbalet, Sara Dowse, Suzanne Edgar, Marion Halligan, Dorothy Horsfield and Dorothy Johnston. When I say `the others were', it will not be the same without Marian Eldridge, although the remaining six no doubt will still meet and discuss as they have in the past.

Marian was the ACT Arts Council literature coordinator and a writer‐in‐residence in the Northern Territory. She has won many awards and has been a member of many learned literary societies. She was friend to many, certainly to her husband, Ken; her daughters, Elizabeth and Catherine; her sons, David and James; their partners and her grandchildren.

Marian wrote many short stories, and they are all worth reading. Her books which have been published have been donated by her husband, Ken, and placed in the Parliamentary Library. So they are available for you to read. One might ask, `Why did she die so young; why so far ahead of the three score years and 10 that one expects?' In fact, these days a woman can expect to live to 80 or beyond. But Marian contracted cancer and died at the age of 61.

During her last days, her last months, while she was suffering from cancer and reflecting, and her family were reflecting with her on why it should be happening, she wrote 12 poems. Several of them have been published, and one was read at the opening of the Word Festival, held in Canberra earlier this year. The 12 poems are worth reading and are worth publishing. Tonight I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate them in Hansard so they are available for people to read.

Ann Holt walks with money in her stride ‐

Elizabeth introduces her as a woman of exquisite taste, some one who reads fashion magazines the way women read illustrated cookery books, whose advice is invaluable at specials and annual sales and who goes to every one
She looks keen enough
Run to catch up! Run, catch her sharp, polished shoes!
"This would suit," she says, "I can just see . . . " and I feel a tapestry needle of envy, because I want the lovely waistcoat for myself
"I don't know where to begin," I tell her.

Ann Holt smiles. "What did you have in mind?" she asks, picking up a burnt orange jumper and holding it across her miniature bosom in front of a mirror. I tell her she looks a million dollars, and she tosses the jumper at me.
"Yes but the neck! I will look double‐chinned!"
Soon I am carrying the burnt orange, the blue, the bone ("We used to call them twinsets" I tell her), the black and white waistcoat ‐
I tell her what I had in mind was a sheath dress, red wool ‐ and there it is on the rack in front of me
"It's you," Ann Holt assures me. "Now what about this blazer for real elegance?"
"I have a black wool blazer," I protest, all at once terrified of elegant persuasion.
"But not with velvet revers," says Elizabeth.
Frowning like a greedy child, I try the blazer on. There's something funny about the cut.
"Too fat," I sigh, secretly relieved
"Nonsense," says Ann Holt. She hurries me to the counter. "This jacket is badly tailored," she tells the assistant.
The assistant is indignant. "Perhaps Madam's hips . . . "

Ann Holt grows taller by the moment. "Excuse me," she says quietly, "This has nothing to do with Modom's hip. My mother, who was employed as a tailor in this store, would never allow a miscut garment on to the showroom. Please show us another blazer immediately." But there is no other blazer. Ann Holt stares at the ceiling. Then something funny happens. Here over the manager's arm is the very blazer, which someone is supposed to pay for in the next half hour, by closing time.
"Poor woman, she'll be so . . . " I mouth at Elizabeth.
Elizabeth shrugs.
"Coffee!" gasps Ann Holt.
"So which are you buying, Ann?" I ask, with a backwards glance at our clothes piled on the counter. I see a look pass between the two young women.
Talk gets around to a poetry reading they have both been to recently, and then to Dorothy Porter's poetry, and then to Dorothy's dress sense.
"I could make something of that woman," says Ann Holt
Suddenly Ann Holt says "Marian, you should come out. You'd make a wonderful lesbian."
"Ann Holt! I'm straight as a die . . . Whatever would my husband think?"
"Oh, men! . . . I'm not talking about men!"
We laugh some more, and talk about lesbians, and then it's time to make our purchases.

"Are you really not going to buy anything at the annual sale, Ann?" I ask, shocked, trying to persuade her to take the matching bra and pants she is admiring. While she is checking off our selections, Elizabeth whispers that Ann Holt really has no money to buy clothes. She reads fashion magazines and she window shops and she dreams.
"Ann Holt," I say, while my credit card is being checked, "this is a date for next year. Okay?"
"Yay."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I respect the fine words you spoke in memory of that well‐known Canberra writer. I want to say a few words on the adjournment tonight as a follow‐up to my speech yesterday regarding the constitutional convention. During that speech, I made some comments about the fact that some people in Australia, in the constitutional monarchy camp, claim that the Governor-General is our head of state. I pointed out that that was an absurdity.

SPEECH.PARA: During that debate, I also made reference to the fact that the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Evans, has written many articles. In fact, I have gone back to my file and got them all out to refresh myself. He has been a prolific writer—I say that not in a pejorative sense—on the issue of the constitution, the republic and the powers of the Senate, et cetera. That has been part of the public debate.

I think it is true to say, after having read through most of this material that I have refreshed my memory on, that the clerk, Mr Evans, has taken an unusual position on some aspects of the republic debate. Again, I do not say that in a pejorative sense. But when you look at some of the views he has raised, they are quite legitimate and are part of the public debate. At one stage in the debate I said:

I have even seen articles written by our eminent Clerk of the Senate saying that we do not need to change because in fact we are a de facto republic in every sense other than whom our head of state is.
They are my words; they are not a direct quote from the Clerk of the Senate.

As a result of those remarks, I received a note from Mr Evans yesterday saying that my description cannot be attributed directly to him. I want to take this opportunity to put the record straight. Again, having gone back through all the material, I think the theme of what he has written can be interpreted as saying that he has a different view from us normal republicans. I do accept, from all the material that I had available, that he has not explicitly said, unlike others, that the Governor‐General is effectively our head of state.

BREAK.PARA: I refer to an article Mr Evans wrote on 17 May in the Australian. It contains an interesting variation on the argument about the republic and about constitutional structure. He said:
One could say that the Constitution—
That is, the present constitution—
is 70 per cent republican and 30 per cent monarchical.

I have to say that I disagree with that view. The constitution is clearly a constitutional monarchy, and so on. But Mr Evans clearly gives an example of why he believes his view on that matter is correct. I think the theme is there that he has a slightly different view from the one that I have about the structure and the operation of our constitution. I think that is valid, and I am not in any way criticising his right to say that in the broader debate.

If he believes the words I said in the broader context of the many articles he has written are misleading to his view that he has not actually said outright that in fact the Governor-General is our head of state, I accept that and I put it on the record that he wants that corrected. I certainly accept that. He does point out that he supports strongly that, if there is to be a republic, he wants the President elected by all the people. In several articles he goes through why he thinks that is the best way to go. He talks about a republican culture and various other things. I am not criticising the content of that. I may disagree with it, but he has a right as part of that public debate.

But he does say in his note to me that, as I had mentioned during my speech, Mr Abbott, a Liberal member in the lower House, has only as early as this week on radio described the Governor-General as our head of state. He wanted to make it quite clear, and I quote from his note to me:
I also object to being associated with Mr Abbott.

I presume on that particular matter. When I look at the remarks I made—and one is always pressed for time in these sorts of debates—I do not think I did infer that Mr Evans and Mr Abbott were in league on this issue. But Mr Evans wants to make it quite clear that he has no association with Mr Abbott on any issue dealing with the republic. I want to accept Mr Evans's view completely and without qualification. That is a correct position of course that he should have.

I think it is noted around this place that I have very strong views about the republic and at times I have expressed them strongly. Because the clerk does not have the opportunity to explain his view in this chamber when issues are raised about what he has said, I thought it was only appropriate, that I, at least in my own humble way, try to explain and take the opportunity to put on the record that he had actually written to me disagreeing with my description. I think the only other chance the clerk has to explain himself on the public record is in an estimates committee when the administration of the Senate is before the estimates committee.

Normally I would not worry about commenting about another senator objecting to something I said, because they can stand up in this place and clear the air themselves. With those few remarks, I am pleased to have had the opportunity to put in context my remarks and certainly make it clear that Mr Evans is not associated with Mr Abbott and that he has made it clear he does not accept the view that the Governor-General is in fact the head of state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to discuss some of the measures that have been proposed this week in relation to young Australians. I was quite distressed this week to see the common youth allowance announced, the specific details of which are yet to be refined and, of course, we are yet to see any legislative format for that scheme. But I think the CYA is yet another example of the scapegoating of young Australians and, specifically, young unemployed Australians today.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure comes at the end of a string of measures designed to punish, victimise, even demonise, our young people. The measures introduced that will see 16- and 17-year-olds stripped of unemployment benefits will affect 25,000 young Australians. The means testing arrangements for 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds has the potential to, if not take away benefits completely, at least reduce benefits severely for up to 50,000 young Australians in that age group. I notice that the government is expecting these young people to turn to their families for help.

For that reason, I thought it was important to put on record tonight some of the comments in the papers today, the editorials or comments from community and other organisations. Some of these were overlooked in the selective reporting or quoting we had from ministers during question time today. I notice that ACOSS comments that the scheme would hit poor families the hardest. Mr Robert Fitzgerald from ACOSS says:
Unemployed young people from lower‐paid and middle‐income families will lose most.
That concurs with an editorial in the Age in Melbourne, which states in regard to these changes:
And they place great trust in families—
that is, the government—
without trying to ease the pressures that make it increasingly difficult for many families to survive.

I think the decisions that have been made by this government in the last week totally and fundamentally misread the economic and social reality of family life in the 1990s. There seems to have been no consideration by the government—it has not taken into account whatsoever—the struggling and the hardship that families are currently undergoing. Families may have one parent, possibly even two, out of work. The means testing arrangements for this scheme do not take into account that two parents on an income of, say, $20,000 per annum would mean that young people who are unemployed and some students would lose out on their payments as a result of those threshold measures.

But the government claims that these measures have been introduced as an incentive to encourage young people to participate and stay longer in education and training institutions in this country. Why does the government not offer real incentives to young Australians? Why does it insist on introducing disincentives, be they psychological or financial, in the form of fees and charges for education and training? Even at a primary or secondary level, we are seeing increasing charges for incidentals, study and book materials.

No-one disputes that getting young people to stay in education for longer is not necessarily a bad thing, provided those education institutions at all levels are appropriately resourced or compensated. Nobody denies the fundamental link between skilling, training, educating and better work opportunities for the future, especially in such a radically different, radically restructured and constantly changing work force. However, rather than introducing incentives, as I said, this government has introduced disincentives whether they are HECS hikes, up-front and full cost fees, cuts to operating grants, a narrowing of the eligibility criteria or a lowering of the amounts for student financial assistance in the form of Austudy and Abstudy.
Has the government taken into account the pressures on the school system? The editorial in the Age states:

The new system also has unreal expectations of educational institutions. In Victoria at least, the State Government has wound back financial support for public schools and throughout Australia universities are complaining that the Federal Government is pressing them to increase enrolments while at the same time cutting their funding.
So I do not believe that the additional burden on the school system is going to be taken into account.

Certainly, I acknowledge what both Ministers Vanstone and Newman have said repeatedly in this place and in question time today that 100,000 new traineeship and apprenticeship positions will be created. But let us look at where those positions have come from. Let us look at the TAFE sector which has been cut by at least $72 million. Let us look at the number of training places that have disappeared in the form of labour market programs: at least 120,000 of those will be lost over the next three to four years.

This is particularly ironic when you look at schemes such as LEAP and REAP—those land care and environmental and regional based labour market programs that did provide young people with some training and some skill development. They would have seen potentially 75,000 places over the next three years. Yet those places have been cut in favour of the so‐called green corps.

I note that the green corps was launched with a bit of a fanfare last week in Sydney, with Mr Abbott doing his job as junior minister in that area. However, only 360 places have been made available under that scheme this year as I understand it in that region. Three thousand young people applied for those places. That contradicts any images perpetuated by this government or the media that young people are not anxious or willing to apply for jobs and that they somehow need to be compelled or required to turn up for employment opportunities. It is not true at all.

Julian Pocock, the Executive Director of the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, which is the peak national body representing young Australians in this country, is reported in the Courier‐Mail today as saying the common youth allowance policy is `draconian and a breach of the rights of teenagers to seek work'. The article continues:
Mr Pocock said 62 percent of young people completed Year 12, but the rest were often in a situation where they had to find work to support themselves or their families.
He also questioned whether there would be enough training places because 60,000 applicants could not get a place in TAFE colleges last year.

So we see many young Australians not only applying for work opportunities and training opportunities but also for TAFE. Yet 60,000 were denied entry this year alone. I note also that the amount of money originally promised for the green corps scheme was around $68 million, but only $41 million was delivered. Of course, the age range was going to be much larger than what we finally ended up with.

I do not quite understand why the emphasis this week has been on getting more young people to stay at school or on pushing them into education and training without adequate and livable incomes. One of the focuses that seems to have been lost from this debate is the creation of real, sustainable, meaningful long‐term jobs for young Australians. What do we get instead? I mentioned green corps, but also the work for the dole program—a debate that we are yet to have in this place.

Again, the work for the dole scheme is based on the premise that young people need to be compelled to work and that somehow they need to be required to look for jobs, as if this is not happening every day of the week. Young people are engaging in active searching for work. They are filling in jobseeker diaries and they are dealing with the pain and issues of rejection that come with applying for jobs that simply are not there or that many others are applying for as well.

I am sad to see some of the myths that have been perpetuated about young people in this place and in the media recently. I notice the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Fischer) was perpetuating some of these myths in the lower house yesterday. Certainly, the idea that young people are choosing to be on unemployment benefits because this provides some sort of enjoyable or interesting lifestyle where they can `swan around'—and I believe those were the words used by a government member yesterday during the debate—is sad and quite regressive.

If this government wanted to fulfil its election promise to give hope to young Australians then what it would give young Australians would be realistic education and training opportunities. It would not put up fees and charges and other barriers to education at whatever level. It would provide young Australians with realistic and adequate levels of income support; that is, livable income or income supplements, not income like Austudy or the common youth allowance which at its maximum rate is no more than 60 per cent of the poverty line, with its average rate around 35 per cent of the poverty line.

I must remark on a decision made in this place today to cut by at least a third the rent assistance available to students living in shared accommodation. What a mixed message that sends because I acknowledge one good part of the common youth allowance announced this week was the decision to extend rent assistance to some students on the common youth allowance or currently under Austudy. But how at odds with that decision was today's decision by the parliament to cut rent assistance by a third. If they are the decisions this government is going to make then young Australians are going to be caught in a poverty cycle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you should not be reflecting on a decision of the Senate made today.

—Sorry, Madam President, I acknowledge that fact. I would just put on record the difficulties that young Australians, especially those on Austudy, have accessing student financial assistance benefits. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1996 annual report, the Progress of Nations , produced by the United Nations Children's Fund, paints a depressing picture for women's health, nutrition, education and mortality. Focusing on the indicator of maternal death rates, around 600,000 women die each year in pregnancy or childbirth, 140,000 women die each year as a result of haemorrhaging during childbirth, 75,000 women die each year as a result of attempts to abort themselves, another 75,000 women die with brain and kidney damage during pregnancy, 100,000 die of sepsis and 40,000 die each year due to obstructed labour. In total, 1,600 women around the globe die each day in pregnancy or childbirth and for every woman who dies, approximately 30 more incur injuries, infections and disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the evidence that educating girls can result in increased incomes, better child health and nutrition, lower birth rates, and lower maternal and child deaths, the Progress of Nations report finds that 50 per cent of primary school age girls are locked out of the primary education system in Sub‐Saharan Africa; 22 per cent of girls are excluded from primary school education in the Middle East, Northern Africa, Asia and the Pacific; and seven per cent of primary age girls are not attending school in America or Europe.

Whilst Australia compares favourably on the international league table on the issues of health, nutrition, education and maternal morbidity, this does not mean that Australian women are immune to such problems. We await the publication of the 1995 national health survey findings, but the 1994 study found a direct link between the reported health status and socioeconomic status of women. Women who reported themselves to be of fair or poor health were 145 per cent more likely to be from low income families than from high income families, 33 per cent more likely to report suffering serious chronic illness and 159 per cent more likely to report suffering mental disorders.

Indigenous women fared much worse, with the life expectancy of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander females being 20 years less than that of the total Australian female population and indigenous females accounting for almost 15 per cent of all maternal deaths in Australia between 1985 and 1987. Infant mortality in the indigenous population is still over three times that in the total population.

With 59,000 females dying in 1995, principally from diseases of the circulatory system and different types of cancer, the central question which remains is how Australia's current health system can be improved to meet the needs of women. A status report on women's health published by Paul Mackey in May 1997 indicates that health policy measures alone will be unable to improve health outcomes and/or address the inequities in the health status of Australian women from different socioeconomic backgrounds. What is required is a holistic approach which addresses health outcomes in conjunction with a range of other measures relating to employment, training and skill development, income support programs and housing. While the 1995 statistics measuring access to health services favour women over men, improving access to health services has not translated into achieving equity in health outcomes.

The message from the latest earnings parity figures indicates that addressing equity in outcomes is not instantaneous. Despite equal pay decisions dating back almost three decades, women still do not receive the same pay for the same work. In February 1997, women's full‐time average ordinary weekly earnings were 84 per cent those of men. In May 1996, 63.6 per cent of workers with total earnings of under $100 per week were women and only 20.8 per cent of people with total earnings of $800 per week or above were women. The median total earnings figure for all female employees was $434.20 per week compared with $630 for all male employees. Women remained over‐represented in the lowest paid jobs, with two‐thirds of women concentrated in teaching, nursing, clerical work, sales and personal services. In February 1997, only 9.3 per cent of tradespersons and related workers were women, while 90.1 per cent of advanced clerical and service workers were women.

The coalition government has acknowledged the need for a holistic approach to women's issues, offering women greater choice through policy action in the following key areas: work and family life, employment opportunities, safety, income support and women in decision making. In its policy document Opportunities and choice for women, the government has confirmed its commitment to the national women's health program and has undertaken to continue existing funding and program arrangements. The program has received an additional two years funding in the 1996‐97 budget.

Funding under the program is directed principally towards improving health services for all women. It particularly targets those women who suffer inequality of access to health services due to economic disadvantage, cultural difference or geographic or linguistic isolation. Preliminary findings of the second phase evaluation conclude that the national women's health program has been an effective strategy in giving practical expression to the intent of the national women's health policy. The future of the program will be considered in the context of negotiations for the bilateral public health outcomes funding agreement.

Other gender specific measures supported by the coalition government include the alternative birthing services program, which promotes greater choice in birthing for women in the public health system. In relation to breast screening, the Commonwealth has recently undertaken booster television, radio and print advertising, as part of a strategy to achieve a 70 per cent participation rate by asymptomatic women aged 50 to 69 years by 1999. Unmatched funding has also been provided in 1996‐97 to a number of states for specific projects to increase participation rates.

The government demonstrated its commitment to maternal health in its policy statement Health throughout life. Increasing the intake of folic acid by women in childbearing years and encouraging breastfeeding were identified as nutrition measures which can have very positive outcomes for maternal and child health. The sum of $2.4 million has been provided over two years to support these initiatives.

I am pleased to be hosting a seminar directly addressing women's health issues on 1 July 1997. The objective of the seminar is to facilitate action by and discussion between local service providers, peak agencies, departmental representatives and coalition members on the issues affecting women's health and service provision in south‐western Sydney, including current strategies and future directions. The seminar will focus on four specific case studies, including anti violence and sexual assault campaigns, marginalised women's groups, female genital mutilation and bridging networks between peak agencies. I look forward to informing the Senate of the issues that come out of the seminar and to working to achieve positive outcomes that significantly improve the health and prospects of all Australian women.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to highlight the exceptional and strong build-up of the defence forces in the Top End of the Northern Territory and the many positive influences this is having on territorians at all levels. The Northern Territory has a long and proud history of being at the forefront of Australia's defence. On Thursday, 19 February 1942 at 9.58 a.m., 188 aircraft from the same Japanese force that attacked Pearl Harbour raided Darwin.

BREAK.PARA: This first raid killed 243 people and was the first of 64 recorded raids against Darwin and the Top End of Australia. Many people do not realise the extent of the raids, just as now many do not know the impact and importance of the changes currently taking place with regard to our defence forces in the Northern Territory.

The major development affecting the territory is the army presence in the north project. This project stems from the 1987 defence white paper, Defence of Australia, and commenced with the relocation of an armoured reconnaissance regiment in 1992 to Darwin. The subsequent build-up will see the relocation of the army's 1st Brigade and its support elements from Holsworthy and Puckapunyal to Darwin by 2001.

This is a huge project that is quite staggering in its scope. The numbers of defence personnel arriving in Darwin, the amount of equipment, the capital works that are being undertaken and many other factors are worth relating to help indicate why the Northern Territory is experiencing growth and change that enhance its already unique and fascinating character and make it one of the most important areas for the defence forces in Australia.

Some $850 million is to be spent on infrastructure development and relocation activities over the 10‐year period from 1992. I would like to describe some of the major areas and projects in which this very significant sum of money will be spent.

APIN involves the relocation to Darwin of approximately 2,300 personnel, 200 armoured fighting vehicles—leopard tanks, ASLAV light armoured vehicles and M113 armoured personnel carriers—and 500 support vehicles. This mammoth undertaking also includes all the supporting elements needed to keep such a huge machine running smoothly.

The numbers of personnel being transferred to the north are significant and are having a large impact on the territory's social infrastructure, and the housing industry in particular. By the year 2001 Australian Defence Force numbers in the Northern Territory will stand at 4,400—with the total defence `family', including dependants, well in excess of 10,000 people. This is a huge number of defence personnel and dependants to have based in any one region and is particularly significant when the small population base of the territory is taken into consideration.

Defence, as a major and increasing stakeholder in the Northern Territory, is fully aware of both its contribution to the development of the north and the need to incorporate infrastructure and social planning within broader community frameworks. The move of so many ADF personnel to the north was phased in over 10 years to allow adequate infrastructure and social planning to be implemented and allow defence families to integrate into the NT community. This integration into the community has been handled in a sensible and sensitive manner and perhaps the best example of this is the housing of personnel.

Apart from those single personnel based in Robertson Barracks and other towns in the NT, many of the personnel have been housed in Palmerston, Darwin's satellite city and Australia's fastest growing town. Due to the cooperation between Defence, the NT government and the community, we have not seen suburbs of Palmerston turned into enclaves of defence personnel. Rather we have seen policy and planning that resulted in a socially harmonious mix of defence personnel and civilians that has done a great deal to ensure that defence personnel assimilate into the community with the minimum effort and fuss and a great sense of contribution.

The NT government's Department of Asian Relations, Trade and Industry's Defence and Space Industries Group has played a major role in ensuring that Defence, the community, government and industry work together in the most efficient and acceptable manner possible. They play a large role in organising and facilitating meetings and communication between the defence forces, the community and industry. There are several ways in which this is done, and the Community Integration Committee and the Defence Industry Network Northern Territory are two examples.

A major part of the capital works program being conducted to accommodate APIN is the construction of Robertson Barracks at Palmerston, 25 kilometres east of Darwin. Robertson Barracks provide state of the art facilities for the army's 1st Brigade, and stage 2 of APIN will see $251 million spent on them over a period of 60 months completing the facility. This will bring the total relocation expenditure to over $500 million.

In addition to infrastructure such as Robertson Barracks, there are major works being conducted on Bradshaw Station field training area and the Delamere weapons range. These developments are two of many that will see significant expenditure in isolated areas of the Northern Territory and subsequent benefits for nearby communities. The Bradshaw Station field training area will have $54 million spent on developing it as a large-scale bushland facility where it can exercise under monsoonal wilderness conditions. The nearby town of Timber Creek will see significant benefits from the work being conducted and the troops stationed there.

There is also RAAF Base Tindal which will see base development stages 3 and 4 happening in the near future, costing $70 million and $31 million respectively. The town of Katherine is experiencing the benefits—along with Darwin, Palmerston and various bush areas of the territory—that come from such a large amount of expenditure and the flow-on effects that follow.

The APIN project, recent speeches by the Minister for Defence, the Hon. Ian McLachlan, and reports such as Defending Australia, the defence white paper of 1994, indicate the importance the defence forces place on the north. Defence activities in the Northern Territory are critical to the maintenance of the defence of Australia and its contribution to the security of the region into the next century.

The Northern Territory also places much importance on defence and recognises the major contribution to the territory economy it makes. By the year 2001 defence will be the third largest sector of the Northern Territory economy after tourism and mining. Currently, defence spending in the Northern Territory stands at over $7 million per week.

The recent defence efficiency review and the government's response to the recommen dations—the defence reform program—will see major changes in our military that will have a significant and positive impact on defence and the territory. The effectiveness of our armed forces will be enhanced by the recommendations which flow from the defence efficiency review and the implementation of the defence reform program. We will see an increased emphasis on the `sharp end' of the defence forces. Personnel will be redirected from administration areas into combat and combat support roles. This will not only improve the efficiency and fighting capacity of our forces but will enhance the many benefits received by the Northern Territory from the military.

Previously I mentioned that $850 million is to be spent as part of major ongoing infrastructure development and relocation activities in the territory. This is, and will be, spent particularly at Robertson Barracks, RAAF Base Darwin, Darwin Naval Base, Bradshaw Station and RAAF Base Tindal—several of which I examined in more detail earlier.

This $850 million does not, however, include the continuing and growing defence expenditure on operating costs in the territory which, in 1993, was estimated at about $80 million per year. ADF members in the Northern Territory are paid almost $100 million per year, with most of this flowing into the local economy—a significant amount of money that has a large role to play in the local economy.

Whilst I have tended to concentrate on the direct economic impact of the Defence Force, such as the benefits generated by capital works, salaries and administration, mention must also be made of the many other areas of economic and social benefit. These include many flow‐on benefits. Many Defence personnel have highly skilled partners who have made the move to the territory and brought with them their particular skills into the community. These include doctors, nurses, engineers and many more involved in community activities.

The highly sophisticated nature of modern military hardware is bringing new levels of technology and research into the area, resulting in new industry locating to the territory and existing industry expanding. In the De fence Industries sub‐study of the Wran report it was estimated that, for each dollar spent by defence in the Northern Territory, there is generated three more dollars—a significant input to the economy.

I would also like to mention the absolutely vital role the commanding officers have played. The RAAF's Vice‐Marshall Peter Nicholson invested considerable energy in establishing the groundwork for defence in the north from 1992 to 1994. He is now Air Commander Australia. I notice that a former Commander Northern Command, the navy's Commodore John Lord, will soon be promoted rear admiral and take over as Head, Joint Education and Training Canberra. Commander Lord served as Commander of Australia's Northern Command for two years from December 1994. I congratulate him on his recent promotion. He has been succeeded by the army's Brigadier Chris Roberts, who is continuing the fine example of visionary leadership.

It is a tribute to all of them and their personnel that they have been accepted, welcomed and embraced by the wider community. I acknowledge the important contribution that these families make to the territory economically and socially. There are hundreds of special influences and involvements on sports fields, in education and in commercial activities caused by this defence build‐up.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 15 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Minister's response to Senator Allison's question without notice (Senate Official Hansard , 7th May 1997, p. 2853) about mobile phone emissions, in which the Minister stated, "We will be taking advice from the experts":
(1) Who are the experts referred to by the Minister
(2) What qualifications and credentials in the field of public health do these experts have.
(3) In what areas of the public service are these experts located.
(4) If they are not located in the public service, in what areas do they practice.
(5) What criteria does the Government use to select such experts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I was referring to experts in this field which would include in the case referred to the researchers who undertook the Royal Adelaide Hospital study, the experts on the Committee on Electromagnetic Energy (EME) Public Health Issues and any other recognised experts (e.g. World Health Organisation).
(2) I can only comment on the qualifications of the experts on the EME Committee, which include a:
‐ Biomedical Engineer;
‐ Bachelor of Engineering (Communications) and Master of Systems Engineering;
‐ Doctor of Science of Engineering (DScEng) University of Sydney;
‐ PhD Biology University of Sydney;
‐ PhD Health Physicist; and
‐ PhD Chemist.

(3) Members of the EME Committee are public servants and are located in the Australian Radiation Laboratory, AUSTEL, CSIRO, Department of Communications and the Arts, Department of Health and Family Services, Spectrum Management Agency, Therapeutic Goods Administration.

(4) I am unable to comment on the areas experts operate, other than the EME Committee. They could be in private practice or employed by any number of organisations including universities, hospitals, international organisations or scientific institutions.

(5) Public servants are selected on the basis of their qualifications and experience judged against specified selection criteria. Selection criteria varies across Departments and Agencies to reflect the differing requirements of positions. Membership of the EME Committee is drawn from government agencies with responsibility for and expertise in EME Public Health matters.
